DEBATE.TITLE: EXPORT INSPECTION CHARGES (MISCELLANEOUS AMENDMENTS) BILL 1985[COGNATE BILLS:EXPORT INSPECTION (SERVICE CHARGE) BILL 1985EXPORT INSPECTION (ESTABLISHMENT REGISTRATION CHARGE) BILL 1985]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 22 August, on motion by Mr Kerin:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it is the wish of the House to debate the Export Inspection Charges (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1985 concurrently with the Export Inspection (Service Charge) Bill 1985 and the Export Inspection (Establishment Registration Charge) Bill 1985. As there is no objection, the Chair will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The severity of cost pressures on the agricultural export industries should not be underestimated. In recent years these industries have turned in an unusually sluggish export performance. Using constant prices, over the five years to 1983-84, total Australian export income rose by 4.5 per cent. Over that period, rural exports, accounting for 40 per cent or more of total income, fell into decline. Rural earnings in constant prices eased by 12.7 per cent, while the balance of non-rural exports rose by 20 per cent. Even the three-way economic boost in the 1982-83 financial year-the impact of the wages pause, drought-breaking rains and the upturn in the United States economy-has been slow to show up in the rural export figures. The only jump in rural export earnings of note occurred in 1984-85, influenced largely by the sudden crumbling of the dollar's value and the record wheat crop. The one-off influence of the devaluation is reflected in the Bureau of Agricultural Economics estimate of rural export income which is set to decline again in real terms this financial year. Yet it is these industries which hold the key to winding back Australian's foreign debt, spiralling from about $40 billion to around $70 billion in less than two years and to which we will be looking for some hope.

SPEECH.PARA: With relatively small levels of effective assistance, Australian farmers are world leaders in efficiency. We know that many of the influences on these export-oriented industries, such as world prices, overseas economic trends and domestic seasonal conditions, can scarcely be controlled. It is all the more important to ensure that factors which can be controlled, especially domestic costs, do not impinge more than necessary on these industries. It is in this context that the action of the Hawke Labor Government in sending export inspection charges skyward-200 per cent or more for some major produce-gives us most concern. Its action has been described-I think quite rightly so-as economic vandalism.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is shameful.

—It is shameful. The Opposition will support the Export Inspection Charges (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill, the Export Inspection (Service Charge) Bill and the Export Inspection (Establishment Registration Charge) Bill which are contingent Bills as they represent some effort to reduce the impact of export inspection charges on the industries concerned. We cannot make the point too forcefully, however, that this is much too little, much too late. If the Hawke Government was as fair dinkum about cutting farm costs as it claims it is, it would not be tinkering around the edges of these vastly increased charges which impact directly on primary export returns. The consistent policy position of the Liberal and National parties has been to remove export inspection charges and to bring our export industries more in line with those industries with which our agricultural industries are competing because it is clear that the burden our export industries are meeting is not being met by our competitors in the United States of America or anywhere else. Charges of the magnitude presently burdening rural exports, in particular the meat and the beef industry, have no place in the coalition platform.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendment to be sought by the Opposition expresses its concern that inadequate consideration has taken place with the export industries concerned to ensure that the most efficient and cost effective method of export inspection is adopted. However, we will not seek to amend the substance of this legislation despite the criticism over the way in which it has been brought into the Parliament without adequate industry consultation. The farmers are grateful for the smallest of mercies from the Hawke Government, and as these Bills have some potential to ease export inspection costs they will enjoy the Opposition's full support.

The purpose of the Bills is to expand the range of methods by which the inspection charges can be levied. The present flat rate or quantity-based charges will be supplemented by two other means of payment and a number of industries will be able to pay by any one method or by some combinations of methods. The Export Inspection (Service Charge) Bill introduces a man-hour basis for payment; that is, the charge is levied over time instead of quality. The Export Inspection (Establishment Registration Charge) Bill introduces a charge upon registration or annual renewal of registration of an export licence. In summary, exporters in certain industries will have the option of any of these three methods of payment, or in some cases a combination of methods.

The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin), in his second reading speech on the service charge Bill, estimated that industries should eventually benefit through the streamlining of inspections by $18m per annum. Little or none of this benefit will be realised in the present financial year. The savings, by the time they are fully experienced, will be little more than a step in the right direction.

Already under this Government the cost of inspections to industry has more than doubled from $23.9m in 1982-83 to $53m this year. That is quite a burden on industries that are struggling to maintain their footing in the world market scene. By the time full savings under these Bills are realised the difference will barely be noticeable to the industries. So it will be cynical in the extreme for honourable members opposite to argue that the Government has gone as far as it could be expected to remove the burden it has imposed.

As I said earlier, the farmers are grateful for small mercies. Major primary industries utilising export inspection services are the meat, wool, grains, fruits, dairy produce and fish industries. Of these, the Australian fisheries will gain earliest access to the new charging systems. Fisheries are likely to opt for a change from the existing per kilogram charge to a combination of man-hour and registration charges.

I note that, under clause 7 of the miscellaneous amendments Bill, once a commodity is subject to a service charge it cannot then be subject to a quantity charge. It is anticipated that the new system will be in place before the end of 1985. The poultry meat industry has recently agreed to payment on the basis of registration only. Other industries named by the Minister as having an interest in these Bills are the meat, dried fruits, canned fruits and dairy produce industries.

It is important that the Parliament understand just what discussions have taken place. The Minister told this House that discussions had commenced with the meat industry. In fact he has broached the subject once, in a very preliminary fashion. He was told bluntly by the meat exporters that a fee for service was just not on. Why, then, does he appear keen to pursue these discussions? On what basis does the Minister-I hope he answers this question-estimate savings of $18m--

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is the Minister?

—Yes, that is a good question: Where is the Minister? In any case he has advisers here who will be good enough to put the question to him. On what basis does the Minister estimate savings of $18m if the meat industry, accounting for 90 per cent of all export inspection revenue, rejects the changes to the method of payment? On what basis does he estimate those savings?

SPEECH.PARA: There is wide concern within the industry that the Minister is attempting to force a fee for service on exporters and that this legislation represents a foot in the door. I am not saying that; that is what the industry, from discussions I have had with it, believes.

Let it be said very clearly that the industry will not accept bullying tactics by the Minister, in the same way that the dairy industry would not be bludgeoned into submission. The abattoir chain typically experience fluctuations in supply and variations in killing hours per week. A flat charge would in no way represent a step towards the user pays principle. Rather, the meat industry could be severely disadvantaged through a fee for service payment, especially if the Minister were to attempt to force these charges on the industry at some later stage.

I call on the Minister to give an undertaking, in his response to this debate, that the meat industry will continue to have total freedom in selecting the manner of payment which best suits its requirements. I have been asked to put that point forward in this debate here today. The industry wants a special undertaking in that regard. If the Minister can give that undertaking, I am sure it will be gratefully received.

TALK.START.PARA: —They won't even work at Mudginberri.

—That is absolutely correct. It is a disgrace. It is also curious that the Parliament has been asked to approve these Bills even though the dried and canned fruits industries and dairy producers have neither been advised nor consulted--

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Loyd-They were not consulted at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —They were not consulted at all, which to me seems an extraordinary state of affairs.
—When you have SPC and Ardmona, the two biggest companies in the industry, not being consulted.

—It is an outrage. This has been the problem for the farm sector. There has been little or no consultation with so many of these industries that have been affected by legislation. The Minister has a responsibility to consult with these industries because, surely, we produce legislation in this Parliament in the interests of the industries that are supposed to be served by the elected representatives in this Parliament. This is not some monolithic institution. It is not some institution which makes laws apart from the interests of the industries or the people whom this Parliament is supposed to serve. The Parliament is here to serve the people. Every piece of legislation introduced into this place should be canvassed. I add, in fairness to him, that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has attempted to adopt this principle. He has come in for much criticism for having had his summits and having tried to pull people together and to achieve consensus, which is hard to get. His Ministers should follow his example and enter into consultation before bringing legislation into this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: Once again we are witnessing the reluctance of the Minister to ensure that full and proper consultation take place before legislation is presented to the Parliament. Farmers are sick and tired of learning about Bills after they have come into this place. Farmers should not be treated as third class citizens. I hope that the Minister has recognised, from the mistakes that he has already made with regard to the dairying industry, that such action will not serve him, his Government or the industries any good purpose.

Inspection costs cannot be raised by 200 per cent or more without having serious repercussions on the competitiveness of our producers. On a number of occasions this Government has attempted to shift blame for its actions regarding inspection charges by claiming that our parties adopted the 50 per cent cost recovery principle. It is true that a move in this direction was indicated in 1981. However, 1982-83 Budget Paper No. 1 sets out clearly why the Fraser Government did not pursue this course. The industries were hit savagely by drought, experiencing heavy increases in debt, and could not be expected to foot such additional cost so the right decision was made because of the circumstances of the industry and its inability to meet these sorts of charges at that time, and the same situation applies today. The decision to increase inspection charges was abandoned because of the declining terms of trade of farmers.

I can understand the battles the Minister has, because when I was a Minister I had the same sorts of battles. The Department of the Treasury constantly tries to do the right and proper thing for the macroeconomic conditions of the economy, but to do these things across the board without taking into account the circumstances or problems of an industry or a sector of the community can only bring great hardship upon sectors of the Australian community.

It is all very well to say that we should have a user pay principle. If one applied that sort of principle to the urban public, the people the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Hand) represents, how much would public transport cost the average commuter going to his job? There is no suggestion that there should be a user pay principle in the city of Sydney. It costs about $1.5m a day in Sydney to help move people from western Sydney to their place of employment. Enormous subsidies are being paid in that regard. Where is the user pay concept being adopted for the average citizens?

The people whom I and so many honourable members of this Parliament represent today have reached income levels one-third of average weekly earnings. I am not talking about wealthy farmers, those of us who were lucky enough to inherit our farms; I am talking about soldier settlers, people who have struggled on small blocks to make ends meet and have not been trained for any other form of activity. These people today are in great financial difficulty. There is a new poverty in the Australian community, as the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow) is aware. He is honest enough to stand up to fight for the people affected, and I know he has tried to do that. There is an obligation on all of us to represent the rural people who have problems. He is in the wrong party; he ought to be on this side of the House to join with us to fight on their behalf.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about how you are going to protect them against telephone charges.
—The honourable member for Melbourne will cease interjecting.
—Can you answer the question?
—I warn the honourable member for Melbourne.

—Thank you, Mr Speaker. I certainly would not want to provoke him. The industries affected by this legislation have been hit savagely by drought. They are experiencing an increasingly heavy debt load. The total debt of the farm sector is now in excess of $6,000m. Many farmers are paying up to 20 per cent interest through their banks. Who can survive paying 20 per cent interest? Who can survive in business paying 15, 16, 17, 18 or 20 per cent interest year after year? I can think of no more crippling impost than the interest rate burden; it is far worse than the burden of export inspection charges. The decision to increase inspection charges was therefore abandoned, as I said, in 1981 because of the declining terms of trade of farmers. By contrast, this anti-farmer Government could not care less about the plight of the rural sector. The now Prime Minister, in his rural policy speech in 1983, said:

SPEECH.PARA: At the outset of this campaign I make an unqualified commitment to maintaining the viability of Australia's great rural sector and the provincial infrastructure.

That great undertaking was made at that time, and yet we have seen in three Budgets and two mini-Budgets $442m ripped off the Australian farm sector. Is that the sort of recognition and unqualified commitment necessary to maintain the viability of Australia's great rural sector, pressured today by the internal costs and pressured by the European Economic Community in our international market scene? I know that the Minister for Primary Industry, who is in the House at the moment, is concerned about the activities of the European Economic Community and has done a fairly good job in highlighting that difficulty. The Bureau of Agricultural Economics report has been a very constructive attempt to present some of the options that surely are available to the EEC countries to handle their own domestic problems but not, at the same time, to disrupt world trade to the extent that they are. These industrial nations would not for one minute have industry and manufacturing outside the terms of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. But so far as agriculture is concerned they can stay outside the terms of GATT because agriculture involves only damned farmers, a minority group in the community. It is the Third World countries, the developing countries, and countries like Australia that will suffer while ever that continues.

That is one of the great challenges. It is no good fighting on that international front unless we try to recognise the problems here at home. What sort of argument do we have to put in Brussels if the Government loads the farm sector with export inspection charges, if it rips off $442m in three Budgets and two mini-Budgets? Mr Andriesson and others surely would be saying: `If the Government is really concerned about the farm sector and the welfare of the farmers of Australia it surely would be attacking the problem in its own backyard'. When the Government singles farmers out for treatment, as it has done, it makes its attempts fairly hollow. Without warning the Labor Government announced in its first Budget a 200 per cent leap in export inspection charges. There was no election forecast, no prior warning.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is your policy. Why don't you be truthful about it?

—It was indeed our policy but it was a principle that was never implemented. The honourable member should go back to the Budget Papers of 1982-83, before he came here. The reasons were spelled out. My dear friend the honourable member for Bendigo needs to be very cautious and careful on this issue and should get in there and fight his own people. He should make sure he fights them on the right matters, because if he does not he will not be here as the member for Bendigo after the next election. The Government has consistently sought out the farm industries for special treatment ever since the Prime Minister's speech in 1983. The decision to raise the charges caused such an uproar within the meat industry that the Minister for Primary Industry was forced to refer the new rates to the Interim Inspection Policy Council for review. The Government then proceeded to ignore the strong stand by the Council-a very reasonable stand-for a two-year moratorium on the increases. Labor simply could not wait to get its hands in the farmers' and meat exporters' pockets.

SPEECH.PARA: It is worth recalling the statement of the Australian Meat Exporters' Federal Council of 25 July 1984:
The IIPC package was a reasonable approach, yet the Minister discarded the critical sections of the package without any consultation with the industry.
This makes a mockery of the Hawke Government's stated commitment to consultation and consensus.

The export inspection charges are a good example of the wide variance in attitude towards primary industry which exists between members on either side of this House. The Liberal- National Party policy, laid out prior to the election last December, gives this commitment:
The Commonwealth will co-operate with industry bodies and the States concerned to ensure that the inspection is efficiently conducted without duplication and at the Commonwealth's expense.

It is pleasing to note there has been some pro- gress in removing duplication of services. The big obstacle to improved competitiveness, however, is the continuing high level of export charges. To underline this commitment I foreshadow the following amendment:

Whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House is of the opinion that inadequate consultation has taken place with the export industries concerned to ensure that the most efficient and cost-effective export inspection system is adopted.

Madam Deputy Speaker, recently the Chairman of the Australian Meat Exporters' Federal Council, Mr Kevin Bowtell, indicated that bur- eaucratic regulation within the meat industry is now costing perhaps $20m a year. Among the findings of the Cameron Committee is that, since trials began in 1983, the objective meat exporttrade descriptions have not effectively served their purpose. The Committee also believes that export inspections by the Commonwealth should be restricted to such areas as health and hygiene and to assist with the development of a national description service. In general, there is an impression that export inspections are heavy with red tape, and that significant cost savings are achievable. I note the Minister's reaction that he wants further study into these matters.

Our meat industries face severe competition in terms of both price and market access, especially along the Asian-Pacific basin rim. If some of the more intensive aspects of inspection services can be modified this saving could well be translated into significant savings. The Export Inspection Service has a staff of 2,500, and I know efforts are presently under way to streamline the service and reduce staff numbers by natural attrition without compromising the standard of the service. Meat inspector numbers have been reduced by 300, mainly in the area of post-mortem inspection procedures, while the number of staff attending to inspection of canned and frozen fruit and vegetables has been lowered from 40 to 11. New procedures for some industries, which include `flying squads' of inspectors checking produce at random, in many cases may serve the same purpose as more intensive inspection procedures.

In government the Liberal and National parties will review the inspection service to establish whether further cost savings are achievable. Industries will be invited to submit proposals to overcome such difficulties as those experienced by the live sheep export trade in the calculation of charges according to specific consignments rather than total shipments-a problem which has unnecessarily raised the cost of inspections beyond an equitable level.

The Liberal and National parties will continue to pressure the Hawke Labor Government to reverse its decision imposing heavy export inspection cost increases on the agricultural export industries at a time when they are facing severe competition on a corrupted world market. These Bills are a step in the right direction, but they are by no means adequate. I move:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

`whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House is of the opinion that inadequate consultation has taken place with the export industries concerned to ensure that the most efficient and cost-effective export inspection system is adopted'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Deputy Leader of the National Party, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt), has again been fulfilling a negative role-the negative role that the Opposition has been developing. I thought we were told yesterday that such a role would finish and that the Opposition would give the Government credit where it was due. But I shall return to the honourable member for Gwydir shortly. I commend the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) on the introduction of the Export Inspection Charges (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill, the Export Inspection (Service Charge) Bill and the Export Inspection (Establishment Registration Charge) Bill, because they are further evidence of his commitment to the rural sector and the need to reduce farm costs by making government involvement more cost-efficient for the farm producer.

SPEECH.PARA: We must have meat inspection because of the present international and national requirements and the fact that government is required to have involvement on and off the slaughter floor by overseas governments; and our State governments also require involvement in varying degrees in inspection. Inspection is also required by the purchasing countries on a range of our primary products other than meat-for instance, fish and dairy products. The maintenance of a high level of quality is important if we are to hold our current export markets or establish new ones.

Inspection is costly, and it is the high cost that is of concern to the Government. Most key agricultural exporting countries impose inspect- ion charges, with costs in European countries ranging from 50 per cent to 100 per cent cost recovery. New Zealand will have two-thirds cost recovery by 1986, and the United States of America will have 100 per cent cost recovery over three years. Australia's cost recovery rate is 50 per cent.

The Deputy Leader of the National Party has been fulfilling that negative role of opposition in his speech today. He has been ignoring the export inspection charge shambles which was handed over to this Government in 1983. I take as an example the abalone industry. Under the system of the Deputy Leader of the National Party, with the present new identikit economic rationalist, the present Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) as Treasurer, the total weight of abalone was added-shell, water, the lot-and a rate per kilogram was charged. That was a totally unfair system for an industry which has got itself together nationally. The industry has done that, and this Government is prepared to respond. Having been involved in the negotiations with Barry McRoberts of Ulladulla and Max Cartner of Eden, the Government has responded, contrary to the statement by the honourable member for Gwydir, to representations from the industry. Instead of charging on the basis of weight, the new system will charge on the basis of staff time.

Contrary to the words of the honourable member for Gwydir, the Government has been trimming the inspection force to reduce costs. The service was reduced by 120 inspectors in 1984. Export inspection cost Australia about $102m in 1984-85, and the Government met about $60m of that cost. This Government has been able to absorb increased costs to close to $10.5m in 1985-86, and the charges will remain the same in 1985-86 as they were in 1984-85. Whilst the aim must be to reduce these costs to rural producers as much as possible and to withdraw inspectors, it is important that the inspection system is such that it guarantees overseas market acceptability for our primary products. Any deregulation or withdrawal of the Government from present areas of inspection must be done in such a way as to ensure that overseas countries' requirements and State requirements are met and that integrity of product is protected so that it can be sold. The legislation before us ensures this protection and, at the same time, allows cost reduction and a more equitable base for the calculation of export inspection charges.

The Commonwealth first introduced meat export inspection in 1914 and the concept of export inspection charges in the 1920s. An export inspection service was set up in 1982 following the meat substitution scandal and it assumed responsibilities for inspection from the Bureau of Animal Health. The Export Inspection Service's role is regulatory, with responsibility for providing an efficient and effective inspection service for primary industry products to ensure that they are safe and wholesome, that they are informatively and honestly described and that product standards comply with the requirements of importing countries to facilitate trade. At present the Government recoups a proportion of the cost of export inspection through charges based on quantity. Under these arrangements producers are charged at an equal rate regardless of the actual cost of inspection. As a result producers who have brought in efficient methods of inspection pay the same as other producers although their actual cost of inspection may be lower.

Despite strong representations from rural producers and processors for a change to a more equitable and efficient system the previous Government failed to act. Instead of talking about selling to multinationals and quasi-government organisations, such as Telecom Australia, which turns its profits back to the people of Australia, the Leader of the Opposition would have done better as Treasurer to attempt some genuine cost reducing reforms, the sorts of reforms which this Government has undertaken since coming to office in 1983 and which these Bills provide. This Government is genuine about its efforts to rationalise and reduce the costs of government involvement in industry. The changes to export inspection that are proposed in these Bills will save our rural industries over $18m a year. Dual State-Commonwealth fees will be eliminated and new inspection arrangements introduced. Industry will have the option of moving to an alternative charging system. Under the new alternative method of calculating charges to be introduced by these Bills, establishments will have the option of paying an initial registration fee and charges based on the time inspection takes. This will provide an incentive for efficiency and will relate charges more closely to actual cost. Exporters will be able to choose the method of inspection they feel is best suited to their pro- duct in terms of cost efficiency. They may remain under the present system or they may move to a system involving a registration fee and a per hour inspector rate. Both the fish and poultry meat industries have opted for a basic establishment registration fee and subsequent charges calculated on the actual time taken to inspect.

The Export Inspection Charges (Miscellan- eous Amendments) Bill will ensure that establishments that have opted for a service charge will be exempt from quantity charges. This will prevent double charging. Farm costs have slowed to an average rise of 6.2 per cent under this Government from a staggering 10.9 per cent under the previous Government. From the statements made by the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair) we would not have known that farm cost rises have actually dropped by over 4 per cent from 10.9 to 6.2 per cent. These Bills are part of the Government's continuing efforts to reduce those costs even further. I commend the Bills to the House.

Is there any evidence that the countries importing meat from Australia demand that the Federal Government must pay the wages of meat inspectors?

So far as is practicable, in the light of overseas requirements and sound meat inspection practices, managements should be encouraged to take over responsibilities for work on the chain now performed by meat inspectors.
That is what Mr Justice Woodward told this Parliament. Paragraph 9.5 continues:
The numbers of meat inspectors should be correspondingly reduced but, on average, their work should become more responsible and call for greater experience and higher personal qualities.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my pleasure to speak in support of the Export Inspection Charges (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill, the Export Inspection(Service Charge) Bill and the Export Inspection (Establishment Registration Charge) Bill. I will spend some of my time on the precise nature of the Bills-
—The Chair hopes that you will spend all your time on them.

—I used the word `precise', Madam Deputy Speaker. I will make some precise points about the Bills and some more general points about them. The primary purpose of these Bills is to extend the range of options for imposing charges on industry to recoup part of the costs of inspecting rural produce for export. The Export Inspection (Service Charge) Bill provides an option for a charge to be imposed on a manhour basis. The Export Inspection (Establishment Registration Charge) Bill provides for a charge to be made upon the registration of an export-registered establishment where this is requested by an industry. The Export Inspection Charges (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill, which, in a sense, provides amendments consequential on the other Bills, will ensure that there is greater flexibility in the future in the way in which export inspection charges are calculated.

SPEECH.PARA: These Bills are important. Contrary to what has been said by some of the Opposition speakers, they provide meaningful options for charging inspection costs. They do that on a basis which accords fairly closely to the user pays concept. Under current arrangements, export inspection is carried out for a range of different products in a range of establishments such as abattoirs, fruit canneries and fish processing plants. A flat rate charge is imposed and that rate is imposed regardless of the cost and type of establishment. The new method of recouping costs embodied in this legislation will give industry an opportunity to streamline its operations. It will promote more fairness in the application of inspection charges and, perhaps more importantly, it will provide and allow for more efficiency in the delivery and use of the inspection services which are provided.

Honourable members would be aware that a major review of inspection services has recently been completed. As a result, simplified inspection procedures will be introduced between now and June 1986, which will lead to significant savings in the cost of running the inspection service and immediate cost savings to industry. The new arrangements in terms of those cost savings will benefit industry by some $18m per annum. Those new arrangements have been taken into account in calculating the charges which will apply through the 1985-86 financial year.

Let me give a brief summary of the legislation. The charging legislation in this package of Bills will enable industries to make a choice. They can opt for the new charging system which will encourge individual operators to establish systems which reduce their export inspection needs and costs while maintaining the required standards, which are crucial, of hygiene and quality. Alternatively, under this legislation, they can remain on the current flat rate charging system whereby operators with less expensive export inspection systems tend to cross-subsidise the operators with more expensive systems of inspection. These new charging arrangements provide industry with an opportunity to work positively with the Government to reduce costs to farmers and to taxpayers who, of course, subsidise inspection activity.

The element of cost savings and the more efficient use of resources, which are embodied in this legislation are crucial to Australia's primary producers and those in the export market. If we look at Australia's exports and its export performance for the last financial year we appreciate the enormous importance of exports, in particular agricultural exports, to Australia's overall prosperity and, in that sense, these Bills are important. Total Australian exports for 1984-85 were $30.6 billion. It is significant that of that sum $11.1 billion were agricultural exports. In other words, 36 per cent of Australia's total exports come from the agricultural sector.

In terms of specific products, most of which, of course, are affected by this legislation, wheat brought in $2.7 billion worth of exports last year and that is almost 10 per cent of Australia's total exports. Wool brought in $2.4 billion in exports which is about 6 per cent or 7 per cent of Australia's total exports. Beef is obviously an important aspect of this legislation in terms of inspection charges. Boneless beef brought in over $1 billion and other beef $37m. So there is over $1 billion worth of exports of beef. Fish and other exports which, in terms of this legislation are important, brought in more than $400m. On the other side, exports of lamb, goat and mutton products-a good market-brought in $150m. I think the broad figures are worth repeating. Of a total of $30.6 billion worth of exports from Australia more than $11 billion comes from agriculture. That is 36.2 per cent of total exports. We are talking about exports. In terms of those basic exports, particularly meat and fish products, these export inspection Bills are important. Without the effort embodied in these Bills to make the system more efficient and more cost effective and, at the same time, to retain our international reputation as an exporter, we could not hope to maintain those high levels of agricultural exports.

A number of claims have been made by Opposition speakers during the debate on this legislation. I note that the Opposition is not opposing this legislation although it has moved a minor amendment to it. The most interesting points to come out of the Opposition's contribution to this debate were the very conflicting accounts of the Opposition's policy on export inspection that were given by the spokesman on primary industry, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt), and the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey). The Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia, the Opposition spokesman on primary industry, was totally emphatic that, under the Fraser Government, there was never any intention of proceeding with 50 per cent cost recovery in the export sector. That was the view that the spokesman on primary industry put but, of course, only a matter of minutes later, when the honourable member for O'Connor was speaking, he made it quite clear that he took an equally opposite direction; that the Fraser Government was going to move to 50 per cent cost recovery in those industries. So there is quite a difference in approach between those two representatives on the Opposition benches. I am not sure that they knew what they were going to do in government. I think one message is evident if we look back in retrospect. We can see now that the Opposition did not know at the time what its policies for the primary sector were or should have been. I do not think it knew where it was going in the future. What has come out of today's debate is that if the Opposition ever got the chance of being in government again it would still have no idea at all of whether it would endorse the 50 per cent cost recovery or whether it might go to some other system. I think that point ought to be emphasised.

A number of other points were made during the debate. Again the honourable member for O'Connor made some points regarding fuel prices and he made them very aggressively as is his wont in this House. I just make the point for the interest of honourable members that the index of fuel prices paid by the Australian primary producers-the figures are not rubbery, cooked or crooked, as some people on the Opposition benches might like to suggest-shows an increase of 40 per cent in 1979-80. That was not under our Government; it was under the Liberal-National Party Government. In 1980-81 fuel prices increased by 25 per cent. Two increases have occurred under the Hawke Government. In 1983-84 there was an increase of 8 per cent and in 1984-85 there was an increase of 8 per cent. I want to correct this misapprehension, this misguided-I hope-enthusiasm that the honuorable member for O'Connor has in his concern for the rural constituency. He needs to get his figures right because this Government is concerned about farm costs. We have taken an enormous number of initiatives to reduce farm costs so that our export markets and our primary producers can be more competitive and stand on their own feet in the world market.

I just want quickly to run through those farm costs because this legislation will also play an important part in reducing costs to those exporting sectors. I wish to run through the figures for the last few years, and I do this for the benefit of the honourable member of Wannon (Mr Hawker) who seems to have some difficulty understanding the figures prepared by the Bureau of Agricultrual Economics. The honourable member is in the House. It is nice to see him in the House. Only one member of the Liberal Party of Australia is in the House. Members of that Party are not too interested in this legislation or how it affects primary producers. For the honourable member's benefit, I will run through these figures. The percentage increase in farm costs was 12 per cent in 1976-77; 11 per cent in 1977-78 and 7 per cent in 1978-79. Here comes the good part; it is bad for farmers and in terms of the Opposition's record: There was a 12 per cent increase in 1979-80; a 15 per cent increase in 1980-81; an 11 per cent increase in 1981-82 and an 11 per cent increase in 1982-83. That is what happened. I see that the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) is in the House. He has an interest in this legislation and he has an interest in Australia's rural sector. He is staggered by the increase. The average percentage increase in farm costs under the Opposition when it was in government was more than 12 per cent per annum. The relevant figures under this Government-I know that the Minister will be interested-are 8 per cent in 1983-84 and 6 per cent in 1984-85, and the estimate for this year is around the 6 per cent mark. In other words, the rate of increase in farm costs has halved under this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the terms of trade?

—The honourable member asks about the terms of trade. His spokesman on primary industry, the honourable member for Gwydir, only moments ago complimented our Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) on the efforts he is making overseas, as is our Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), to get the best possible markets for our exports and to get our foot again into the European Economic Community in order to get rid of some of its corruptive trade practices so that there is a fair go for Australian producers.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill is concerned with the costs to our exporting primary industries. This Government remains totally committed to reduce farm costs as much as possible for Australia's export industries and primary producers. There is no doubt that in that broad sense the single greatest contribution we can make, which is a point made often by our excellent Minister for Primary Industry, is to get the economy right. That is the single greatest contribution we can make to improve the returns to farmers. A fair assessment by Opposition members-there is not one single National Party member in the House now-would indicate that we have done our part in getting the economy right. We have achieved the best growth for two years of any country of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. We have halved the rate of inflation. We have floated the dollar-something that the Opposition never had the courage to do. We have deregulated the banking system to put some competition into it. We have reduced industrial disputation to its lowest level for 17 years and real labour unit costs are down to the levels of the early 1960s. That is what we are doing for our export industries, our primary producers, because we want them to be cost effective and cost competitive and we want them to be able to stand on their own two feet in the export market.

We are getting the economy right. The floating of the dollar and its devaluation alone have brought a net benefit to Australia's primary producers of many hundreds of millions of dollars. In terms of the full year effect, the wool industry should be better off by more than $200m, the beef industry by more than $300m, and the wheat industry by more than $800m because we floated the dollar and let it find its real level. But it is not only through the broad macro-economic policies that we have introduced that we have been able to reduce the farm costs for our primary producers. We have done other things to maximise the returns for our farmers. We have completely reorganised the meat and livestock industry. We have restructured it. We have put policy ahead of politics. We have given our statutory marketing authorities some commercial freedom to maximise returns for farmers. We have introduced new wheat marketing arrangements. They are the result of tough but fair negotiations which the Minister handled. They now provide a sound basis for this industry to maintain market access in what is an increasingly competitive world environment. Only three weeks ago in the Federal Budget, the third Budget this Government has brought down, we provided for a full rebate on the excise on diesel fuel which is used by primary producers. This is at a cost of $35m per annum.

SPEECH.PARA: In seconding the amendment put forward by the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Hunt), I think it is disappointing that the Government has moved to put these Bills before the House without proper consultation with the industry. Export industries are very conscious of the problems they are facing now. We welcome the attempts by the Government to reduce the cost of export inspection services, but frankly, we feel that they do not go far enough. They do not really address the inefficiency in various sections of the Export Inspection Service, in particular, the massive costs of the meat inspection service, which, as has been said already by previous speakers, is by far and away the biggest service provided by the Department of Primary Industry.

It is interesting to look at the cost of the export inspection services. Going back to 1979-80, 8.8 million cattle and 30 million sheep were slaughtered and the export inspection services cost $31m. In 1983-84 the number of cattle slaughtered was seven million, which was a fall of 20 per cent, and the number of sheep slaughtered fell by 21 per cent, yet the cost of the export inspection services rose by 150 per cent. I know that the New South Wales Government had handed over the State service, but even so the cost increases are out of this world. It is interesting to draw a comparison between the cost of the meat inspection service in Victoria and the cost of the Federal inspection service. As my colleague the honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur) said in a speech in this House on 8 October last year:
. . . the cost of the service in Victoria runs at $8.4m.
That is the State meat inspection service. He continued:

The service inspects something like 85 to 90 per cent of the meat processed in that State. Industry sources estimate that it costs about $13m to render the same Federal inspection service which covers about 10 to 15 per cent of the remaining export products.

The Country Abattiors and Wholesalers Association of Victoria reports that because of this cost differential the State meat inspectors could inspect and brand the present export kill in the Victorian export works for a cost of $4m.

So one can see that on a contractual basis the Victorian inspectors could save the producers and processors $9m.

The State service, which is doing the major part, according to the most recent figures, is covering 16.4 million units. Those figures include sheep and cattle, so that they are slightly different from the last group of figures. That is costing about $8.4m. On a per head basis the Federal inspection service costs three times more per unit than the State service.
It is interesting to read a letter sent by the Country Abattoirs and Wholesalers Association of Victoria to the former Minister for Agriculture in Victoria, which stated, in part:

As both Local and Export Meat Inspectors have the same qualifications it is possible for Victorian State Meat Inspectors to inspect and brand the present export kill in Victorian Export Works for at most $4 million.
Going this way, and using Victorian Meat Inspectors on a contract basis to the Federal Government would save the Australian Meat and Livestock Industries of Australia $9 million.

When we talk about the efficiency of the service, the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) has a long way to go before he can come in here and say that we are providing a cost effective or cost efficient service.

It is disappointing to the industry when it is facing so many problems to find that no real effort is being made to improve the efficiency. Past debates on the meat inspection service in this place have highlighted some of the incredible inefficiencies of overmanning. About 18 months ago I brought into this House the example of 150 meat inspectors who at the time were on full pay and were doing absolutely no work. It is interesting to note also the cost of the Export Inspection Service. If we look at Appropriation Bill (No. 1) we find that the total cost of the Export Inspection Service for all industries for 1985-86 is projected to be just over $102m. This compares with $88.6m in the 1984-85 figures. That is an increase of over 15 per cent in one year. We are told that this year inflation might be something like 8 per cent or higher. Those figures probably are a bit rubbery, as we heard earlier, but by any standard that is a massive increase in the cost of export inspection services. I challenge the Minister to find ways of making the Service more efficient and reducing that cost, because that really is a massive increase.

That highlights the basic problem which the Minister and the whole Government face, namely, that the Australian Council of Trade Unions is directing this Government. In particular, in this situation obviously it is the Meat Inspectors Association which is directing the Government on how to run the service, what the staffing levels should be and how many people should be employed in the industry. The Minister is hamstrung. In some ways I feel rather sorry for him, but it is his decision to be in the Australian Labor Party, which is subject to the whims and fancies of the union movement.

When we talk about efficiency, we should look at how the inspection service is implemented and paid for and how it works when it is put into the various abattoirs around Australia. The basic problem which the Minister has not addressed, which he should address, is summed up very well in a paper delivered by Dr Miller, the former Secretary of the Department of Primary Industry, who is now Director of the Economic Planning Advisory Council, when he spoke at the closing session of the National Agricultural Outlook Conference last year. What he said applies specifically to the problem about which we are talking today. He said:

The hip pocket nerve is a most effective motivator . . . If a meat boning operator doesn't pay for the services of meat inspectors, he doesn't care how hard his plant is to inspect or how many inspectors are needed. If inspectors are not offered increased pay for improved productivity, they have an incentive to use their industrial muscle to maintain their numbers. If individual abattoirs pay for inspection by an invariable slaughter levy, they have no incentive to plan their layout and operations to reduce inspection costs.

Dr Miller highlighted the real problem of the cost of export inspection services, which is the problem the Government ought to be addressing. Unfortunately, because the Government is subject to the views of the unions, this is one area from which the Government will run a mile before it will face up to the problem.

It is interesting to look at the particular example of the export inspection services problem at the Mudginberri meat works. I think all honourable members are well aware of the massive increases in productivity that have been attained at Mudginberri meat works by employers and employees getting together to make the productivity of the works rise. In fact, the meat workers at Mudginberri are getting double what their fellow workers in other abattoirs are getting. The killing cost at Mudginberri is way below the cost at Katherine. The figures are something like $38 per beast at Mudginberri while at Katherine, using the union endorsed tally system, the cost is over $140 per beast. It is important to remind the Minister that his agreement at Mudginberri was ratified by the Full Bench of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, yet he would not support the meat works when an illegal picket line was put there to stop the Federal meat inspectors going into the works. The picket line was illegal yet the Minister, who is responsible for providing the Federal Export Inspection Service, was quite gutless, I think, in not ordering those inspectors into the works. He had a very simple option: If they were not prepared to work he should have taken steps to have them dismissed. He comes in here and says: `What are we supposed to do with these inspectors? We cannot just sack them'. I suggest that the Minister look at the number of station hands on various properties around Australia who have lost their jobs because of the lack of profitability in primary industry at the moment and not try to adopt a double standard quite so often. As I have already said, he is facing the problem of the unions dictating to the Government what it should be doing, and the Meat Inspectors Association is no exception.

Another interesting thing to note about Mudginberri is that all the staff who work there live on site, and there is no doubt that there would be absolutely no problem in the inspectors living on site. If that were the case, the picket linewould be irrelevant because no-one would be crossing it. The meat workers certainly do not have to cross it every day and the meat inspectors would not have to cross it either. So I suggest to the Minister that the so-called problem of meat inspectors refusing to cross the picket line is rubbish. Because the union told the inspectors what to do, the Government refused to act.

As the Deputy Leader of the National Party said, we are grateful for small mercies and the few improvements in export inspection services but we feel that there has been inadequate consultation. It is an accusation that is being made about this Minister more frequently. He is listening less and less to the industry and I think that it will become more evident in the type of legislation that he is bringing into this House that he has no real feelings for what the industry reasonably expects.

The other point to remember about the Export Inspection Service is that it is nothing more or less than a tax on exports. We have heard in this chamber many times in recent days of the problems we have with the balance of trade. We have enormous balance of trade problems and the only way we can improve that situation is by increasing exports. Obviously if we are trying to increase exports the last thing we want to do is put a tax on them. Yet this Government has done that very thing, and it has done very little in other ways to help the problem. Something was said earlier in the debate about the devaluation. Obviously that has helped export industries, but the fact remains that devaluation is something that a country really hopes to avoid because devaluation is nothing more or less than the rest of world saying: `You are not worth what you used to be; we are going to cut the capital base of your country'. If any business were faced with that sort of rundown of its assets it would be going broke very quickly.

My final point is that when the coalition is returned to government it will be looking very closely at the Export Inspection Service. In particular we will be looking very closely at contracting out part of the service. We have seen, from the figures that I have already mentioned, the massive inefficiency and increase in costs of the Service. There is no doubt that there is something violently wrong with its level of efficiency. Unfortunately the Minister has shown that he is not prepared to address this problem but I assure him that when we get back into government we will address it for the benefit of all exporters and primary producers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would seem that the Opposition does not learn anything if one takes into account many of the arguments used, particularly by the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker). I do not accuse him of making these statements with malice, but he is wrong in most of what he said. I think the only way I can satisfactorily try to convince him is either to arrange a briefing for his Party or to send him very comprehensive correspondence. There is no way that I can be accused of not looking closely at the whole question of the Export Inspection Service because, quite frankly, I inherited the situation following the royal commission into the Australian Meat Industry. The previous Government set up the Export Inspection Service as a result of the problems that Government then had. The work done by the Export Inspection Service and by the Department of Primary Industry since that time has been outstanding and I will defend the work being done by that Department, and the Export Inspection Service, in here, outside or anywhere. We can now stand proudly in the world and guarantee the integrity of our product. We do meet the requirements of our customers in situations where we have to negotiate with very many parties.

SPEECH.PARA: Regarding the nonsense about there not being enough consultation, the previous spokesman for Primary Industry, the honourable member for Groom (Mr McVeigh), once said that there had been no consultation about a dairy inspection matter. I actually checked it out and to my surprise-I did not expect to get this figure-there had actually been 155 consultations with the dairy industry and various parties concerned with this very minor piece of legislation concerning inspection. It is absolute nonsense to say that there has been no consultation. We have formally established consultative bodies. I mention the Inspection Policy Council, which has industry representatives on it, the Efficiency Initiatives Consultative Group, which basically comprises the unions involved in this industry; the Meat Industry Advisory Council, comprising the processors and employers; the Fish Inspection Advisory Committee; the Veterinary Public Health Committee, which concerns the States; and individual industry groups chaired by my Department or by me. To say that there is no consultation is absolute nonsense.

I would have thought that the Opposition would have at least given credit where credit is due. The Export Inspection (Service Charge) Bill, which we are discussing cognately with two other export inspection Bills, is very important. It gives us flexibility, it gives us choice and it gives us agreement from the industry before anything happens. In other words, the opportunity is there for flexibility and choice such as the industry has never had before, and it totally agrees philosophically with the fee for service concept to which we are moving. This year we have contained costs. An amount of $10.8m has been absorbed and this gives us, on the best estimates we can make, a potential for $18m in savings. The honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt) has already commented on that matter and I will speak further on it in a moment.

We are making progress in attaining what was once a dream-a national inspection service. It is starting to come to fruition. Negotiations to facilitate the transfer to the Commonwealth of certain inspection functions in Tasmania are almost finalised. In the case of Victoria and the Northern Territory negotiations are well advanced and a date of effect of 1 January 1986, probably earlier in the case of the Northern Territory, is expected. We have strong indications that Western Australia also wishes to revise inspection arrangements involving the Commonwealth resulting in the abolition of the duplicate State charge. This has already been effected in Queensland. Meetings of the Australian Agricultural Council and other meetings I have had with State Ministers have shown that the States too have understood the magnificent progress we are making towards getting a national inspection service and addressing this fundamental question of costs in the industry. We are making enormous progress.

TALK.START.PARA: —At double the cost.

—That is absolute nonense. The honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) came in here in his usual lethal way throwing around charges and facts like confetti. He said that he did not want lessons in history. This is not so much a lesson in history as a lesson in fact. In 1979 the previous Government decided to recover half the cost of export inspection. It had a timetable for this which was set out-July 1979 for meat, wool and grain, July 1981 for fish and dried fruit and January 1983 for edible oils, eggs and dairy products. This has all been reinforced by statements made by the razor gang-the Committee of Review of Commonwealth Functions-on which the then Primary Industry Minister, Mr Nixon, was one of the prime personalities. That policy was reinforced by that committee. The previous Government arrived at a 50 per cent figure for recovery of the cost of export inspection for grains, wool and dried fruits by the time we took government-that is, in the January before the March 1983 election. The previous Government was clearly on that path.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not so much due to the previous Government's incompetence that it did not arrive at the 50 per cent, but the long harrowing process of discussion, negotiation and consultation which it had entered into. Those steps were already under way when we came to power. I did not transform the Department of Primary Industry into a maelstrom in order to get the 50 per cent charge; basically, it was already proceeding down that path. The object of the previous Government was very clearly to recover 50 per cent. It is true it did not raise the charging rates frequently, nor did it vary the volume of exports. This Government re-endorsed the previous Government's policy. The honourable member for Wannon said a few moments ago that there was a drought and that was why the previous Government did not move in that way. Why then did it move on grains and wool, two of the principal industries. Certainly it did not move on meat, but that was mainly because the costing exercise and the consultations had not progressed far enough. There was no other reason. It is really a nonsense to say that all this is due to us.

The other charge is that the decline in terms of trade is a reason for keeping inspection charges down. The Government's policy is to recover half the cost of inspection and it is also policy to keep the inspection charges as low as possible. We have cut out 20 per cent of what was then the 50 per cent inspection charge by removing some cost items out of the charging mechanism itself. At present an assistance measure of about $55m is provided by this Government to primary industries for whom we provide a ser- vice. Further assistance is considered on an industry by industry basis. For example, there has been money in this Budget going directly to the meat and fishing industries, two of the industries concerned with charges being applied to them.

The honourable member for Gwydir wanted to know the basis for the $18m savings mentioned in my second reading speech on the Export Inspection (Service Charge) Bill 1985. This cost reduction is based upon charges to the inspection system which were agreed to by the industry. I say again that the industry accepts the fee for service approach. Any further savings from this legislation will be in addition to the $18m and will arise from more efficient use of inspection time by the industry itself. The charge has been made also that inspection costs have nearly doubled since 1982-83. That is not correct. Costs for 1985-86 include domestic inspection taken over from the States and Territories. In real terms export inspection costs have been reduced.

I turn to the concept of the fee for service. The Meat Industry Advisory Committee, one of the committees which has a permanent consultative arrangement, is meeting again next Tuesday. I can give a commitment to the House that the new methods of charging will not be introduced until there has been full consultation and until the industry as a whole wants them. However, the industry as a whole has agreed to the philosophy of a fee for service; in fact, it has been pushing for it. The reports we have had reinforce this. This Coopers and Lybrand report, which put up a range of options, put this forward and it has been discussed, as have all the other analyses and papers which have been put forward by the Department. I heard some quotations from the honourable member for Gwydir of comments made by the outgoing Chairman of the Australian Meat Exporters Federal Council. This Council supported the new inspection proposals and the move towards self-regulation. The comments referred mainly to product description including particularly a new acronym OTD(E) which, I understand, stands for overseas trade descriptions (exports), and the fact that the industry itself should be responsible in this area. It is product description, more the commercials end and not the export inspection part of it.

My Department and the Government have supported this in principle but have pointed out that there needs to be caution in order to see that interests are protected. Some people in the industry believe that the industry can do nearly everything itself. If I look at the number of allegations before me at any time and the fact that two of the largest groups were fined very heavily recently because of breaches of the regulations which we enforce very rigorously, I do not believe that we have reached the stage yet where any responsible government can move to self-regulation without iron-clad assurances. In other words, we are not opposed to self-regulation to the extent that that can happen and we do not want to involve ourselves in commercial decisions, but we do want to ensure that we do not have problems that result from our trying to do the job on the cheap simply because some people have a philosophical leaning in the direction of self-regulation.

The honourable member for O'Connor indicated that the Government should return responsibility for inspection to the industry and that this has not occurred. That is wrong. Major moves have been made to hand back some responsibilities and where this has happened these have been fully supported by the industry. He and other Opposition members who have spoken have lost sight of the fact that overseas countries require full control by a federal government authority which must be independent. There is no sense in putting forward a philosophical position just because it accords with one's rhetoric in this country about the virtues of deregulation. We have to supply a service to an industry with export inspection and that service must be Australia-wide and run by the Commonwealth. There must be a Commonwealth export stamp. Our customers require that and they want such a service to be independent. That is the requirement of our principal customer, the United States Department of Agriculture. One of that Department's most prominent officials, Mr Gast, will be here within two weeks to look at what we are doing. The United States keeps a close scrutiny, not only on our works but on our administration and regulations. It is an absolute requirement to satisfy that market that we proceed in in the way we do. There is no point in saying that we can somehow get away with it, because we simply cannot do that. We cannot give all responsibility to the industry when our customers require that the function be performed centrally and officially by government.

The honourable member for O'Connor said that I had not done much about the Australian Federation of Islamic Councils. What we are concerned with here is God, money and politics and that is not a very easy matter to sort out to the satisfaction of everyone at all times. This Government, like its predecessor, does not make decisions on the religious requirements of our customers. I am not going to Saudi Arabia to tell them how to run Islam. The customers put requirements upon us and we have developed a consultative mechanism with AFIC so that we can look at the question of fees and practices. We have progressed a lot in that area as well. It is all right for the honourable member for O'Connor to accuse me of not being able to solve all the problems with AFIC; but largely that situation is now in a responsible setting. AFIC speaks freely with us, and we have an agreed path. What is more important, our customers know and understand our Halal procedures and they are totally satisified with them.

I opened my speech by referring to the nonsense spoken by the honourable member for Wannon. The comments made by the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow) and the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby) were spot on. The assertion that the cost of Commonwealth inspectors is higher than that of State inspectors is absolute nonsense. The honourable member for Wannon was saying that there could be a $9m saving if we inspected only at the rate at which the States did, such as in Victoria. It is pretty obvious that the honourable member has been wound up by the Country Meatworks Association in that State and the livestock agents, the saleyard people. I have seen them personally, and my officials have seen them goodness knows how many times. Although one can convince them face to face and convince them with letters, they will still run a political line. The fact of the matter is that the saving with the takeover of the Victorian inspection service will be $2.1m. There will be a saving of $0.9m with respect to the dual fee, and a saving of $1.2m with respect to staffing. There is no difference in the cost of inspection whether a man has `Commonwealth' or has `State' written on his white coat pocket. The requirement of our customers overseas is for export inspection and that it be performed by the Commonwealth, that there be a Commonwealth export stamp upon it.

Sure, State inspection costs less, by definition; but if a works has an export accreditation and the owner of the works says that he wants an export inspection service in, the beasts go through. It is his requirement. We have three kinds of industries in this meat industry, and on all occasions the Commonwealth Export Inspection Service is providing a service to them; so they require export inspection. What costs more is the presence of veterinary surgeons. One cannot identify which cut in a beast that goes through the chain is to be exported, so that is why one has export inspection applied to the lot. That is the very basic problem.

We also have the allegation of meat workers sitting down. We sometimes have a surfeit of inspectors. We sometimes have a near shortage. With the big kills in the late 1970s, of course, we often nearly ran into shortages. We must have people on tap to meet the requirements of the abattoirs and to provide that service. So one has people in Adelaide, and one suddenly has to put them into Tennant Creek or somewhere like that. Also, one needs people who are trained. We are exploring methods of getting as much flexibility as possible into our staffing arrangements. Once we get a national inspection service we shall have much more flexibility with respect to the managment of those people.

There were some final points raised in this very wide-ranging debate that went well past it. However, as regards Mudginberri-and I have never addressed the issues at Mudginberri because the Government has been at pains to try to resolve the dispute rather than to expand it-many lies have been printed in the newspapers about what has happened in the Northern Territory, particularly by the Australian of 10 August and 11 August. There was a statement there that the Katherine works would not open; but the fact of the matter is that broad agreement was reached with Mr Ibbotson in that plant, and availability of cattle was the problem. There was a statement that Tennant Creek was not opened. It actually opened on 8 May on conditions similar to those which apply in Queensland. There was another statement that the AMIEU had forced Northern Territory cattle to be slaughtered interstate. The fact is, of course, that two-thirds of the cattle in that Territory traditionally go outside it. Freight of $90 is paid and they are slaughtered under the tally system. The fact is that the processors reduce their prices to meet those of the contract abbattoirs. There was another statement to the effect that Point Stuart closed due to the actions of the AMIEU. That again was a nonsense. That plant had a debt of $2m 12 months before any AMIEU action. (Extension of time granted) My final point is that both Alice Springs and Souery's abattoirs in the Northern Territory went broke under the contract system. This is a very difficult issue, and what the Government has been saying all along is that we should focus on the tally system itself, because we have virtually three kinds of meat works in this country-those in the isolated areas, those in the country areas that are open two or three days a week, and those which have year round killing and which favour the tally system.
