DEBATE.TITLE: NORTHERN PRAWN FISHERY VOLUNTARY ADJUSTMENT SCHEME LOAN GUARANTEE BILL 1985[COGNATE BILLS:FOREIGN FISHING BOATS LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1985FISHERIES AGREEMENTS (PAYMENTS) AMENDMENT BILL 1985]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 22 August, on motion by Mr Kerin:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the House that this Bill has fairly narrow applications, and I ask honourable members to keep their remarks within those applications.

INTERJECT.PARA: I understand that it is the wish of the House to debate this Bill concurrently with the Foreign Fishing Boats Levy Amendment Bill and the Fisheries Agreements (Payments) Amendment Bill. If there is no objection the Chair will allow that course to be followed.

DEBATE.TITLE: NORTHERN PRAWN FISHERY VOLUNTARY ADJUSTMENT SCHEME LOAN GUARANTEE BILL 1985

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —As we shall be debating cognately the Northern Prawn Fishery Voluntary Adjustment Scheme Loan Guarantee Bill, the Foreign Fishing Boats Levy Amendment Bill, and the Fisheries Agreements (Payments) Amendment Bill, I shall deal with the Foreign Fishing Boats Levy Amendment Bill and the Fisheries Agreements (Payments) Amendment Bill initially. These Bills relate to methods by which licences are issued and payments received for foreign vessels operating within the 200-mile Australian territorial waters. The Northern Prawn Fishery Voluntary Adjustment Scheme Loan Guarantee Bill, to which I shall return shortly, outlays an initial loan of $5m to the fishery to assist with the process of rationalisation. The Opposition endorses the action taken in each of these Bills, does not seek any amendment to them and will give them speedy passage.

SPEECH.PARA: The foreign boats Bill simplifies the administrative processes needed to exempt a foreign fishing vessel from levy charges where such a vessel generates significant benefits for Australia. Most foreign vessels operating within Australian waters are subject to a licence levy unless the Minister considers that the foreign operators are providing substantial benefits to Australia. In 1984-85 Australia received some $3m in foreign licence fees. Fifty-two pairs of Taiwanese trawlers and 30 Taiwanese gill netters contributed $1.6m, while another 270 Japanese tuna long-liners paid access fees just short of $1m. Eight Korean squid boats paid $388,000 while 7 Taiwanese gill netters operating under a joint venture were levied $8,000. Recently permission has been given for additional Thai trawlers and gill netters to operate in joint ventures off the Northern Territory.

The foreign boats Bill amends the Foreign Fishing Boats Levy Act 1981 which complements the Fisheries Act 1952. Amendments to clause 4 of the 1981 Act will cut across some of the complexities and delays in settling formal agreements and will simplify processes of levy exemption. Amendments to clauses 5 and 6 of the Act close a legal loophole in the payment of foreign levies. A licence to fish within a specified zone may carry a total access fee which is divided between the agreed number of vessels. At present, if fewer than the agreed number apply for a licence a portion of the access fee would remain unauthorised. The Bill gives necessary statutory authority to collect the full amount of lump sum access payments.

The Fisheries Agreements (Payments) Amendment Bill complements these amendments by extending the power to refuse licenses to cover fisheries agreements between Australia and one or more parties which are not foreign governments. The Opposition has discussed these changes with a number of industry leaders, and I hold no objection to what are common-sense changes serving the interests not only of the fisheries but also of the wider Australian community. There is, however, a need for some revision of the purpose to which the $3m foreign levies will be channelled. The levy Act of 1981 followed declaration of the 200-mile zone on 1 November 1979, creating Australian waters almost equal in size to the continent's land mass. Access rights have been granted to foreign vessels in waters under-exploited by Australians or in waters unlikely to be used in the foreseeable future.

Levy payments by foreign operators will continue to rise beyond the $3m mark this year, so the Government has become the recipient of a considerable pool of levy funds which are not earmarked for any specific industry purpose, which I think is a great pity. I know it is not consistent with the view of Treasury that funds, levy collections or whatever should be hypothecated for a special purpose. The first time that hypothecation rule was broken was in respect of the Australian bicentennial road program. I well remember the great fight that occurred at the time, because it has been consistent policy of the Treasury not to allow hypothecation of any description. I give the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) some credit for having been able to follow up the bicentennial road program with his land transport program and hypothecating further fuel excise for road construction.

Notwithstanding the hard held views of Treasury, I think there is a very strong argument in favour of using funds that are collected from an industry for a specific purpose. The user pays principle is sound provided the user who is paying actually has those funds allocated to a trust fund to be used for that specific purpose. I do not know whether the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) agrees with my view. He may not, but I do think there is some justice in debating and arguing with the Treasury on these issues. I believe the funds should be expended to the benefit of the fishing industry and the Minister should give close consideration to the ways and means of expending this $3m to improve the industry. For example, several major fisheries are undergoing adjustment measures and an additional injection of a grant or low interest or interest-free loans would markedly assist this rationalisation. Commendably, the Government has reinforced a $5m loan to the northern prawn fishery with a $3m grant for adjustment purposes. The expenditure of foreign licence fees could help to accelerate the adjustment process, giving those who wish to leave the industry a chance to do so, and hasten the onset of accelerating the return of profitability to the fisheries.

These industries are facing intense cost price pressures. Fuel accounts for up to 40 per cent of the total costs, and prices have risen by 10c a litre or more this year alone. This figure includes the Budget decision to restore the 100 per cent off-road diesel excise rebate. In at least one case northern operators are importing fuel from Singapore rather than paying the exorbitant increases on Australian supplies, and I do not blame them either. The high costs of northern prawn and southern blue fin tuna operators have been further increased in this year's Budget by management fees of about $250,000 in each case. The Government claims justification on the basis of a partial cost recovery of the new management plans, but the goal of those plans is to expand industry profitability, not to exacerbate the cost price squeeze. The impact of these new charges could be offset if the industry were given the benefit of foreign licence revenue. It would be helpful if the Minister asked the Department of Primary Industry and the new National Fishing Industry Council to examine and report on the possible uses of the foreign licence revenue.

In such a review the opportunity may be taken to assess current rules applying to the issue of licences for Australian vessels. The Australian motorist needs only one licence to drive in any State; yet the typical fishing vessel must have one Commonwelath and three State licences for the boat, one Commonwealth and three State licences for the ruddy skipper and, with a crew of ten, three licences for each. Really and truly, it is becoming a debacle. Small business today is struggling under all sorts of regulations and licensing. I know that the Premier of New South Wales has given an undertaking to try to reduce the regulations, to reduce licensing. I do not know that progress has been made at all. I spoke to a small businessman the other day who had no fewer than 20 licences to operate a buisness with a turnover of no more than $100,000. Really and truly, I think the time has come to get off the backs of people. Fancy a fishing vessel having to have one Commonwealth and three State licences and one Commonwealth and three State licences for the skipper. What is so marvellous about a skipper? Fancy having to have three licences for each crew member if there are 10 members. How many have they got to have for the cook? It is ridiculous. Some 40 licences are required just to put a vessel to sea. We have really gone licence mad. We are taking licence with common sense by doing this.

For a 25-metre vessel in the northern prawn fishery, with a crew of six and an average turnover of two crews a year, the cost will be $4,269 this year in licence fees. It is ridiculous, is it not? I think most of us in this place can see the foolhardiness of it all. It appears the red tape is running out of control. The cost of collecting so may fees could even outweigh the revenue obtained. I am not being party political on this matter because these ruddy licences must have been there when we were in government. It is about time that we started to knock this red tape out of the system altogether because it is binding up the whole system. It is turning Australia into a constipated country.The industry would be receptive to the issuing of far fewer licences. With reduced revenue, the Federal and State governments would still enjoy some net benefit from a reduction in the costs of issuing and maintaining so many licences. All we are doing is keeping stamp lickers and so on in jobs. It is ridiculous.

The Northern Prawn Fishery Bill before the House formalises the provision of an initial $5m adjustment loan, a measure which has been sought for more than two years. The industry has proposed this self-adjustment scheme, outlaying compensation to those who wish to terminate their involvement to be repaid with interest to the Government through an annual levy on the remaining operators starting in the 1986 licensing year. The fishery is aiming to rationalise its existing fleet of 250 with an annual catch of 10,000 tonnes to fewer than 200 vessels. The Chairman of the Northern Fishing Companies Association, Mr France, said in part:
By making diesel excise fully rebateable for eligible primary producers, including fishermen, the Government has merely righted a `wrong' that it instituted in the 1983 Budget.
Mr France said the saving of $2m a year to the northern prawn fishery would go:

. . . some way towards redressing the increase of $4.2 million northern prawners had to bear this year as a result of the removal of fuel freight differentials for safe anchorages and increases in diesel price flowing from the Government's world parity pricing policy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not sure whether the previous Government cared for Australian fisheries or for the men and women who have worked so hard in the industry to develop an increasing Australian involvement in Australian fish resources. Fishermen throughout Australia will now be able to plan efficiently how they will invest and concentrate on resources that are available. As a seventeenth century writer said in a book called the Compleat Angler: `Fishing is like maths: it can never be fully learnt'. In Eden-Monaro, where Australia's largest trawl fishery fleet is based, the industry's problems were pronounced. In fact, he insisted on it, and it is in line with his belief that industry must be involved in rural policy decision-making. With encouragement from the Minister, who, I understand, has been named fisherman of the year, the struggling, disorganised trawl industry in Eden-Monaro and elsewhere now has a strong and viable body-the South Eastern Trawl Owners Association. People such as Laurie Walkear, Joe Greco, Jock Petrie and Peter Bell, and many others, throughout Australia, have brought their industry together to present a united voice to Government. Officers of the Department have given valuable assistance to the association in the past year.

One of the most remarkable achievements has been the development of a revolutionary marketing system for the fishing industry. Through the use of Telecom Australia's Viatel system, the association will provide an alternative marketing system which will expand the market for Australian caught fish. It will enable Australian caught fish of improved quality to be supplied to Australian consumers and will thus reduce import requirements. It will ensure fresh fish supply to a decentralised market and will thereby provide the possibility for improved prices for fishermen. The Viatel marketing system will lead to a reduction in the costs of handling and marketing of all fish products and it will be controlled and supervised by the executive committee of the Trawl Owners Association, which has its origins in Eden-Monaro and arose out of the fishing industry's frustration with past fisheries policies and an improved receptiveness on the part of this Government to fishing problems. The Association was given a grant of $110,000 from the Fishing Industry Research Trust Account to develop the Viatel marketing system for Australian fish products. This was a recognition by the Government of the need for the industry to expand its marketing possibilities, to decentralise purchasing points to ensure fresher supplies of fish to home consumers and restaurants throughout the country.

The Bills before the House provide for a proper statutory authority for collecting the full amount of fees specified in any agreement between the Commonwealth and a foreign interest for access to the Australian fishing zone. the Bills also aim to make the administrative processes simpler, exempting from a levy imposed on foreign boats in the Australian fishing zone, 200 nautical miles to sea, foreign vessels which bring benefits to Australia. They will also extend the Minister's power to refuse licences to foreign boats due to the non-payment of agreed fees to cover fisheries agreements between Australia and one or more non-government foreign interests.

The Government has committed itself to protecting the welfare of the Australian fishing industry and the granting of licences to foreign vessels will be considered only in this context. It has also committed itself to constant review of foreign involvement in particular fisheries where Australians express an interest in participating. The Australian Government has an obligation under the Convention on the Law of the Sea to allocate surplus fish resources to foreigners, but it also has a greater obligation to the Australian fishing industry. I am pleased that the Government is going to find out who has what boat where and is going to know not roughly, as in the past, but exactly what foreign boats are doing in our waters. This Government will make sure that action is taken to control the level of exploitation so as not to prejudice the future entry of Australians into fisheries in which they presently do not participate.

There are about 9,000 commercial fishing vessels in Australia with a capital investment of approximately $500m and about 160 registered land-based processing plants, of which 70 per cent are located in rural areas. The benefit to local and national economies is enormous in terms of revenue and job creation. It is estimated that the fishing industry gives employment to some 18,000 fishermen with a further 5,000 jobs in processing and wholesaling. The industry also returns almost $500m to the country in exports. Its importance to Australia in terms of both local and export benefits is substantial. The Government has shown that it is well aware of this importance and of the need for rectifying years of neglect and has, accordingly, undertaken significant and long overdue reforms in the fishing industry. I thank the Minister on behalf of an electorate with a comparatively high fishing component and I commend the Bills to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Northern Prawn Fishery Voluntary Adjustment Scheme Loan Guarantee Bill, the Foreign Fishing Boats Levy Amendment Bill and the Fisheries Agreements (Payments) Amendment Bill, which were very ably debated by the Deputy Leader of the National Party, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt), earlier this morning. SPEECH.PARA: I can recall very clearly many debates in this House concerning the problems facing the fishing industry. A decade back the situation was really chaotic. The previous Government, particularly the then Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Nixon, did a singularly important service for the fishing industry and the individual fishermen in this country in bringing together the participants in fishing around the Australian coastline. I refer in particular to the negotiations with the Japanese and the difficulties that were encountered in those days. One has only to have a sparse knowledge of the industry to understand its complexities. I represent an area which has a very substantial fishing industry and which is, in part, involved in the northern fishing area as well as the fishing area immediately off the east coast of Australia. It was the practice for those within the industry to travel north to participate in the fishing and prawning season. They did so because of the overall economic necessity of achieving an effective catch which would give them some viability in through-put and some return on their investments in boats, equipment and labour to operate the vessels. Over the last decade, and perhaps the decade before, the endeavour to succeed has been a challenge and a mission in life to men of the sea involved in fishing.

I can recall the problems in my very early days as a parliamentarian with the establishment of an efficient fishing industry. There were no proper on-shore facilities; there were poor boats; there was a sparsity of effective equipment and there was a very difficult situation for effective marketing. The co-operatives established in New South Wales contributed very largely to the ultimate creation of a viable industry. This was followed by effective work in Queensland and right around the northern areas which finally became part of a really Australia-wide link in fishing. The southern areas and across to the west had a different situation. Tasmania also had a different situation. Today we are dealing with the east coast and the north of this continent, in terms of the legislation before us.

I particularly emphasise that the legislation before the House is part of an ongoing and important part of the progress to bring about efficiency and to aid the viability of those who participate in fishing. I applaud the Government for belatedly-the announcement was made in the 1984 Budget-providing $5m by way of loan, with a subsequent decision to provide a $3m grant, to assist in what can be, I suppose, properly described as the reconstruction of the fishing industry. On this occasion I believe the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) has taken an effective approach. It is certainly in contrast to the approach that we experienced a few weeks ago with the dairy industry and in contrast to his approach currently with the sugar industry. Assistance is being given, and in a meaningful way. It is to be applauded. The success of assisting the industry in the next year or two will depend on the ingenuity of both those within the industry and those who administer the departmental aspects of this legislation. I am particularly concerned that the Federal Government will use State governments as agencies to administer the legislation and implement the amendments.

I want to refer, in a very simple way, to the experience of a fisherman in my electorate. This fisherman operated a trawler on the Richmond River and had a three-mile limit on his fishing rights because he was registered only under State regulations. Having improved his boat and having found that he needed to do more to make his business viable, he applied for a Federal licence. He had to do so through the New South Wales State Department. He sent off his correspondence and the cheque required as the application fee. He had no reply. He then visited the Department to try to ascertain what was happening in the matter. He was told that his application had not been received. It was then too late. There was no way his application could be considered because the deadline had passed. He had a very uncomfortable few days before contacting me, as the Federal member, and my State colleague to seek some assistance. We then discovered that his application was in existence. We discovered that his cheque had been negotiated by the Department. He was told that he would have to fill in another form and that the matter would then be considered.

At this point I am not able to ascertain the real outcome of the matter. I mention the experience simply because it is not good enough for State agencies to be used if they are not going to be efficient and effective in the administration of Federal law and decisions in matters so important to the individual fisherman. I appeal to the Minister for Primary Industry to have a good look at the aspect of administration that will be required to implement the legislation with which we are now dealing.

Certainly, assistance is being given to fishermen who will operate in northern waters by way of the $3m grant. However, I hope that the committee of inquiry, which was appointed not so long ago and about which there has been a deathly silence in the last couple of months, will soon respond to its responsibilities as indicated by the Minister and that we will have some precise advice as to what is really to be the outcome of the matter of the crippling cost of fuel for the fishing industry.

We now have assistance for those in northern areas by way of a $3m subvention. We have some concessions in the Budget which are to apply from a later date. The whole thing needs to be tied together to create some reasoned relationship between costs in the various locations in which the fishing industry has to operate around the Australian coastline, a coastline which, I suppose, compared with most countries, is one of the most difficult because there are limited onshore facilities. Trawlers have to travel long distances to reach ports where they can operate and processing locations which, in may instances, are a very great distance from the fishing grounds. So fuel costs have become the greatest burden for this industry. If we are to see an effective result from this legislation there has to be a practical approach to how assistance will be directed to individual fishermen.

This industry is important to very many of the coastal areas of Australia which have no other potential. We cannot replace it with some alternative. There is a demand for jobs and for the continuation of existing businesses to retain viability at many of the locations of processing plants. This demand needs to be met. The co-operation of this Government is needed to ensure that in the difficult period that still lies ahead for the industry there will be complete recognition of the importance of the individual fisherman and his contribution to this industry and to Australia.

The report of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial Systems rotted on the shelf and it took the courage and foresight of this Government to make the financial system be again what it once was.

ANSWER.PARA: As I remember, the interest rate that applied on Bankcard was 1 1/2 per cent a month or 18 per cent a year for the credit extended to its patrons. Some people use credit extensively; others use it for a very short period. I understand that the rate was set in 1974, and it remained at that rate until the ceiling was lifted by this Government.

The fact of the matter is that interest rates, high as they are, have not slowed down the real economy. In fact, the real economy now is running so strongly that in the June quarter the real growth is at a rate of about 8 per cent on one measure of the national accounts and as high as 12 per cent on an annualised basis. Hence the market has been prepared to pay interest rates of this kind. They are not paying them, as they were in the Leader of the Opposition's time as Treasurer, to stay alive, to hang on and keep their businesses solvent; they are paying them now by choice, to invest and to spend. That choice has not slowed down economic growth or consumption but of course money is rationed in the market by interest rates. In case all the phoney dries opposite need a lesson in basic economics, I remind them that it is rationed in the market-place by price. If the current Bankcard interest rate slows down the expansion of credit in the personal finance area and in so doing slows the rate of growth in the economy to a level which contains inflation, wages and prices, I will be very happy indeed with that outcome.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Health aware that today the Public Accounts Committee tabled its report on fraud and overservicing in the pathology industry? While congratulating the Minister for Health on the transfer of the fraud and overservicing detection function to the Health Insurance Commission, I ask whether the report drew the attention of the Parliament to the concentration of ownership and entrepreneurial activity in the private pathology industry and problems associated with the approved pathology practitioner scheme. Will the Minister for Health inform the House of current and proposed action by his Department in these areas?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the quite excellent report brought down by the PublicAccounts Committee in relation to the pathology industry and I appreciate that once more this Committee has made an effective contribution to the scrutiny of public moneys in this country. I also welcome the Committee's acknowledgement that it is because of the existence of the Medicare system that the most thorough statistical analysis of any particular branch of the medical profession in relation to these matters has been possible. I am also grateful that the Committee acknowledges that the transfer of the fraud and surveillance detection function to the Health Insurance Commission has greatly improved our ability to deal instantly with the issues of fraud and overservicing. As to what the Government is doing in this area, as honourable members will be aware the Layton Medicare Benefits Review Committee was given as its first and major task the examination of the pathology schedules and therefore many of the issues dealt with in the Public Accounts Committee report are being dealt with by that Committee. Also, in co-operation with the State governments, we have sought to pursue the accreditation of pathology laboratories in the various States. Considerable progress has been made in that area and I am sure that this report will provide further stimulus to State and Commonwealth activity in this area.

ANSWER.PARA: The most important point of all about the report is that it is a very serious indictment of the pathology industry in this country. It refers to elements of corruption within that industry and confirms what this Government has been saying ever since it came to office, and that is the need for much more effective regulation of the diagnostic industries in this country. It was the Opposition, in alliance with many members of the medical profession and led by the honorable member for Mackellar, who fought all the way and refused to accept any efforts to introduce much more effective controls in these areas of diagnostic services. I hope that when all members of this Parliament have read this report and have noted the serious concerns it raises we together, at last, with the medical profession will be able to embark upon a major restructuring of the pathology industry to prevent the exploitation of ordinary citizens by many of the activities identified in the report.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Treasurer accept the assessment of many economic commentators that excessive money supply growth resulting from the Government's attempts to hold down interest rates before the last election is now creating significant upward pressure on interest rates? In other words, are we now paying the price for the Government's irresponsible monetary policies in its push to last year's early election.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Government has always believed in having an appropriate monetary policy. Not only have we relied upon a decent fiscal policy, an incomes policy which keeps wage restraint and prices in check, but we have also backed that up with a decent, consistent and firm monetary policy. In fact, after the Government's massive deregulation of the Australian financial system, we saw a change in the relationship between the monetary aggregates and activity, much the same as we saw in Britain and the United States. The traditional relationship, between say, M3 and economic activity changed, and it was very hard to decipher the change and to take readings from it. We have not gone through the pretence that many countries have gone through of moving off M3 to M2 then, finding that that does not work, broadening the range and moving to M1, and abandoning that and broadening some other range. We have dismissed that pretence-which I might say has been raised to the level of a performing art in the United States and the United Kingdom-and sought to operate a firm monetary policy at all times, keeping an eye not only on growth in monetary aggregates, bank lending activity and exchange rates but also on the measure and indicator of balance in the market, interest rates. That has always been our view.

ANSWER.PARA: Well before the end of the 1984-85 deregulation was already having a very large impact upon monetary aggregates. We said quite clearly that we would fully finance the deficit and run a monetary policy which was appropriately firm. We have continued to do that and the interest rate outcomes have been a consequence of that policy. The Opposition also said that we tightened policy in the face of volatility in the exchange market, but the outcomes in financial markets we are seeing today and the attendent interest rates are an indicator of balance in themarket. I presume the implication of the question is that the honourable member for Mackellar now believes that the Government has a firm monetary policy. That is what he seems to be saying, although it is not what his Leader was saying a week or two ago. Honourable members on the other side of the House should get their story straight. I believe that we have a firm monetary policy, and at no time did the Government seek to slacken the monetary policy for interest rate outcomes. We had bond tenders in the election campaign.

TALK.START.PARA: —You heavied the Governor.

—We did not heavy the Governor. Take an interest and read the annual report of the Reserve Bank of Australia. It is all in there. The honourable member should have a little read, a little study, and if he can keep a clear eye he will find that it is there. In a story in yesterday's Australian Financial Review there is this quotation from the United States Federal Reserve. It said this:

ANSWER.PARA: Financial innovation and deregulation have apparently so distorted the relationship between money and economic activity that money is no longer a reliable guide to the economy's course.
I would have been pleased to have written that myself.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations aware of a number of reports suggesting that the countries which have led the world in economic and employment growth in recent years have been those with flexible labour markets? Is this correct? Can the Minister inform the House whether policies to deregulate the labour market are likely to be widely accepted in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of reports of a speech made by the then Deputy Leader of the Opposition to the National Press Club on 28 August this year in relation to the Budget in which he made various statements about labour market deregulation. In particular he said:

ANSWER.PARA: There is abundant evidence that those countries which have led the world in economic growth and employment creation in recent years have had flexible labour markets. The United States is the prime example.

He said that in the context of pointing out that the first priority of an incoming coalition government would be to deregulate labour markets. The fact is that the statement by the then Deputy Leader of the Opposition and now Leader of the Opposition is absolutely and utterly untrue. If we look at what has happened to employment growth in Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries recently we find that the country which has led the world in employment growth in the most recent year for which we can obtain statistics, that is the year to March 1985, is this country. We have had growth of employment over that period of 3.3 per cent, which compares with 2.9 per cent in the United States, the prime example of the Leader of the Opposition. Our rate of growth of employment is double the OECD average. In those circumstances, it is obviously clear that the statement by the Leader of the Opposition which was made to the National Press Club a couple of weeks ago is totally untrue. It follows from that that we do not need to deregulate the labour market in this country in order to generate substantial employment growth. We have achieved record growth in employment in this country pursuing policies based on the prices and incomes accord and with the maintenance of a regulated labour market, which we believe to be most appropriate to an overall optimum employment outcome.

In relation to the second part of the honourable member's question about community attitudes, I believe that the community at large would not appreciate the application of deregulatory policies to the labour market. The trade union movement is obviously totally opposed to it, but so too are the employers-

TALK.START.PARA: —We can knock off now; that is it.

—Not at all. I am saying that both sides of the labour market-the trade unions and the employers-are totally opposed to it. Recently the Director-General of the Confederation of Australian Industry said in a speech on the report of the Hancock Committee of Review into Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems:

ANSWER.PARA: Australian employers do not, in our view, wish to take a leap in the dark with some nebulous new form of industrial relations system. The vast majority of employers in Australia support the continuing role of the industrial tribunals in mediating industrial disputes and determining wages and conditions. I have no doubt that any government that attempted to reduce to any significant extent the role of the tribunals would run into immense community opposition.

So said the leading spokesman for employers in this country on industrial relations matters. It follows from that that it is absolutely clear that both parties involved in industrial relations matters, the trade unions and the employers, do not want deregulation of the labour market. It would most certainly lead to widespread industrial upheaval, the community at large would not want it and the best thing that can be said about that policy is that the Opposition will never be in a position to implement it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was the Minister for Aviation involved in or responsible for co-ordinating arrangements for the transport industry mission led by Sir Peter Abeles to the People's Republic of China in June? Did the Minister try to have representatives of all the major Australian transport companies, such as Trans Australia Airlines, Qantas, Brambles and Mayne Nickless included in the delegation, along with Ansett-Thomas Nationwide Transport? If so, why were they not included in the mission?

—I have seen some of the allegations and criticisms made in respect of that delegation. Let me say that they are unfounded. The agreement with the Chinese was that there was to be an official party attached to the prearranged Ansett-TNT delegation with the sole purpose of establishing a mechanism for further official and industry communication and co-operation. It is recognised that that purpose was achieved. This Government will not be deterred in its efforts to build a better trading relationship with China. —Has the Minister for Foreign Affairs noted action against South Africa which was announced on 9 September by President Reagan? Has he noted that President Reagan foreshadowed the withdrawal of United States Government export credits to American companies that do not adopt non-discriminatory employment policies in South Africa? Can the Minister inform the House about progress on the Australian Government's proposal for a business code of conduct covering Australian companies operating in South Africa? In particular, will the Government consider a similar attitude in relation to facilities available through the export market development grants scheme, the Export Finance and Insurance Corporation, the tourism overseas promotion scheme and the Australian Overseas Projects Corporation for Australian companies that fail to adopt non-discriminatory employment practices in South Africa?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the past 48 hours the United States Administration and the European Commission respectively have announced a range of sanctions against the South African Government. Those sanctions follow sanctions announced earlier by a number of other countries, including Australia. In all cases the motive is similar; that is, not to bring South Africa to its knees, but to bring it to its senses and to make it aware of the obnoxious nature of the apartheid administration in South Africa and the conduct of the Government in that country in respect of black people at the moment. What it proves is that although Australia is among those countries at the leading edge in initiating such action, it nonetheless shares a common concern with most, if not all, the countries of the Western association of nations. The United States has announced a series of sanctions affecting bank loans, computer sales, export licences on nuclear goods and technology, import of military equipment, sale of Kruger rands, positive assistance to black South Africans and, of course, inducements-if one can put it that way-to have American companies adhere to the Sullivan Code of Conduct in respect of their practices in South Africa.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Government has outlined a voluntary code of conduct-and I stress voluntary, because we do not and should not claim to have extra-territorial legislative authority in such matters-for Australian businesses functioning in South Africa. Preliminary discussions have taken place between my Department and on other occasions my department and me, and the Confederation of Australian Industry, the Business Council of Australia and the Australian Council of Trade Unions. I hope to be able to chair a meeting of all three bodies and Government representatives towards the end of next week and it is my aim to conclude an agreement in respect of the code of conduct. The Australian Government has certainly reviewed those commercial incentives for the external sector which the honourable member mentioned with a view to moving on those incentives in any area appropriate. My belief is that the sense of responsibility of Australian business and its abhorrence, shared generally by all Australians, of what is going on in South Africa, will be such that we will receive co-operation in the introduction of this code.

I have only two final points to make on this matter. I think it is salutary to recall the words of the President of the USA, President Reagan, in his statement outlining his formal documentation implementing the sanctions announced by the US Administration. He said this:

I, Ronald Reagan, President of the USA, find the policies and actions of the Govt of South Africa constitute an unusual and extraordinary threat to the foreign policy and economy of the US and hereby declare a national emergency to deal with that threat.

The President of the US found the situation in South Africa so totally unacceptable, so thoroughly abhorrent, that he declared a national emergency, and the critical point that he made in declaring it was that the situation in South Africa constituted an ``unusual and extraordinary threat to the foreign policy and economy of the US''.

My final point is simply this. Hitherto there has always been bipartisan support on this matter, dating from the early 1970s. It was implemented by the then Prime Minister, Whitlam. It was upheld with considerable force of character by his successor, Mr Fraser, whose work in southern Africa was humanitarian in its inspiration and positive in its implementation. It was maintained by the previous Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Kooyong. I ask a simple question of the current Leader of the Opposition, and it is this: Can we now expect a continuation of that bipartisan support for this sort of policy? Can we expect it in the light of the fact that not just moderately radical governments of the world, such as this one, have implemented sanctions but that conservative administrations, such as that of the US, have expressed their abhorrence in no unambiguous way at all. I ask the Leader of the Opposition to declare, simply and forthrightly, whether we can look forward to the continued bipartisan support of the policy in respect of South Africa which this country has upheld for more than a decade.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Treasurer. I refer him to the growing public debate about the size of Australia's overseas debt. As a constructive and practical response, will the Government consider eliminating or substantially scaling down present restrictions on foreign investment into Australia, thus facilitating a switch in the future away from borrowing abroad to more equity investment from abroad as a method of financing projects?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no doubt that the pattern of investment has changed over the last decade to one with a high degree of financing as distinct from equity, and no doubt the foreign investment policy has played a part in that. I think it is also fair to say, though, that in the bipartisanship which has existed between the parties in respect of foreign investment policy, the foreign investment policy has made Australian companies very much stronger and has made many world class institutions. The deals that they were shoe-horned into by the foreign investment policy at times when foreign investors were prepared to pay a premium for access to this country have been an important building block in the industrial development of Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: That said, there is still obviously a place for Australia's foreign investment policy, but in the last couple of years we have sought, particularly in the languid state of the economy as the Government inherited it, to lift investment and, provided that the proposals comply with the national interest provisions and the opportunities test, we have generally agreed to them, with some view to the balance between equity and debt. The Leader of the Opposition makes a point which is, I think, perhaps not generally understood by commentators. The great rise in Australia's external indebtedness is one principally flowing from private sector investment. Commonwealth external debt is more than accommodated by Commonwealth reserves on official account and, whilst it is true that the debts of the Commonwealth and the State sector between them are not covered by Commonwealth reserves, the fact is that much of the State debt of the last five or six years was debt borrowed for productive investment for power stations, coal loaders, rail electrification, basic public infrastructure and so on, with, of course, a high degree of commercial application. The great bulk of the debt has been private, based on well founded projects and well founded investments and a lot of it has been related to the energy phase in the oil import replacement program by Japan, which gave us a window of opportunity into the world coal market.

It is true that after the development of those projects, whilst export volumes have been okay from projects, Australian prices have been poor; so the earnings from the debt have not been as fast or as large as we might otherwise have believed, and therefore our external indebtedness position was exacerbated in that respect. Also, because the country was so dreadfully uncompetitive in 1983, when the Government put demand in the economy, when this Government's policies induced demand into the economy, that demand quickly spilled over into imports, and we had a flood of imports which responded to that and which worsened the position of our current account. But in respect of indebtedness, the depreciation brought about by the float of the Australian dollar gives Australia the opportunity to turn our trading account around and to turn around the pattern of our indebtedness.

It needs to be understood that the first and perhaps perverse effect of the depreciation of the exchange rate is to revalue the Australian dollar denomination of overseas debt, which in the first place makes the debt position look worse but, in fact, the depreciation goes along its way to then repair the problem. This Government has made the appropriate policy adjustments to keep competitive and to get the inflation rate tracking back to 5 per cent to 5 1/2 per cent as a result of the agreement that we made with the Australian Council of Trade Unions. By the decent fiscal policy that the Government has in place our competitiveness will allow Australia to improve its export performance, to deal with its current account and, hopefully, to improve the competitive position of our industries to repair their indebtedness.

Whilst it is always an issue in economic management and one which must be examined, I think that some of the extravagant language imputed to our debt position is unwarranted. This is not a question of sovereign debt of the South American variety. It is mostly private debt, well founded. But, over time, I think that the point made by the Leader of the Opposition is sound and that there will be a change in the pattern of investment in respect of equity as distinct from debt, the opposite of which has been the case through the late 1970s and early 1980s.

To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. We are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian national flag;
2. We are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
The Union Jack-itself the creation of 3 Christian crosses-represents the nation's historical origin, and the source of its language and law.
The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its place in space.
The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. We know the flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. We recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. We are certain that any change to the flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your honourable house will: Propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian national flag remains sacrosanct from change''.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Blunt,Mr Rocher and Mr Tuckey.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Private Health Insurance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives. Humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully sayeth:
That we the undersigned are totally opposed to any taxation change which involves a tax on Health Fund contributions or benefits.

That we are already required to pay a 1 percent levy to partly finance the Medicare scheme and that we would regard any further taxation of our health insurance arrangements as unfair and unreasonable.
That therefore we urge the Government to ensure that there is no taxation on illness and no special taxation on those who seek to insure themselves against the cost of private health care.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cross,Mr Hayden and Mr Webster.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will:
Propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian National Flag be changed only with the approval of the Nation as expressed in a Referendum''.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beale and Mr Hawker.

PETITION.TITLE: Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of we, the undersigned citizens of Australia, respectfully showeth: That the government reverse its decision to cut pre-school funding in the mini-budget.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Bilney and Mr Hurford.

PETITION.TITLE: Pornography
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

We hail as a victory for the not-so-silent majority the decision of the Federal Government to now conduct an inquiry into the effects of hard-core pornography and violence upon people and especially children.
We view with grave concern and deplore the decision of the Hawke Government to allow the sale of this objectionable material to continue and become more widespread during the period of the inquiry.
Request the Federal Government to immediately re-enact the previous laws which banned the entry into Australia and the sale of hard-core pornography and violence in video and publication form.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Blunt and Mr Tim Fischer.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that they are opposed to the proposals contained in the Government's White Paper for the reform of the Australian Tax System in so far as they relate to the imposition of further Capital Gains and Wealth Taxes.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled will call upon the Government to reject any proposal to increase the burden of Capital Gains and Wealth Taxes on the Australian people.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Blunt and Mr Grace.

PETITION.TITLE: International Year for Repairing the Earth
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out:

That, for our survival, an effective Worldpeace Initiative needs to be established which will work towards mutual understanding, world disarmament, economic well-being for all, fulfilling employment, a sustainable society conserving natural resources and revitalising soils essential for growing a plentiful and healthy food supply and tree cover. By achieving these objectives, Australia can set an example for the rest of the world to follow.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will:
1. Create an Australian Ministry for Peace specifically devoted to peace-building and the non-violent resolution of conflict;
2. Convene a national Summit for Survival to discuss the issues of world disarmament, security and national and international co-operation;
3. Support the United Nations World Disarmament Campaign by allocating the equivalent of at least 10% of our military expenditure to fund peace activities;
4. Actively assist the International Year of Peace in 1986 by initiating programs for peace education, self help development and environmental repair;
5. Develop National Employment Programs to give priority to the planting and growing of forests, food producing trees and other crops to assist the greening of Australia.

6. Implement National Recycling Programs to reuse water and to compost all presently wasted domestic sewage-sludge and organic garbage with mineral rich gravel dust, a by-product from rock quarries and mines, into hygienic humus, a natural fertiliser, for use in revitalising impoverished soils.
7. Propose to the United Nations General Assembly that 1989 be declared International Year for Repairing the Earth.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Blunt and Mr Hand.

PETITION.TITLE: International Year for Repairing the Earth
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out:

That, for our survival, an effective Worldpeace Initiative needs to be established which will work towards mutual understanding, world disarmament, economic well-being for all and full employment. This Initiative will help to ensure a sustainable society conserving natural resources, and revitalising soils essential for growing a plentiful and healthy food supply and tree cover. By achieving these objectives, Australia can set an example for the rest of the world to follow.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will:
1. Propose to the United Nations General Assembly that 1989 be declared International Year for Repairing the Earth.
2. Implement Action Programs Leading up to 1989 which will include:
A. Actively supporting the International Year of Peace in 1986 by reallocating at least 10% of our military expenditure to fund environmental repair programs.

B. Implementing National Recycling Programs to reuse water, and to compost into hygienic humus all presently wasted organic garbage and sewage-sludge mixed with fine ground powder from mineral-rich gravels and rocks, to use as a natural fertiliser in revitalising impoverished soils;

C. Developing National Employment Programs to give priority to irrigation systems and the planting and growing of healthy forests, food producing trees and other crops and vegetation to assist the greening of Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
