PETITION.TITLE: Funding of State Arts Councils
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the current policies of the Community Arts Board of the Australia Council are disadvantaging rural residents with regard to access to the Arts.

Your petitioners, therefore, humbly pray that the Federal Government will allocate sufficient funds to the Australia Council specifically to ensure ongoing funding to State Arts Councils to enable those organisations to maintain access to performing and other arts activities in country areas.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Braithwaite and Mr Ian Cameron.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament Assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

The proposed service tax on all accommodation provided by hotels and the proposals to disallow legitimate entertainment expenses as a deduction for taxation purposes will lead to a dramatic fall-off in tourism, business travel and will have a deleterious effect on restaurant patronage. This will threaten present employment and extensively curtail job opportunities in the Industry.
Measures as proposed will seriously jeopardise the livelihood of Australians engaged in the Accommodation and Hospitality Industry.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that a service tax not be imposed on short-stay accommodation and that a deduction for tax purposes for legitimate entertainment expenses remain.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Hurford and Mr Scott.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia shows that there is a need to end the current discriminatory application of sales tax on confectionery and the other anomalies existing in sales tax law. Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that this tax should be replaced by a broad-based consumption tax with a uniform ad valorem rate, without any exemptions whatsoever.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Rocher and Mr Scott.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Children's Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives, the Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That the recent cuts announced in the Mini-Budget to Preschools and Day Care Services are a reversal of A.L.P. policy to make child care services available to all at an affordable cost. Further, that the fee rises arising from the cuts will cause great hardship to the majority of families using these services. Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House fully restores all Federal funding to children's services in Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Social Security and Repatriation Assets Test Abolition Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament asembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in the light of the Labor Government's failure to act to correct the anomalies in the Assets Test on pensions, brought to its attention prior to the Assets Test's introduction on 21st March 1985, this legislation should be repealed before it has an unduly unfair impact on pensioners.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should immediately seek the passage of the Social Security and Repatriation Assets Test Abolition Bill to repeal the Labor Government's iniquitous and unfair Assets Tests.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory Classification of Publications Ordinance
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled; should disallow the new Customs and Objectionable Publications Ordinance and that:
The Attorney-General enforce laws to prevent the importation and sale of hard-core pornography (e.g. X-rated videos) and publications which consistently incite the use of hard drugs;
The importation and sale of grossly obscene publications, including those associated with blasphemy be prevented;
Imported video tapes/discos for non-commercial use to be registered by the Films Censorship Board;
Censors more appropriately reflect responsible attitudes;
Further measures be taken in association with States to protect Australians, particularly women and children, from exploitation; and
That, because of the importance of this issue to society, a conscience vote be permitted to all Members of Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Changes to Veterans' Entitlements
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembed, we the undersigned call upon all Members to pay due respect to all returned service personnel. Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that all changes to benefits for veterans, and conditions of service for military personnel, as announced in the May Economic Statement, be withdrawn as to allow sufficient time for sensible community debate before any veteran or service person can be unfairly disadvantaged.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Excise on Beer
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
The Labor Government's policy of automatically increasing the excise applying to beer and therefore its price,
eliminates the opportunity for public or parliamentary debate on tax increase,
perpetrates inflation,
reduces job opportunities in the hotel and brewing industries,
and your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
immediately repeal those legislative provisions that automatically increase the excise on beer when the C.P.I. increases.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Small Businesses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
Introduction of any additional capital gains taxes, wealth taxes or death duties is opposed on the grounds that:
they adversely affect the small and medium size businesses in Australia, destroying incentive and discouraging investment in this important area of the economy;
the Australian economy, and employment in particular, is heavily reliant on growth in small businesses;

any capital gains that might result when owners of small buinesses finally sell the business are not ``windfall gains'' but the result of many hard years of work and sacrifice, with very little being taken out of the business by way of salaries so that the maximum amount of money can be ploughed back into the business to create growth and jobs;
the owners of small businesses often depend on a capital gain-which are simply deferred salaries- when they eventually sell their business to sustain them in retirement;

Your Petitioners request that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, will protect the rights of private enterprise and reject any inequitable additional taxes. And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Compensation for Use of Private Property
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth.
That all steps be taken to prevent the continuous erosion of the rights of the holders of freehold land.

Your petitioners draw to the attention of Parliament the denigration of freehold rights as practised in N.S.W. and calls on the Parliament to enact overriding legislation to allow full and proper compensation to all Australians where Government requires the use of private property and traditional rights attached thereto. And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate and to the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we deplore the discriminatory tax proposals as outlined in the Government's ``White Paper'' and the Government's preferred option on proposed new and widened tax proposals as so outlined, namely:
Capital Gains Tax
Hidden Death tax described as ``Capital Gains tax after death''
Gift tax
Increased Company tax
Employer taxes on employees, employment benefits.
All such taxes will discriminate against and inhibit progress, growth and employment throughout the nation.

They will attack hardworking people who have built up their assets; they will discourage thrift; they will inhibit development; they will treat unfairly all who plan for the future; they will cause trouble and expense in arriving at the value of their assets; they will discourage industry and punish achievement.
We ask that the tax proposals be rejected.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Gold
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable, the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Repesentatives in Parliament assembled should continue the present tax free status of gold.
We members of the Yilgarn Prospectors and Leasholders Association and concerned citizens feel that any imposition of a gold tax would have a devastating effect on exploration, mining and employment.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fuel Price
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
1. We are completely dissatisfied with the pricing policy of petrol in this country.
2. We are aware that it has an adverse affect on the living standards of the average wage earner of this country.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your Honourable House will:
Propose and pass a motion that the price of petrol be reduced by 3 cents a litre in line with a commitment given by the now Prime Minister of Australia during the 1983 election campaign.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fuel Price
PETITION.PARA: The Petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
1. That we are completely dissatisfied with the pricing of petrol in this country;
2. That under a Labor Government petrol prices have continued to rise excessively, with recent Government decisions adding over 8 cents per litre to the price of petrol in some country areas;
3. The proposed consumption tax could lead to a further rise of 6 cents per litre; and
4. The high cost of petrol discriminates against country residents who rely on their cars for essential communication and transport.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Government honour the commitment given by the Prime Minister during the 1983 election campaign to reduce petrol prices by 3 cents per litre.
Further we strongly urge the Government to adopt a petrol pricing policy which does not cause unnecessary rises in the cost of petrol. And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fuel Price
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, the humble Petition of the South Australian Country Women's Association Incorporated and the undersigned shall showeth.
The necessity to restore the concessional price of fuel in rural areas-without which there will be increased freight and production costs.
Your Petitioners therefore pray that your Honourable House will restore concessional price of fuel in rural areas for the benefit of all Australians.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Aerospace Industry
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows that:

Whereas space technology involves many of the very highest engineering and scientific disciplines that Australia posesses, which may be applied at an international level to reap significant economic and technological return to the nation, and;
Since an appropriate space program for Australia must involve presently unco-ordinated industry, government and research agencies, united together with Federal Government funding;

Your petitioners therefore pray that you will support the establishment of an Australian Aerospace Agency to manage aerospace programs under a Federal Budget, promote technology transfer, and market our expertise overseas, while ensuring the continued operation of existing space-related facilities within the nation.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned electors, are deeply concerned at the possibility of an increase in indirect taxation currently being considered by the government.
To pose a broadly based consumption tax would mean a proportionately greater burden on low income groups and worsen their already precarious and impoverished position.

Women who are supporting mothers, together with their children, are acknowledged as the largest single group forced to exist below the poverty line. As beneficiaries of an already inadequate government pension, their futures would be even more jeopardised if there were to be a change towards increased broadly based consumption taxation.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Federal government not adopt the proposed shift towards increased indirect taxation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament Assembled:

We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government, in re-structuring the taxation system, upholds as fundamental the principle of an equitable distribution of wealth among the people of our nation, and
1. That the Government does not levy any form of broadly based indirect or consumption taxation, and
2. That the Government does levy gift and death duties, excluding the family home from the latter, and a substantial tax on realised capital gains and wealth.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament Assembled:

The humble petition of ABC listeners and viewers showeth that the autonomy and non-commercial independent broadcasting services of the ABC is in jeopardy because the ABC is currently having to bear additional costs involved in the AUSSAT satellite operation.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that:

1. The Government restores $20 million to the ABC's budget for 1985-86 to ensure that the services the ABC provides the Australian public are maintained and improved, particularly in terms of educational and rural programs, and that ABC staff are not needlessly retrenched.

2. The Government will not introduce corporate sponsorship or any form of advertising into the ABC since this would destroy the independence and autonomy of the ABC. The non-commercial independent broadcasting service provided by the ABC is fundamental to Australian democracy.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions: Assets Test
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament Assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in the light of the Labor Government's failure to act to correct the many anomalies in the Assets Test on pensions brought to its notice, the Labor Government's legislation should be repealed before it has an unduly unfair impact on pensioners.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should immediately seek the repeal of the Labor Government's iniquitous and unfair Assets Test.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Enterprise Migrant Hostel, Victoria
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

We are concerned that the closure of the Enterprise Migrant Hostel will be detrimental to the long-term settlement prospects of migrants in Victoria as well as detrimental to Ethnic Communities who have settled in the Springvale area. In addition, the long-term development of commerce and industry in the area will be adversely affected.
We urge the Government to reverse this decision.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Free Zones
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of citizens of Australia shows:

That the people of New Zealand and the New Zealand Government have given an example to the world in their efforts to achieve a nuclear free South Pacific, and such decision being endorsed by the people at a general election.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government support the principled stand taken by the New Zealand Government and urges it to condemn any efforts by the U.S. Government to impose economic or other sanctions on New Zealand in retaliation for their stand on nuclear vessels.
We further urge the Australian Government to urgently implement its policy to promote the development of zones of peace and nuclear free zones in the Indian and Pacific Oceans.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Post Agency, Joondana, Western Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:
That it is proposed Australia Post's Post Office Agency on the corner of Green and London Streets, Joondana, Western Australia will be closed down on 30 June,1985.
Your petitioners therefore pray that this Agency be kept operating for the benefit of the many people who avail themselves of its services and who appreciate the convenience of its location.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Compulsory Unionism
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain concerned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the actions of trade unions have gone beyond their traditional goals of protecting workers' conditions and rates of pay and have reached the point where they are seriously affecting the economic health of the nation and the people.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray:
1. That all Governments throughout Australia acknowledge and protect the Right to Work on behalf of all Australians.
2. That the total sovereignty of individual governments be recognised as a fundamental requirement of a workable, balanced Federal system of government.
3. That all necessary steps be taken to protect the citizens of Australia from any compulsion, threat or intimidation to join any trade union.
4. That the supremacy of elected governments over the sectional interests of trade unions be recognised, and
5. That the provision of essential services be maintained, free from industrial disruption.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Swan Island Lighthouse
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that:

1. Manned lighthouses provide a safer service for mariners than automated lighthouses, as well as serving a wide cross-section of other community purposes including: meteorological observations, search and rescue, coast watch, environmental protection and control;
2. Swan Island Lighthouse serves the heavily trafficked and extremely dangerous Banks Strait;
3. Swan Island is listed for registration under the Commonwealth administered Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, will call upon the Government to ensure that Swan Island Lighthouse continues to be a manned station.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Army Artillery Base, Orange-Bathurst Area
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We the undersigned are deeply concerned that the decision to place an Army Artillery Base in the Orange-Bathurst area would cause undue hardship to the families affected.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled will call upon the Government to:
1. Abandon its decision to resume land in the Orange- Bathurst area for military purposes.
2. That no site is chosen which includes prime farming land.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nursing Home Patients
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of South Australia showeth that:

Without any warning and at the worst possible moment, the Federal Government has abandoned the pensioner patients in South Australia's Nursing Homes. These people are suffering undeserving hardship and trauma as a result of the Federal Government's decision to freeze the nursing home benefit levels in South Australia.

The pensioner patients and those on fixed incomes now cannot expect any relief from recent significant fee increases approved by the Department of Community Services and which have coincided with the decision to freeze benefits.

80-85% of nursing home patients are pensioners and the majority are now required to pay in excess of their pension for their nursing care for the very first time. Some are paying over $5 per day on top of their pension. Many are looking for cheaper nursing care that does not exist:
We request that the Federal Government:

1. alleviate the distress of South Australia's nursing home patients and their families by effective restoration of the principle that pensioner patients should not have to pay more than their pension for nursing home care
2. restore the review of the benefit rates in November 1985
3. resolve its concerns over health care costs with the South Australian Government rather than inflicting unnecessary suffering on nursing home patients.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Bilney,Mr Downer,Mr Steele Hall and Mr Jacobi.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Fisher respectfully showeth:

That we deplore the discriminatory tax proposals as outlined in the Government's ``White Paper'' and the Government's preferred option on proposed new and widened tax proposals as so outlined, namely:
Capital Gains tax
Hidden Death tax described as ``Capital Gains tax after death''
Gift Tax
Increased Company tax
Employer taxes on employees' employment benefits.
All such taxes will discriminate against and inhibit progress, growth and employment throughout the nation.

They will attack hardworking people who have built up their assets; they will discourage thrift; they will inhibit development; they will treat unfairly all who plan for the future; they will cause trouble and expense in arriving at the value of their assets; they will discourage industry and punish achievement.
We ask that the tax proposals be rejected.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions: Assets Test
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of the Federal Division of Fisher in Queensland respectfully showeth:
That the Hawke Socialist Government be called upon to remove the unjust and cruel Assets Test;
That the Assets Test discriminates grossly against those people living on acreage blocks or in rural areas;
That the introduction of the Government's grab for the assets of senior citizens is condemned as un-Australian;
That the Government is requested to reconsider the Assets Test.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The peition of certain citizens of the Federal Divison of Fisher in Queensland respectfully showeth:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will:
Propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian national flag remains sacrosanct from change''.
. And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The damaging effects of record high interest rates on home owners, small business and other borrowers.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

TALK.START.PARA: —I call the Deputy Leader of the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not quite, Madam Deputy Speaker, but thank you for the accolade. This afternoon the Opposition raises the matter of the damaging effects of record high interest rates on home owners, small business and other borrowers. Let me make it quite clear that our concern with the Government today is not about the question of the deregulation of interest rates, a question regarding which we share a great many of the Government's objectives. It is not about the effects or otherwise of monetary policy on interest rates; it is about the sheer deception employed by this Government of the Australian people before the last election when it claimed, dishonestly, that interest rates would be lowered this year and when it knew jolly well they would not be. That is the argument we have with the Government, a government which maintains the facade of honour, integrity and fair dealing but which has been caught out in the grubbiest of possible manoeuvres.

SPEECH.PARA: It was very evident today in Question Time, as it was yesterday, that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) were very uneasy when asked questions about the highest interest rates in Australia's history. The Prime Minister was asked today by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) whether it was a fact that a person with a housing loan of $40,000 at the moment is paying about $10 a week more in loan repayments than he was in April 1985 when the Prime Minister renewed his pre-election promise that interest rates would fall. So as recently as April 1985 the Prime Minister was still repeating his pre-election promise that interest rates would fall.

The response of the Prime Minister in the House today to that question was absolutely disgraceful. I repeat his words. He said that he was not concerned with `the hypothetical home owners' mentioned by the Leader of the Opposition. The Prime Minister is not concerned with `hypothetical home owners' borrowing $40,000 on their homes and having to pay an extra $10 a week in interest payments since he made the promise in April that interest rates would be reduced. The Prime Minister had very good cause for unease in his reply. It was a measure of his uneasiness that he made such a nonsensical and insulting response to the home owners of Australia about their very real end of week concerns. The sum of $10 a week dwarfs the money that is being talked about in terms of tax cuts under the accord next year. However, $10 a week in hard cash out of a family's pocket is something that people are really worried about.

What was the Government saying before the last election? Let us get the quotations. In an interview with John Laws on radio station 2UE on 5 November 1984, before the election, the Prime Minister said:
. . . because inflation is coming down and inflationary expectations are down interest rates will come down too.
On 20 November 1984 in an address to a business lunch, and talking to another audience, the Prime Minister said:
At present the outlook for interest rates is as bright as it has been for more than a decade.

I remind the House that the present level of interest rates-I mean real interest rates after one subtracts for inflation-is the highest it has been for 50 years. That is the prospect, `brighter' than it has been `for more than a decade'! In order to rub it in, at the same business lunch I have just mentioned, the Prime Minister also said:

Australia and Australians will during 1985 reap the interest rate rewards that are flowing from the successful policies of the last 20 months. We have plowed the fields and sown the seeds. In the very near future we will harvest the crop.
It was not only the Prime Minister who was making remarks such as that. The Treasurer, who is my opposing speaker in this debate, said on 14 March on the PM program, again after the election:
I still stand by the remark I made in the election campaign that I think there is an interest rate step fall ahead for Australia and its interest rate structure generally through 1985.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was on 14 March!

—That was on 14 March 1985, which is not all that long ago. However, it was certainly repeating the false claim that had been made before the election. What happens when one makes false claims before an election? The Press takes them up in exactly the way one would expect. I have with me a copy of the front page of the Sydney Daily Mirror dated Monday, 5 November, the headline of which reads: `Home Loan Drop on Way'. It is accompanied by a picture of the Treasurer. What does the accompanying article say? Guy Ker of Canberra states:

SPEECH.PARA: Home buyers are set to receive a New Year bonus with mortgage rates strongly tipped to fall.

Treasurer Paul Keating has predicted an across-the-board fall in interest rates flowing on to home repayments. Mr Keating said: `I accept the views of most market commentators that we have further interest rate falls ahead of us.'

That is the headline the Government was searching for during the election campaign. That is the headline it got. It repeated its false claim later. More recent headlines and those of today are somewhat different. A headline of the Daily Telegraph dated Wednesday, 21 July reads `Home Loans to Hit 15 per cent', a somewhat different headline. Of course, there is no election on at the moment. Another headline, which appeared in the Sunday Telegraph on 25 August, reads: `Bankcards to hit 21 per cent'. That is the reality. What the Opposition accuses the Government of is having economic policies which, taken together, have pushed real interest rates to their highest level for 50 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you deregulate housing interest rates?

—If the honourable member had been present at the beginning of my speech he would have heard me make it quite clear that in this case we are not arguing with the Government's general approach of deregulating interest rates. Nor are we arguing, as the Treasurer has tried to imply in answers to questions, that we do not understand the distinction between monetary policy and the links between monetary policy and interest rates. I make it clear to the honourable member that we are not arguing on those grounds. We are saying quite clearly that before the election there was a deceitful commitment and promise by the Government to bring down interest rates which led to the kind of headlines we saw in the Daily Mirror and on which the Government went to the election. Since then interest rates have gone through the roof.

SPEECH.PARA: What are the basic effects of this? I have already given the example of the home owner with a $40,000 loan from a savings bank who is an extra $10 a week out of pocket as a result of the rise of the last few months. Let us look at what has happened to other interest rates. What about small businesses? Small business overdrafts dropped to a bottom interest rate of 13.5 per cent in January 1984. The most recent rate, which was quoted by a bank this morning, is 16.25 per cent. So interest rates have gone up from 13 1/2 per cent in January 1984 to 16 1/4 per cent.

How does that effect a small business that is borrowing, shall we say, $90,000? On my calculations it would mean an extra interest cost of $2,475 a year-certainly enough to pay somebody a part time salary for work in that business. It would mean an extra bill of $206 a month for that small business. I presume that if the Prime Minister thought we were talking about hypothetical home owners during Question Time he also thinks we are talking about hypothetical small businessmen. How many people out there in the community who are running small businesses would be pleased to hear that their Prime Minister regards their problems as hypothetical, as he regards the problems of the average home owner?

What about people borrowing on Bankcard? Bankcard interest rates will go up to 21 per cent over the next month. What is happening with savings bank loans? Not only are people paying an extra $10 a week on their loans, but also they are being asked by savings banks to pay additional special charges on home loans as a device to get around the artificial ceiling of 13 1/2 per cent imposed by the Government. It is quite possible that if one has a home loan of about $40,000 through a savings bank at the moment one is being charged, say, an additional $70 a year by way of special charges. Indeed, the Treasurer admitted in Question Time today that that is a means by which banks are getting around this ceiling. So whichever way people go, whether they go outside the savings banks to other forms of borrowers or whether special packages are devised by the lenders to get around the 13 1/2 per cent, the simple fact of the matter is that the costs of financing home mortgages and the costs of running small businesses have been going up enormously.

The critical point we want to make is that the Treasurer made an absolute meal of the so-called $9.6 billion deficit which he said he inherited from the previous Treasurer and which he used in the first election campaign in 1983. Subsequently it was discovered that the particular estimates he was looking at were considered by him to be not worth publishing the following year because they were not soundly enough based. Now he has been sprung on that piece of deception. He claimed that the previous Treasurer was guilty of deception, and he himself was sprung by using this trick a year later when he was not prepared to publish the identical figure on the grounds that it had no validity. These were forward estimates of no particular value and no credibility could be placed on them.

This is a question of the credibility of this Government. The very same Treasurer who accused our former Treasurer of misleading the Australian public over what were then phony figures is now shown, with his Prime Minister, to have made statements before the last election, which he knew were dangerous, about interest rates going down. In fact he criticised people on our side of politics well before that for making similar statements. That he did some years ago. He knew when he made those statements that a Treasurer could not possibly do so with any degree of credibility. In this case I suggest that they were made as a matter of sheer deceit during the course of the election campaign.

Another piece of evidence supports this. Before the election the Government relaxed its monetary policy, in other words, it allowed more money to flow into the economy thus easing artificially the pressure on interest rates. There was a deliberate attempt by the Government, by manipulating and relaxing monetary policy, to make it appear that the pressures on interest rates which it knew would come after the election were not there. The whole time that the Government was making these claims to the Australian public, getting all the good press and getting people to believe that interest rates would come down, it knew that there was a substantial possibility that interest rates would go up in the new year.

In a speech yesterday and in other speeches the Treasurer has tried to create a contrast between the supposedly wonderful economic policies of this Government compared with the record of the previous Government. The present Treasurer had the advantage, on coming into office, of inheriting a wage pause which was brought in under the Fraser Government. He had the advantage of coming in when the world economy was rising as a result of the successful policies of the United States of America Government. He also had the advantage--

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha!

—The Treasurer does not like to hear this. He hates hearing this. He also had the advantage of coming into office when one of the worst droughts that we have had in our history broke. He had advantages on three counts. He had the breaking of the drought, the world economy turning up and also the benefits of the Fraser wage pause. If he cannot do a reasonable economic job on those grounds he is a hopeless Treasurer.

SPEECH.PARA: The net result of the Treasurer's economic policies and what he has been going on about since he has been in office is to get us the highest interest rates in Australia's history and also to go into a situation where our external debt is rising substantially, where we are not internationally competitive and where our inflation rate is higher than our competitors around the world. Yet he is doing inflationary deals with the trade union movement which will make our overall situation worse. What we are trying to do and quite clearly presenting is an overall contrast between the claims of the Government about its economic policy and the actual reality. We are trying to expose for the fraud that they are the attacks that honourable members opposite have made on us, on the previous Treasurer and on the previous Government. Before the election the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said:
. . . because inflation is coming down and inflationary expectations are down interest rates will come down too.
Post-election he said the same thing. He said:
We nevertheless believe that given the fundamental strengths of the Australian economy . . . I would expect, a lowering in the level of interest rates.

That statement was fraudulent at the time it was made before the election; it was fraudulent at the time it was said in April; and it remains a fraud. I condemn the Government for this deceit of the Australian people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — I am absolutely devastated. I thought that, with this new dry Liberal Party of Australia, we would get some real philosophy. The honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) is supposed to be the philosophy whiz kid, the bloke who determines where the Liberal Party is heading. But what do we find? We find just a bit of political opportunism, a whinge about interest rates set in a market in which he supposedly has faith. We would have done better with the Opposition led by the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) who never pretended to be anything but an opportunist and with the former Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), who handled these matters of public importance in the House and at least had some idea of basic economics. At least then we would have heard something which resembled the facts. The honourable member for Mackellar went on to say that he wanted to attack the Government for what was said at the election campaign. The terms of the matter of public importance are:

SPEECH.PARA: The damaging effects of record high interest rates on home owners, small business and other borrowers.

What damaging effects? The economy is bursting along at an annual rate of about 5 per cent. If we use the American flash number system, for the last quarter we would have had a flash figure of between eight and 12, depending on what measure of growth we use. The honourable member for Mackellar comes into this chamber and tells us that the economy is being damaged by these interest rates. I remind the honourable gentlemen that in the last few years the United States economy did very nicely under high interest rates with a basic strength in the economy. While nobody in his right mind would like interest rates higher than they need to be the fact of the matter is that this economy has grown very nicely as a result of the policies of this Government.

What we heard today was not an addressing of the damaging effects of high interest rates. We heard a whinge about what I said at the election campaign and what the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is supposed to have said. We cannot help it if everything we say gets beaten up on the front page of the Daily Mirror. There is no point in showing me the front pages of the Daily Mirror. Half the stories are thought up and are on the morning tabloids at 5.30 in the morning before the journalists get out of bed. The honourable member should not raise that matter to give substance to this issue.

The fact is that interest rates are set in the market. The former Government, of which the honourable gentleman opposite was a Minister and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) was the Treasurer, had the most regulated financial system in the world. It was so constipated by regulation that it was simply incapable of servicing the needs of this economy. We came into government and just about cut down every regulatory stalk. Not one regulatory stalk is standing bar the housing interest rates. That is the only one. We are urged to let that go too. The humbug of the position of those opposite is that they come into this chamber today crying crocodile tears about housing interest rates while urging us in Press statements to take the regulated ceiling off housing interest rates.

In the whole market of interest rates in this country we have re-established the banks into a position of primacy in the Australian financial system and have lifted their competitive position against non-bank financial institutions by having rates set in the market using a sophisticated bond tender system on Federal Government securities and by accepting rates at the market yields. What do members of the new dry Liberal Party say? They do not like the rates. They do not like the market outcomes. The Opposition's supposedly dry philosphy of letting the market rule will not accept that we have interest rates in this country in respect of market positions. What absolute humbug for members of the Opposition to talk about housing interest rates when they are urging the Government to lift the interest rate ceiling on housing. For months now the Leader Opposition has been urging that we lift the interest rate ceiling on housing. Then the Opposition trots out the fact that it will cost borrowers x number of dollars. This is the first week of the new dry Opposition. It comes in with the sort of motion which any back bencher in opposition would feel guilty about proposing and then talks about some phoney interest rate calculation on losses per week.

The fact is that the Opposition right through has opposed full wage indexation. It has said that it should not exist. It opposed all the wage rises before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. Last year the present Leader of the Opposition said there should be no tax cuts and that we should have a lower Budget deficit. Since this Government came to office there have been wage rises of $45 a week and $7.60 in tax cuts. The Opposition is saying that there should have been none of that but that we are terrible because housing interest rates have risen. Yet those interest rates have not risen to the ceilings that occurred during the time of the former Treasurer. But, while saying all that, the Opposition says that the ceiling should not be there anyway. How does the Opposition expect us to have any respect for it when it espouses those views?

The honourable member for Mackellar then talked about Bankcard and said that we lifted the ceiling on personal credit card interest. We did lift the ceiling. That was part of a general deregulation that the Government has sought to introduce in this country. It is true that the rate of interest on Bankcard has risen from 18 per cent to 21 per cent. But the fact is that that will have its own rationing effect in the market. If the people who run Bankcard find that they cannot do the business that they used to do, they will lower the rate, and it will find its own equilibrium.

But the Opposition is not about finding equilibrium. The Opposition is just about a bit of cheap politics. I understand all about that because I have been listening to Opposition members for 2 1/2 years. But they should not come and parade themselves as paragons of virtue, saying that they know how things should be and have some philosophy that will help and that this Government has its policies wrong. The fact is that they do not have a free market philosophy. They never have had. When they had the opportunity to do anything about it, they did not take it. This Government has taken every opportunity to have a favourable influence on interest rates impacting themselves upon the economy and has reduced the Budget deficit from nearly 5 per cent of gross domestic product in prospect to 2.2 percentage points for this year.

We have reduced the public sector borrowing requirement in this financial year by 1 1/2 per cent. The previous Government was easy on the States in Loan Council and we were left governing 25 per cent of State borrowings. We have reduced that amount. But, despite that, we still see bank credit running strongly. Trading bank advances rose 25 per cent in July over the figures for the previous year. What the Opposition is saying is: `Oh no, what we ought to do, where the rate is lower, is to have 35 per cent advances'. But the fact is that rates are set in the market. We are seeing an enormous change in the financial system. The balance sheets of non-bank financial institutions have risen by about only 7 per cent over the last year whereas those of trading banks have risen markedly showing a greater flow of funds back into the trading bank sector as the banks become more competitive. But the Opposition has given no commentary on that.

I cannot believe that, with the great expectation that the shadow Treasurer has of painting the philosophy for the future economic policy of a Liberal government, he could come here with a sleazy loose-mouthed proposition about how much it costs a week in interest rates. I honestly do not know what else I can say about this. It is not often that I run out of words but his policies are so crook that I do not know what to say next.

I will turn to another point the honourable member for Mackellar made. He lasted for about five or six minutes on interest rates. I have done my best; I have lasted eight minutes. But he then went on to talk about the economy and said: `Those lucky mugs in the Government got the advantage of our wage pause'. Let me tell honourable members about the wage pause. The wage pause was the state of the labour market after the previous Government destroyed it, but it called it a wage pause. There was a pause in wages but it was because there was no labour market left, so they called it the wage pause.

The honourable member then said: `You lucky people also had this enormous fillip from the world. World recovery picked up, the drought broke and that is what saved you.' But let me cite the figures, which are official Treasury figures-something that I always have to point out to those opposite-for the contribution of net exports in total GDP for the last three years. For 1983-84 the figure is 0.1 per cent, to which I hope the Opposition is listening. For the second year this lucky Government received a minus 0.4 per cent contribution to total GDP from net exports. This year, with the depreciation, the figure will be 1.25 per cent. In other words, we secured an economic recovery, but does the Opposition know how? It was the hardest way of all, from inside Australia. It was not with any help from anybody else. It was not with any help from the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —A certain amount from upstairs.
—The farm sector occupies a very small proportion of GDP and it was in our first year only. It diminished in the second year and this year.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that we have been able to secure an economic recovery and wage restraint through the prices and incomes accord, which the Opposition deplores, and then the opposition says: `You were all lucky because it came off the world recovery'. The Opposition members should go and try to tell the people who are selling in the world how good it is out there and how much demand there is out there to lift the state of the Australian economy, if we are said to be relying on the world. The fact is that we have in place an economic policy which has seen more growth in three years than occurred in the whole period that the previous Government was in office-in fact more growth in three years than under the previous Government's eight years.

TALK.START.PARA: —You forgot to deny the drought.

—If the honourable member had been listening, I said that the farm sector occupies a very small part of GDP so, even a big change in that small part would not impact very much on GDP. The honourable member should look at the economic outcomes for 1983-84. The fact is that this Government has been able to mount an economic policy and a resurgence of economic growth and employment growth in this country. There are 410,000 people in work who did not have a job when this Government came to office. Unemployment is decreasing. This is in sharp contrast to the policies of many other governments.

SPEECH.PARA: The Liberal Party and its economic bourbons learn nothing and have forgotten nothing. They still have the same policy. Yesterday the shadow Treasurer asked me a question about flexibility. What he is really saying is that we should have a system in which real wages decline so that company profits can continue to rise. That is the basis of the Opposition's wages philosophy. It will not work; it never worked and it never will work. This Government has put together two more years of wage restraint, flexibility in the labour market, decelerating inflation and strong economic growth. But the Opposition is saying: `That's not good enough. What we want is some sort of theoretical policy which tries to get where you are now!' The previous Government tried its policy and it did not work. But it is back here telling us that ours is no good. The best that the Opposition can do is to say that it does not like the price of housing interest rates but that the ceiling should be lifted and that it does not like the market determined rate for Bankcard and other market determined rates but that it supposedly believes in the free market. But when the Opposition was in government it never deregulated any markets; it let them stay still for 30 years until they were almost entirely constipated. It let the report of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System rot. Yet it says to us that we have restored Australia's competitiveness by bringing down costs and floating the exchange rate to see a depreciation of the dollar.

TALK.START.PARA: —And borrowing money.
—The borrowing is no doubt a reference to the $9.6 billion bequeathed to us by the honourable member and his party, which we have now reduced to $5 billion or more than half in GDP.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that it is game, set and match in economic policy in this country. In a personal sense, I wish Mr Carlton the best; I do not want to cruel it for him. But the fact is that he left Ash Street in a ruin and that is how he would leave the Australian economy if he got his hands on it. Of course, this Government would like interest rates to be as low as possible but, in a market determined system with very strong growth, the price of money will obviously rise with the demand. If growth subsides or if growth is kept in check, presumably, all things being equal, the price of money will subside also. For the Government's part, it must do what it can to create the conditions where interest rates will fall. It is reducing the public sector deficit and the public sector borrowing requirement. We are competitive and we will have more growth in the economy. That will further diminish the state of public indebtedness. In that situation the private sector will continue to invest strongly and consumption will run nicely as a result of a tax cut last year. The fact of the matter is that interest rates finally are mastered. We reject absolutely the central tenets of the Opposition's proposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Treasurer's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard the Treasurer (Mr Keating) talk about game, set and match but if he listened to the electorate, particularly the home owners, small businessmen and borrowers, he would certainly realise that there is no love out there for his policies because of the manner in which interest rates are severely affecting each of the people about whom we are talking. It has become the lot of the Australian Labor Party in government to have risen to the lofty halls of fame and then to have turned away immediately from the people whom it is supposed to be representating. I suggest that, if the Treasurer went home and listened to the people in his electorate, he would find that possibly the thing most talked about at the moment, the problem most people are facing, is high interest rates.

SPEECH.PARA: If we look at the record, we see that we are talking not just about high interest rates but about the highest real rates of interest since the Depression in 1933. This is the basic problem as we see it. We also heard the Treasurer bandy around such phrases as being devastated and being at a loss for words about the flash figures of the United States. I suggest to the Treasurer that, if he came down to earth and started talking in terms that the electorate can understand, he might get the answers he seeks to the problems facing the Australian economy.

The Treasurer made some statements which I believe were not accurate when he talked about an entirely deregulated market. As far as I can see, that is not the situation. If the Treasurer wants to set a difference between interest rates for borrowings under $100,000 and over $100,000 obviously deregulation is still in the market place. He talked about trading bank advances being 25 per cent up on last year's figure. I suggest that if the productivity of the Australian economy is being determined by the earnings of the major banks in Australia, that figure is accurate. As I understand it, major profits have been made in the trading sections of the banks of Australia. I understand that the Primary Industry Bank of Australia has returned a record profit, not because it is lending to borrowers but because it is reinvesting. The people to whom PIBA is supposed to be lending cannot afford to borrow at the current rates and the bank is reinvesting at a profit. If the Treasurer's view of the economy is based on the rewards to big business and big financial institutions, I suggest that he look further and beyond for a just comparison.

The Treasurer admitted that the people most hurt are those in the rural sector as far as their return on capital is concerned in financing large loans at high interest rates. No doubt their performance, as a percentage of gross domestic product, is slipping because Labor's policies are making it slip. There is no denying that the Government's deliberate monetary policy at this stage is to keep up interest rates to shore up the plummeting dollar. We can see the result of the dollar going on to the open market by looking at graphs published recently which show that in January 1985 the dollar was up to United States 80 cents, by April it had shrunk to United States 63 cents, and now it is hovering just over United States 65 cents. That is basically what is determining the Government's monetary policy.

We have seen a 5 per cent devaluation of the dollar just in the last week. No doubt this has come about because of the details of the accord and the productivity claim that have been exposed. This will put another nail in the coffin of productivity and the small borrowers about whom we are worried. As has often been said, the plummeting Australian dollar shows the contempt of every other nation in the world for how the Australian economy is going. Perhaps if the Treasurer went off-shore to some authority other than the persons who gave him his silver medal last year-

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not worth a brass razoo now.

—He should give it back; I admit that. The Treasurer should seek the real facts about what is going on off-shore. Let us look at Australian interest rates compared with those of our export competitors. Australian interest rates for housing are regulated at 13.5 per cent, but the real interest rate for loans over $100,000 is 19.5 per cent. At an inflation rate of 6.5 per cent we are looking at a real rate of interest of 13 per cent. Let me again emphasise that that is the largest real interest rate since the Depression of 1933. The interest rate in France is 5.8 per cent; in the United Kingdom 12.6 per cent in; West Germany 5.3 per cent; in the United States 9.3 per cent; and in Japan 7 per cent. None of those countries comes within 7 per cent of the Australian interest rate. France has an inflation rate of 4 1/2 per cent; United Kingdom 5 per cent; West Germany 2 1/4 per cent; United States 3 1/2 per cent; and Japan 2 per cent. Australia's real rate of interest is a record compared with those of our major competitors, and that is the point at issue. Whatever else anybody may say about the economy and the standard of living of every person in Australia, we depend on how much we trade our goods overseas and how competitively we can get them on to that market. We can talk about the effect on exports of devaluing the dollar, but it is not worth a crumpet if that advantage is removed by upping the real interest rates for the borrowers of Australia who are supplying our export needs. That is the basic economic fact that the Government should start to learn.

SPEECH.PARA: These interest rates reflect a necessity for other people to seek in Australia a high interest return on their money, the rates being a world record as far as our competitors are concerned; or people speculate here. The unfortunate fact is that we bring in that money from overseas to boost the dollar. It has not happened this year; it has been shrinking all the time. So people get a double advantage by bringing off-shore money into Australia. Not only do they get high interest rates, but they are able to gamble on the dollar devaluing more; and that money will be repatriated when the dollar sinks to the bottom of the barrel and there are people in Australia who believe that the dollar has not yet bottomed against the United States dollar and that it has further to go. That not only shows the contempt of the world for our dollar but also indicates what the world thinks about our arrangement with ANZUS at the beginning of this year. The Labor Party should not forget that. It is all tied up together.

The inflation rate is predicted in the 1985 Budget to rise to 8 per cent, which has already brought in the speculators. Within three weeks of presenting the Budget and indicating that increase in inflation-I believe that is a minimum amount, not a maximum-the interest rate for housing has gone up by 0.5 per cent. I believe that there is a connection there. After the Budget, on 22 August 1985, the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) said: `This Budget will bring interest rates down'. He is the man who is supposed to have the concern of the rural populace of Australian and he is condemning it to an ever-increasing interest rate. How can they be competitive and improve productivity? No wonder the farm percentage performance is slimming.

We have had the promises of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer about reduced interest rates. The Treasurer had the hide today to waffle at the dispatch box about there being no issue. It is not an issue for him because he lives in an ivory tower and he is not prepared to listen to find out what is happening. As far as I am concerned, it was probably the most pathetic performance that the Treasurer of Australia has given in this regard.

Who suffers under these high interest rates? Obviously home owners do. The honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) has already indicated other areas in which people suffer. There is no doubt that our export industries are suffering. The cost of interest is one of those items that cannot be reduced; it is a fixed charge. Small businesses in Australia likewise cannot go anywhere else and cannot reduce their borrowing costs; they are the ones who will be going out the back door in large numbers. It will not be large businesses, but small businesses. As I said, the highest uncontrolled cost that we have in rural industry and small business today is the cost of borrowing.

I nearly took a back flip when the Treasurer said that the interest rate is set in the market place. I just pose this question to the House: Who influences that market? Nobody influences it more than the Commonwealth Government itself when putting in place monetary policies such as this Government has. That is exactly the situation. The market has reacted not to the demands of the bloke down the street or the person on the land; it has responded to the demand of the Government to fund its deficit, to cover its unfavourable balance of trade. That is who influences the market and the Treasurer might do well to go on the record so we can see what he says in that regard.

Members of the Opposition are having a great deal of difficulty. I suggest to them that when this short-lived experiment begins to collapse around their ears they had better summon Senator Chaney out of the Senate and get him over here in A grade to lead them out of the wilderness. They will not be led out of the wilderness in this current situation. They do not have a philosophy; they do not know which way they want to go. The honorable member for Mackellar talks about freeing things up, but what does he want to do in regard to housing interest rates? Is he prepared to have people face the higher housing rates that would come about? We have some doubts about that.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Mackellar and others are trying somehow to dredge policies out of the ground. They are going around in a swamp with a divining rod hoping that something will pop up. That is the way they get their philosophy; that is the way they try to manage the economy. At this stage they are trying to work out a wages policy. Their philosophy is simple-get young people to bargain with employers and strike a contract. Where have honourable members opposite been all their lives? What they are putting is absolute hypocrisy. I can tell them where they will be-they will stay in opposition because their policy is disreputable and just does not hang together. That can be done in a place like Newcastle or Wollongong. A young person can roll up to the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd and say: `I want to strike a reasonable rate for working in the refinery'. It will not happen. The Australian electorate sees through this. The Opposition is searching around in the fog for a philosophy. It will not work. What did members of the previous Government give us? They gave us double digit inflation and lost 250,000 jobs in their last year. What a recipe for desperation. What about interest rates? They kept being pushed up, despite all the posturings of the honourable member for Mackellar and the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite). We are not sure where the honourable member for Dawson stands in this. He paints himself as a dry yet when gets into north Queensland he wants to subsidise everything, prop everything up just the way they do in north Queensland. That is all right, but I wish we knew where he stood. They are all over the place. They are an absolutely disreputable bunch and the Australian public recognises them as such. What about their performance in regard to jobs? We have created 410,000 jobs since we have been in office, but they destroyed 250,000 jobs in their last year. Who was their Treasurer? The recently resurrected elected Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard).

We will not let anyone forget the $9.6 billion dollar man, the man who suddenly says: `I have this new formula for getting things right-I will do what Margaret Thatcher tells me'. I suggest to those opposite who come in here posturing about Margaret Thatcher and her performance that they look at what happened in Birmingham, look at the social disruption that the absolutely shonky people in charge of Britain have produced. They saw what the previous Government did. It destroyed jobs and housing. Honourable members opposite come in here and say that they are terribly worried about housing, but I can recall when the coalition was in government some of its members, some of whom are in this chamber at the moment, saying that people had to learn to live without housing, that the Australian people would have to be educated and led to realise that they might not own a house in their lifetime. What have we done in our time in office? We have people who previously lived in caravans now in their own homes. Honourable members opposite are a disreputable lot. All this disreputable lot could say was that people would have to learn to live without housing. What a recipe for disaster and desperation. They come in here with some wafty philosophy, saying: `We are going to put it all right, just give us a chance'. We will not give them a chance; neither will the Australian people. What do Opposition members want? Do they want to deregulate housing rates, or do they want to have them controlled? On what sort of platform do they want to formulate their policy? Are they worried about the current operation of monetary policy? Would they leave everything freed up? From their comments I take it that they are very concerned about us having floated the dollar and deregulated the financial system. Yet according to their philosophy that is exactly what they would do. They cannot have all the pleasure without some of the pain. What is it that they want? We recognise that the Opposition is made up of a lot of retreads. It was in government before and a lot its members failed. The Australian community also recognises that a lot of its members failed and that they are retreads. It is no good saying: `We have just discovered this new philosophy and we are going to get it right'. The Opposition had better have words to Senator Chaney and get him over here into A grade where the business side of things is and suggest that he take over the leadership after the current leader has failed because it is as clear as the day that in fact he will fail.

The Opposition has not got it together and I suggest that it will have to do a lot of hard work. It is going to have to get some consistency. SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Dairy Produce Amendment Bill contains two technical amendments to the Dairy Produce Act 1924. The first will correct a legal difficulty in the operation of the export pooling arrangements for the dairy industry. The second amendment will remove administrative difficulties with the present legislation with respect to the power of the Australian Dairy Corporation to enter contracts. Both amendments are clearly in the interests of the dairy industry. The amendments are a temporary measure, reflecting the fact that the major revisions-including to the Australian Dairy Corporation's financial powers-which are part and parcel of the proposed revised arrangements have not proceeded as soon as the Government would have wished.

Clause 3 of the Bill amends section 20AB of the Dairy Produce Act 1924. This section establishes an export pooling scheme which essentially provides for the averaging of returns for exports of prescribed dairy produce during a season. Since its inception in 1977 advance payments on account of likely final payments have been approved and made under the section.

However, amendments which were made to section 20AB of the Act in 1978 led to an anomaly which was only discovered during a recent comprehensive review of dairy legislation. The effect of the anomaly is to prevent the making of advance payments to exporters of dairy produce from the dairy produce export pools. Honourable members might have noted that clause 3 of the Bill will correct this anomaly both prospectively and retrospectively. I should stress that this particular provision is beneficial in effect and that no burdens or liabilities will arise from its retrospective application.

Clause 4 provides for the replacement of section 25 of the Act. This section requires the ADC to seek ministerial approval before entering contracts involving more than $100,000 unless the contract relates to the sale or disposal of dairy produce. The proposed replacement for section 25 will remove the requirement for prior ministerial approval in respect of two classes of contracts from time to time entered into by the ADC. The first class of contracts proposed to be removed from the ambit of section 25 is futures contracts for hedging purposes in relation to sales or proposed sales of dairy produce by the ADC. Until recently a view had apparently been taken that such contracts were an integral part of the sale transaction and were thus automatically excluded from the operation of section 25. Recent legal advice has, however, concluded that futures contracts are quite separate from the sale contract and thus technically fall within section 25. Since it is necessary to act very quickly when entering futures contracts for hedging purposes and it is quite possible for delays, at times, to attend to the ministerial approval process, it is proposed to specifically remove such contracts from the operation of section 25. The second class of contracts proposed to be removed from the ambit of section 25 is contracts entered into by the ADC pursuant to the Dairy Produce Sales Promotion Act 1958, that is, the Sales Promotion Act. Legal advice has been obtained which states that while it is not clear that section 25 of the Act applies to contracts entered into under the Sales Promotion Act it would be prudent to assume that it does.

Given that the ADC's promotional activities centre on campaigns mounted by advertising agencies retained by the ADC to act on its behalf there are practical difficulties in identifying specific contractual arrangements to place before the Minister for approval. Further, it seems unreasonable that action specifically authorised under one Act should be subject to conditions in another. In this context it is relevant that the ADC's promotional plans for each year are fully discussed with and, in effect, approved by the industry. The new section 25 will also raise the threshold value of contracts, above which ministerial approval is required, from $100,000 to $500,000. The increase in the threshold amount is consistent with current practice in respect of similar provisions in legislation establishing statutory authorities, as is the provision for a higher amount to be prescribed. In the absence of the latter provision it would be necessary for the Parliament itself to amend the legislation to increase the threshold amount as money values changed over time. By providing for higher amounts to be set by regulation parliamentary time will be saved. At the same time the opportunity for parliamentary scrutiny will still be provided. There are no financial implications for the Commonwealth arising from the amendments.
I commend the Bill to honourable members.
