TALK.START.PARA: —Before the debate is resumed, I remind the House that it has been agreed that the Northern Prawn Fishery Voluntary Adjustment Scheme Loan Guarantee Bill 1985 will be debated concurrently with the Foreign Fishing Boats Levy Amendment Bill 1985 and the Fisheries Agreements (Payments) Amendment Bill 1985.

DEBATE.TITLE: NORTHERN PRAWN FISHERY VOLUNTARY ADJUSTMENT SCHEME LOAN GUARANTEE BILL 1985

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gayler Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My comments in relation to the Northern Prawn Fishery Voluntary Adjustment Scheme Loan Guarantee Bill, the Foreign Fishing Boats Levy Amendment Bill and the Fisheries Agreements (Payments) Amendment Bill will be brief.

SPEECH.PARA: In presenting the 1985-86 Budget in August of this year, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) indicated to the House the concern of the Government about the economic difficulties faced by many of our primary producers, having regard particularly to the extremely poor international commodity prices flowing from subsidised over-production from our major competitors. He went on to indicate that as a result of these difficulties the Government would introduce a number of important initiatives to assist the rural sector. From 1 November 1985 currently eligible primary producers will receive a full rebate of the excess on diesel fuel. This initiative encompasses the fishing industry. The rural sector, including the fishing industry, will be paying 2.4c a litre less for diesel fuel from the date I have previously mentioned.

It is interesting to note that appropriation for the fishing industry for the 1985-86 financial year will increase by a mammoth 50 per cent to $21,867.00. Measures in the Budget included, as I have previously mentioned, the rebate on the diesel fuel excess at a total cost of some $5m to $6m, adjustment assistance of some $3m, a loan guarantee of some $5m and appropriation of $0.4m for fisheries management and $5.3m for fisheries research. Commonwealth funding for fisheries research will be a record in 1985-86 and will be directed at those projects underpinning the long term viability and development of the industry.

I now turn specifically to the Bills presently before the House and refer initially to the Foreign Fishing Boats Levy Amendment Bill. This Bill amends the Foreign Fishing Boats Levy Act 1981 and has two purposes: Firstly, to provideclear legal authority for collecting the amounts specified in an agreement between Australia and a person other than a foreign government whereby Australia agrees to licence foreign boats for fishing in Australian fishing zones in consideration of payment of the amount to Australia; and secondly, to empower the Minister to declare by notice that foreign fishing boats operate by, for or on the instructions of an Australian for the benefit of Australia as a boat in respect of which the principal Act does not impose a levy.

The second Bill to which I refer is the Fisheries Agreements (Payments) Amendment Bill. This Bill amends the Fisheries Agreements Payments Act 1981 in parallel with the amendments proposed under the Foreign Fishing Boats Levy Amendment Bill. This Bill authorises the refusal of a licence for foreign boats unless the amounts specified in the agreement between Australia and a foreign government with respect to the operations of these boats in the Australian fishing zone have been paid to Australia.

The purpose of the Northern Prawn Fishery Voluntary Adjustment Scheme Loan Guarantee Bill 1985 is to authorise the Treasurer, on behalf of the Commonwealth and at the request of the Queensland Fish Management Authority, to guarantee the repayment of, and the payment of interest on, one or more loans made to the Queensland Fish Management Authority to provide initial funding for the northern prawn fishery voluntary adjustment scheme. The third Bill relates specifically to the Northern Prawn Fishery which encompasses waters off both the States of Queensland and Western Australia and the Northern Territory. It is a significant fishery and, as in the case of a number of Australia's major fisheries, it has been overexploited and economically overcapitalised, leading to social and financial instability within the fishery and allied industries. It is with this in mind that the Government has enhanced programs to redress this situation by developing measures to increase industry efficiency and assist in stock recovery.

For some years the northern prawn fishery has been characterised by excess fishing capacity and low economic results and the adjustment scheme is a major component of the new management arrangements for the fishery. The main objective of the plan is to achieve a significant recovery from the depressed economic conditions which have affected the fisheries in recent years. The program has been devised with full consultation and importantly the full agreement of the industry. The setting up of a committee to implement the plan involving Commonwealth and State governments and the industry indicates the benefits that can flow from the co-operation of State and Federal governments with industry.

Although production from the northern prawn fishery is valued at about $80m per annum, the presence of substantial excess fishing capacity has resulted in the fishery becoming unprofitable in the existing economic environment.

The introduction of the scheme will allow fishermen wishing to leave the fishery to be compensated for the surrender of their rights within the fishery. To maximise the early impact of the voluntary adjustment scheme, arrangements are being made with a commercial lender to provide initial funding by one or more loans of which the Bill guarantees repayment. It is significant that the full expense involved in implementing the scheme will be met by the industry and the risk of the government having to honour the guarantee will be extremely small.

As I indicated at the outset, the initiatives of the Federal Government in the 1985-86 Budget have been a great boost to the fishing industry generally. I commend the Government's decision to provide a grant of $3m a year for the three years 1985-86 to 1987-88 for adjustment assistance. Importantly, the appropriation of $3m in the 1985-86 grant is to go totally to the voluntary adjustment scheme for the Northern Prawn Fishery. Of course in the part of Australia that I represent there is also the East Coast Trawl Fishery and it is noteworthy that the product emanating from that fishery and the Northern Prawn Fishery contributed to Cairns being the largest fishing port in Australia in terms of revenue. It is a vital industry for the future development of far north Queensland and I welcome the initiatives taken by the Government and in particular by the caring Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin).

The Labor Government has taken a positive approach to the development of the industry in far north Queensland as a whole and particularly the Torres Strait Fishery. The appropriation of well in excess of $1m in the 1985-86 Budget for the further development of the Torres Strait Fishery is welcomed in that part of Australia. I have spoken in this place previously on the Torres Strait Fishery and the agreement reached between Australia and Papua New Guinea in relation to it. It is my belief that with controlled management and development it will become a major fishery within Australia and I welcome- I know that I speak on behalf of the Torres Strait Islands people-the continued interest and concern shown by the Australian Government in the management of that fishery. During the next three years the Federal Government will inject $2.7m into the development and management of the fishery. Under that agreement the Commonwealth and Queensland Governments will then share costs. Recurrent costs will be met on an equal basis by both State and Federal governments and they will also share the replacement of capital items in future years.

I know of the interest and concern shown by island leaders such as George Mye, who is Chairman of the Island Consultative Committee, and Nelson Billy, who is the Chairman of the Warraber Island Council. I have been going there for some three years and every time I sit under the wongi tree with Nelson Billy, the first matter he raises is the future management and development of the fisheries in the Torres Strait Islands. In fact all the Torres Strait Islands chairmen from the eastern group show a real interest in and concern for the controlled management and development of this fishery. It is an area that the people have fished for thousands of years and they do not want to see their fishing areas and fishing beds destroyed by over-capitalisation of the area. I refer also to other island leaders such as the chairman of the Yorke Islands community, Joey Moseby, who always speaks of the interest of the islanders in their fishing industry. I was very pleased that the Federal Minister for Primary Industry was able recently to go to the Yorke Islands and speak to the islanders about the industry generally.

In conclusion, I mention two other island chairmen who have similar concerns about the industry in the islands. I speak here of all the islands but I have particularly mentioned the eastern group because that is where most of the trawlfishing in Torres Strait goes on. I refer of course to James Sallee, who is the chairman of the Murray Island community, and Murray Lui, the chairman of Coconut Island community. It is because of the attitude of the present Minister for Primary Industry and the Government that industries such as the fishing industry have in place proper and realistic management programs. These Bills will ensure that those management programs will continue for the benefit of the industry in the long term.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I would like to make a few comments before we complete the second reading debate on the Northern Prawn Fishery Voluntary Adjustment Scheme Loan Guarantee Bill, the Foreign Fishing Boats Levy Amendment Bill and the Fisheries Agreements (Payments) Amendment Bill. The debate has been most constructive. These measures are not being opposed and many of the comments made indicate the close interest taken by various honourable members in Australia's fishing industries. The honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Gayler) takes a close interest in all fisheries matters and has quite a few notches in his belt in terms of dealing with the problems that have arisen for the northern prawn fishery.

SPEECH.PARA: The northern prawn fishery adjoins the west side of Cape York Peninsula and there are something like 240 to 290 boats in that fishery. The east coast prawn fishery probably has around 500 boats working north and east of Cairns. In respect of the Torres Strait fishery, we are negotiating with the Queensland Government and the Papua New Guinea Government arrangements that are quite unique. We are dealing with another sovereign Government-Queensland-and then dealing with another totally different country, Papua New Guinea. We are working together there with peoples who have lived in that part of the world for a very long time and we are trying to preserve the fisheries for those people because fish are virtually the only resource that those islands have. As the honourable member commented, I was recently on the York Islands and I got a further understanding there of the situation.

The Queensland Minister and I have authority over the Torres Strait protected zone and that is a splendid example of the Queensland Government working with the Commonwealth Government without any problems. We are both putting money in. Goodness gracious, the fishermen associated with the safe anchorage scheme and fuel prices all have cards with their name, photographs and a number on them and the Queensland Government has not taken any objection to that. That is why I am staggered when the Queensland Government cannot talk with the dreaded Commonwealth about the sugar industry. This loan guarantee is a perfect example of the Commonwealth and Queensland governments working together harmoniously in the interests of the people we jointly represent. It is a sterling example of what can be achieved when the nonsense of party politics does not intrude into what is a straightforward arrangement for the people we all represent.

This Government has a good record on fisheries management and people have commented on the fisheries plans we are now putting into place for the northern prawn fishery, the Torres Strait fishery, the east coast and south east coast trawl fisheries, the southern bluefin tuna fishery and the shark and scallop fisheries. There were enormous problems in the negotiations and discussions on all these fisheries and the scallops fishery is the most recent example of great tension. All this has been caused mainly because of over-capitalisation and over-exploitation of the fisheries. We first have to learn the biology of a fishery and then work out management plans. Eventually we will get on to finance and some of the other aspects of administration on which the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt) touched. The problem with the southern bluefin tuna industry was partially caused in earlier years when too many boats were allowed into the fishery.

The really good thing to happen recently was that in July Cabinet agreed to the Commonwealth proceeding with the implementation of the fisheries element of the off-shore constitutional settlement. This will enable the Commonwealth to resume negotiations with the States with a view to implementing formal legal Commonwealth-State arrangements for managing particular fisheries under a single law and exercising executive functions under that law. In other words, we will clean all this up and we will be able to move on to the business of Commonwealth and State licences. I will touch on that in a moment.

The northern prawn fishery is probably one of our best fisheries. It has a very high income but, as I have said, it is over-exploited. There are too many boats in it. There has been some misunderstanding about what this loan guarantee is about. It is just to guarantee the $5m which will be raised by the Queensland Fish Marketing Authority. It is the most competent body to raise that money. True, it took a year to get this scheme in place, but this is the way we are handling it. A voluntary levy is to be applied to the fishery. With the $5m loan guarantee and the voluntary levy we should be in a position to start removing effort from the fishery . The first tenders were recently called to get units of fishing effort out of that fishery. In response to the case put to us by the fishing industry on fuel costs, we were also able to put some $9m back into that industry for adjustment purposes-$3m a year for the northern fisheries in general.

Comments have been made about the fact that we are now trying to extract from the industry some of the costs of management of these fisheries. We will make these fisheries very viable and profitable. When one sees people paying $3,000 a tonne to get entitlement to southern bluefin tuna and one talks about a management levy of $15 a tonne, one sees how much money is potentially in these fisheries once we get mangement plans in place. So it is with the northern prawn fishery-once fishing effort is removed, once people do not have to apply so much power, use so much fuel or put on so many nets, we will find that fishery will be in a very profitable situation. Under those circumstances it is reasonable enough that the fishery should pay back to the public some of the measures of assistance that the Government-or the public-is giving to it.

There is a lot more money in this Budget for the fishing industry. I will not go through it in detail; other members on this side of the House have touched on that point. I would stress that some $5.3m has been allocated to fisheries research and another $0.4m to fisheries management. In addition there is the adjustment assistance of $3m which I have already mentioned. The rebate of the diesel fuel excise will give the industry something like $5m to $6m. So we are looking after these fisheries and doing what we can to help them.

The matter of fuel costs is a very big issue and many people have touched on it. Everyone acknowledges the importance of fuel costs to the fishing industry and we note the magnitude of the fuel price rises that have occurred since 1 January this year. But these cost increases must be seen in perspective. The $19.9m estimated annual increase in fuel costs to fishing right across the board represents only 4.5 per cent of the industry's gross value of production. Most of this increase reflects movements in the exchange rate affecting the import parity price of crude oil. These movements in exchange rates can be expected to benefit the industry's revenues in Australian dollars. In mid-May 1985 the Australian dollar had depreciated by 23 per cent against the United States dollar and 16 per cent on a trade-weighted index basis since the floating of the Australian dollar in December 1983. Since 31 January 1985 the Australian dollar has depreciated by 14.6 per cent against the United States dollar and 15.7 per cent against the yen. According to the May 1985 Quarterly Review of the Rural Economy, the publication of the Bureau of Agricultural Economics, this substantial depreciation was expected to result in significant increases in export prices received by the fishing industry and improve the position of the industry in competing against imports on the local market.

It is alleged that Japanese buyers have partially discounted their prices to reflect the depreciation of the Australian dollar and I think that that is conceded. However, no evidence has been produced that recent price adjustments have involved any more than normal responses to changing demand and supply conditions. Even if Japanese buyers did attempt to adjust their prices to Australian costs, this cuts both ways and they could be expected to make upward adjustments for increases in costs, such as increased fuel costs. Even if allowance is made for some reduction in export prices and for other offsetting factors, such as possible forward exchange hedgings and repayments on borrowing denominated in foreign currencies, it seems unlikely that the resultant increase in revenues to the industry from the depreciation would be any where near as low as the 4.5 per cent of gross value of production represented by the increase in fuel costs. In short, there appears to be a substantial net gain to the industry from these combined effects of the depreciation and the fuel cost increases.

Australia, along with the United States and Canada, has the lowest pricing structure for petroleum products in Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries because of the relatively low level of excise on refined products. The introduction of a free market for crude oil which is currently being considered by the Government would be expected to place further downward pressure on fuel prices, particularly in northern Australia through increased opportunities for the import of the refined product. The Government has sent a reference to the Industries Assistance Commission on the taxation of petroleum products. This is an appropriate forum for considering the non-rebatable excise on diesel fuel. I make those points to put this matter in some perspective. That is to say that with the increase in the fuel price as a result of the drop in the dollar there was very much an offsetting factor.

The honourable member for Gwydir mentioned the question of joint venture fishing in northern waters. I make this point again because it is always contested in the Northern Territory by some of the fishermen there. They claim that they are not consulted or that their industry is being affected. Both the joint ventures we have in the north were developed in accordance with existing policy which had been established in consultation with industry representatives. Far from discouraging the entry of Australian fishermen into previously unexploited fisheries or those only exploited by foreigners, the purpose of joint ventures is to promote such participation while at the same time meeting our obligations under the Law of the Sea Convention to make surplus fisheries resources avaiable to foreign fishermen.

At no time have I been provided with evidence that the pelagic and demersal resources of the north were about to the exploited by Australian fishermen on a scale which would warrant the total exclusion of foreign fishing. Given these circumstances, there are two alternatives: Foreigners can be allowed access in return for payment of a fee directly into Commonwealth revenue; or they can be permitted access under joint ventures which require a range of benefits designed to facilitate Australian participation, such as replacement of foreign with Australian-owned vessels, purchase of fish from Australians and use of shore-based facilities. It is only since joint ventures have been introduced in the north that Australian fishermen have commenced to operate on any scale in the pelagic fishery in conjunction with one of the joint venture companies. If the benefits which a joint venture company has contracted to provide are not forthcoming, I have the power to refuse to re-issue licences or, ultimately, to cancel the agreement itself.

I wish to respond to a few points which were raised quite responsibly by the honourable member for Gwydir. He asked why the Queensland Fish Management Authority, had been selected to administer the voluntary adjustment scheme rather than the Australian Fisheries Service. I touched on this briefly a moment ago. The Queensland Fish Management Authority will administer the borrowing of funds for which the Bill provides a Commonwealth guarantee. This is a convenient arrangement because there is no industry organisation with the necessary financial strength or legal status. If the Australian Fisheries Service were to become the borrower it would require statutory powers to do so. The Queensland Fish Management Authority already has appropriate statutory powers. When I took this issue to the Cabinet just over a year ago, it was decided that we would try to get the money off the Budget and go through some independent organisation. The Queensland Fish Management Authority seemed to be the most relevant body. The Queensland Government and the Fish Management Authority were both very co-operative in this matter because most of the fishermen in the north are based in Queensland.

This is a loan guarantee Bill. The Government is not providing a $5m loan, it is merely guaranteeing loans borrowed from commercial sources and to be repaid by the industry by way of the levy. A voluntary levy is being collected as well, so this provides catalyst money or seed money, if I can put it that way. Meanwhile, we have the additional $3m which will go to the industry for adjustment and again, with all that money available we should be able to get effort out of that fishery and restore it very quickly to profitability.

The honourable member for Gwydir also raised the question of foreign fishing access fees. The claim was made that there is a need to revise the purpose for which these foreign access fees are used. In other words, the money should be paid into a trust fund for the benefit of the industry and this would aid adjustment. I was enjoined to challenge the Treasury views about hypothecation, but I will not open up the debate with all that that implies. As a general rule all revenue goes into Consolidated Revenue and funds are appropriated by the budgetary process in accordance with policies and priorities. Considerable funds were allocated to the fishing industry this year, especially for adjustment assistance. I think we all know the arguments about hypothecation but when we are getting so much money from foreign joint ventures, this is a question that fishermen constantly ask. No Ministers seem to be able, not so much to win the argument as to overcome the rationality in all that is associated with hypothecation. But as the honourable member for Gwydir pointed out, the present Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) has had some success in getting some funds earmarked. All Ministers use this sort of example as a means of bidding for more money in a very tight budgetary situation.

The honourable member for Gwydir also referred to the financial impost on industry of the administrative burden created by the need to have Commonwealth and State licences. The decision to proceed with the fisheries element of the Off-shore Constitutional Settlement should, in time, settle most of this. The Commonwealth really only puts on one licence. It is a problem with multi-species fisheries, and some States have been regulation mad; but the aim of this Off-shore Constitutional Settlement is to rationalise the jurisdictional arrangements and the associated licensing problems by permitting the Commonwealth and the States to agree on the administration of a fishery under a single law. As we have overlapping fisheries due to species mix and we would need to have fracture zones between some fisheries-one cannot draw fences on the ocean-this is a very complex situation. Negotiations with the States are in progress, and the industry is being consulted. The Commonwealth Government removed the requirement that individual fishermen should be licensed; only master fishermen and boats are now licensed by the Commonwealth.

I conclude on the matter of the borrowing agent and the whole question of of the Queensland authority acting as our agent. The State fisheries agencies themselves have undertaken day to day administration of Commonwealth fisheries requirements under a reimbursement program for the last 30 years. Any other arrangement would be a duplication of resources that would not be cost effective. So again we see the advantage of the intermeshing of the Off-shore Constitutional Settlement with this arrangement of the Commonwealth paying for management. The advantage in having the Queensland Fish Management Authority administer the borrowing of funds for the northern prawn fishery voluntary adjustment scheme is that the Authority already has appropriate statutory powers which the Australian Fisheries Service does not. Also, the QFMA is directly involved with the Commonwealth and relevant State agencies in the management of the northern prawn fishery and has a good understanding of the fishery's problems and the remedies being used to overcome them. In other words, my officials work very closely with the relevant officer in Queensland, Mr Dave Mitchell, who is very much au fait with the northern prawn fishery. Decisions about the administration of the northern prawn fishery voluntary adjustment scheme will be taken by me on the advice of the Committee referred to in the circulated explanatory memorandum on the Bill.

These Bills represent more progress in the management of our fisheries. As I say, the prime aim of all this is to make quite sure that our fisheries return to a profitable state, that the biology of the fisheries is taken into account in management plans, and that we get the proper liaison and effective administration between the Commonwealth and the State governments.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

How can anybody get ahead? Moreover, how can anybody get started in our community nowadays? Interest rates, the availability of finance, labour and government costs and charges are prohibitive. The major problems facing this country are, in my view: Interest rates, labour costs, government costs and charges which involve state and local government as well as the Federal Government-taxation and inflation. I add to that list our declining position in international trade. The end result, the bottom line, is that we will continue to have totally unacceptable levels of unemployment, particularly youth unemployment, so long as we have a government which does not regard the stimulation and protection of the private sector as its number one priority. That cliche `priority one', which this Government is hanging its hat on to assist the young unemployed in this country, amounts to nothing unless the first priority is growth and thereby job opportunities in the private sector.

At Question Time today the Treasurer dismissed the discussion of the topic of interest rates as being nothing more than a politically opportunistic attack by the Opposition. In reality interest rates are a tremendous burden on small businessmen, the self-employed and farmers. During Question Time today we had the extraordinary scene of a Treasurer more or less abdicating responsibility for the high level of interest rates in this country; a total abrogation of his and his Government's responsibility to ensure that the proper economic climate exists.

TALK.START.PARA: —Too remote from the real world.

—As the honourable member for Mitchell interjects, the Treasurer is too remote from the real world. Hence I invite the Treasurer or any other member of the Government to visit, with my colleagues, our electorates where day in and day out people come into our offices and detail their financial state and further, and of more interest to this chamber, detail the reasons why they are in an economically depressed position.

SPEECH.PARA: There are a number of other matters which this Parliament should concern itself with other than interest rates, but before going on to those I wish to stress that the prime bank rate in Australia is presently hovering around the 17 per cent mark. We have a government borrowing heavily in the market-place, thereby squeezing out private borrowings. Moreover, I do not think it can be questioned any longer that the Government, together with the Reserve Bank of Australia, through various complex monetary controls, is forcing up interest rates to ensure the value of the Australian dollar. Without such controls I have no doubt whatsoever that the value of the Australian dollar would fall dramatically below its present rate of 67c-odd in the United States dollar to, as startling as it may sound, 50c. That is the judgment of the international financial community-that our performance on any indicator, in comparison with the performance of our major trading partners, is woeful. It is even more woeful when compared with the performance of our near neighbours within the Asian-Pacific basin. In that tax to be brought down by the Treasurer the family home will once again be exempt from taxation. Profit gained on the sole family home will be exempt. Finally, I turn to the matter of inflation. As if the crushing burdens of interest rates, labour costs, government costs and charges and a declining share of world trade were not sufficient, we have a projected rate of inflation of at least 8 per cent for the next financial year. If we compare that rate to the rates of our major trading partners, we see that we are further disadvantaged in our relationship with them. The end result is that the commitment to reducing unemployment and to giving our young unemployed a future in our great country is significantly reduced because of the blinkered, ideological, economic decisions taken by this Government in conjunction with the ACTU.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent Mr L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In discussing the 1985 Budget in the debate on the Appropriation Bill (No. 1), I commence my remarks with a quote from one of the articles in the Sydney Morning Herald of 21 August. The very first paragraph sums up the Budget as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: The Hawke Government has pitched heavily for economic responsibility in a Budget which includes a large cut in the deficit and emphasis on wage restraint, but no income tax cuts.
My Press release issued on the night of the Budget Speech of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) stated in part:
This is a Budget that good conservatives can only dream of.

Of course, my comment came easily as I had watched the faces of the Opposition members across the chamber. The faces of that aimless bunch across the way were rather grim. I could read the thoughts on their faces and I later heard them expressing those thoughts to each other in the corridors. They were saying to each other: `When we were in government why didn't we have the guts to do it?'.

I for one welcome this Budget. It is a responsible Budget, and, if anything, it is too responsible. It should be a watershed in our Government's responses to neo-conservative pressures of cutting expenses and programs. From now on we should baldly reject demands for smaller government. Those demands mean smaller social welfare expenditure, less services to the Australian people as a whole, less for our youth and less investment in our future. The neo-conservative demand for cutting expenses on services to the community comes from representatives of big mining companies, big multinationals, and is echoed by small business. These demands come from business quarters which do not contribute their fair share to our tax revenue. It is a gross impertinence from the Hugh Morgans and their like to tell us how to spend government revenue when they do so much to evade it, and contribute so little to it. It is time that this Government told those business rascals that only those who contribute a fair share in their taxes will have the privilege of saying how it shall be distributed. The revenue collected from the ordinary Australian taxpayer should be used for his future welfare and not for subsidies to the rich tax evaders in the cities or in the country.

I remind my colleagues and the Government that in future our duty should be to serve directly our natural constituency-the ordinary wage and salary earners of Australia. We have done enough for big business. We have restored the economy of this country which was in ruins when we took over from that inept conservative bunch opposite. We have lifted the profits of businesses and companies to a higher level than it was under the seven years of the Fraser-Howard Government. Now it is time that we gave back a fair share of revenue to those who honestly contributed to it-the people of Australia. Unless we start in earnest to serve our constituency-the people who put us in government-we will lose their support and our self respect.

This brings me to a matter to which I would like to devote the rest of my time and to draw to the attention of both sides of the House and the Australian public at large. I want to focus my remarks on the proposed introduction of identity cards. The proposal to introduce an identification card system and computerised data bank on individuals is a sinister attack on our civil liberties by the bureaucracy. Even though the proposal was publicly put by our mild mannered Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) it first appeared in some obscure Treasury papers, nudging the Treasurer to use it as a means to mop up the undeclared interest on small savings of Australian wage and salary earners. It was of no concern to the small minds of the bureaucracy that, in the process of mopping up the petty amounts from the average Aussies who are reluctant to pay taxes on inflation, by the use of ID cards, our traditional liberties and our way of life which respects the privacy of the individual may be jeopardised. Since Federation, except for a short time during the war we have got on well without ID cards.

Australia is a vast continent with a small population, and our identities can be easily established without the introduction of internal passports. During the two centuries of our existence on this continent we have developed a great respect for the individual. In most other countries of the world, including developed Western countries, the individual, unless he or she belongs to the elite, is treated as part of the mob by the bureaucracy and the officials. Unlike the rest of the world, probably as a result of our pioneering era, we in Australia still treat the individual with respect.

I first came across the problem of individual identification at about the age of seven. I was born and brought up in Yugoslavia. My father was born in Yugoslavia and so was my grandfather and great-grandfather. When King Alexander of Yugoslavia and the French Foreign Minister, Monsieur Bartoux, were assasinated inMarseilles in 1934 the situation in Yugoslavia became suddenly tense. Many people of various minorities were expelled from the country. I recall the story in my family that my father was summoned by the police chief of our small country town where we lived, and asked to prove his identity and citizenship. My father told the chief, whom he had known for many years, that he had no intention of providing any proof and if the chief doubted his identity or citizenship, he was the cop and it was his job to prove otherwise.

This story from my childhood indicates to me that our individual privacy and our liberties depend on our willingness to defend them. Later, my distaste of being branded and numbered grew even more when, during the war, ID cards helped the Germans to round up the Jews and, after the war, when some of my friends who survived the Holocaust returned from Dachau and Auschwitz and showed me their numbers tattooed on their forearms. This is only an example of the extremes identification can be taken to, and of the extremes to which human freedom and dignity can be trampled on by the authorities. I mention this only as an extreme. I am not suggesting for a moment that such a use of an identification card would ever be contemplated by the Australian bureaucracy. Since then, I travelled around half the world to settle in a country where one can bring up one's family in peace and freedom. I settled here 31 years ago with my wife and son, who was then three years old. Since then I have learned not only to love this country and its people, but to love the Australian tradition of freedom, civil liberties and respect for the individual and his or her right to privacy.

I vowed then to do my utmost to defend our liberties and our freedoms. When I mentioned the brutal extremes of the nazi era, I did so only as an example to show to what dehumanising extremes identification and branding of people can be taken. Not for one moment did I wish to suggest that such a use of ID cards would ever be contemplated in Australia. However, the uses of such a universal identification system tend to proliferate.

Social security numbers were first introduced in the United States of America in 1935. Since then the use of a person's social security number as both a means of identification and as a method of collecting data is now much greater than could ever have been envisaged in 1935. The social security number is now used when opening bank accounts and this is then reported to the Internal Revenue Service, the Taxation Office. The number is now widely used to check tax records and for other purposes. There is no doubt that once the ID card is introduced it can be used for any purpose, legitimate or sinister, depending on the government of the day or, what is worse, on the bureaucracy, which already advocates its introduction for the sake of efficiency. I ask the house: Efficiency for what?

It is efficiency in keeping a record on an individual, on every individual, a record of his bank accounts, a record on his movements and probably tomorrow a record on his private life. We have seen how limited approvals for phone tapping have proliferated. People's private phone conversations are being illegally recorded. Yet that was not the intention of the legislation! Because of the fear that public opinion may turn against the introduction of the card, the Government was advised to keep a low profile on this issue.

A number or an ID card as such may not mean much. It may be neither good nor bad, but its use and potential abuse by Big Brother is what makes it dangerous and sinister. But even to be a number for official purposes is having a dehumanising effect. If that is extended by the requirement to carry one's number, and produce one's card on request by officials, it becomes the first stage in the destruction of the liberty of the individual. I had the experience of seeing how, even in democratic countries such as Israel and Italy, anyone who packs a pistol can board a bus or train and require passengers to produce their identity cards. I expect that I am not the only member of this House who has come across such incidents when travelling overseas.

I, for one, do not accept the assurances of officialdom that we will not be required to carry our cards with us and I warn the people that, once such a card system is introduced, the occasions for its use will proliferate. Every Government institution will find it necessary for the card to be produced and when it is produced the computer data will be updated. Any safeguards written into the legislation will not be worth the ink used, as the bureaucrats will argue that efficiency comes first, civil liberties and privacy second. Even now before its introduction the ID card is hailed as the universal panacea. According to its supporters it will cure all illnesses of our society from acquired immune deficiency syndrome to illegal immigration. As I mentioned, originally the ID cards were proposed by the Treasury to mop up the small savings of ordinary people who have a couple of thousand dollars tucked away for a rainy day in saving deposits. But since then it has come to be believed by many that the card will stop organised crime, social security fraud, illegal immigration, medifraud and many other unsavoury practices that we believe are rife in our community.

All the ills of our society are no worse than the ills in those countries where ID cards operate. If anything, we are better off, as far as crime is concerned, than many other countries with which we compare ourselves. To illustrate this, I feel much safer walking at night in Melbourne than in New York. As for using an identification system to prevent illegal immigration, let me say that there are over five million illegal immigrants in the US, while we estimate the number in Australia to be 50,000. Would anyone suggest that if we introduce ID cards we will catch and deport 50,000 people who may have settled here without permission in the last 20 years? To prevent future arrivals remaining here illegally we do not need ID cards. We need instead a computerised visa system which will enable immigration authorities to keep a check on overstayed visitors.

The Department is of the opinion that the existence of ID cards might exacerbate the degree of social security fraud. Forged cards will unlock the whole system and in a way forgeries will legalise and perpetuate the fraud. The existence of ID cards will not assist the Department of Social Security in its major problem of people supplying false information about their income levels and domestic circumstances, nor will ID cards help to catch petty thieves who steal pension cheques from letter-boxes. There are other methods of reducing social security fraud-for example, direct crediting of payments to the bank accounts of recipients. But of course there is still the contention that ID cards will catch tax evaders.

Let me deal with that matter. While it may force people to declare the interest received on their small savings it certainly will not stop bottom of the harbour evasions, dry Slutzkin or wet Slutzkin or any other big evasion schemes that cost the community not millions, but billions, of dollars. ID cards will not make big business pay its fair share of taxes, nor will it make small business declare profits. There are hardly any corner shops in the breadth of this country whose owners pay their fair share of taxes. They seem to live from losses, and live very well indeed. The introduction of ID cards will not force the owners of small businesses to pay taxes; it will not make an iota of difference to our tax collection from big and small businesses. It will not stop medifraud; it also will not stop solicitors helping themselves to their clients' money. Only a few months ago it was repoted that $16m was missing from lawyers trust funds in New South Wales alone. Will ID cards stop this dishonesty? Will they stop organised crime? Of course they will not. They will instead introduce a new, profitable line in to the stock of organised crime-the manufacture and sale of false ID cards. The 1,000 new bureaucrats who would be recruited to administer the ID cards would be much more gainfully employed if they were trained as tax investigators so that they could check the false figures of those businesses that show constant losses in their tax figures.

The fact is that the ID card is not directed against organised crime, big tax evaders or sophisticated fraud. According to an article in the National Times of 5 September it is directed against pensioners who work part time to supplement their meagre pension, the students on the tertiary education assistance scheme who work the odd day in a child care centre, a media organisation or a nursing home under a false name, and others who are trying to earn a few dollars more than is the permitted income under the rules of the Department of Social Security. While the card will do little to rectify the ills of our society, it will do enormous harm to our way of life and our civil liberties. As Arthur Horner put it is his article in the Melbourne Age of 20 August 1985:

And, let's face it, when in a democracy you need a bit of card to say not that you can drive a car or are credit worthy but simply that you exist, and have a number to prove it, it's time to get a bit concerned.
While such a card could be very handy for those of us who don't know who we are, the rest of us should take a good hard look at it-before it happens.
Accordingly, I call on the Treasurer to think, and think again, before it happens. I remind the House of what the seventeenth century philosopher Descartes said. He said:
Ego cogito, ergo sum.
Translated, that means:
I think, therefore I am.

Instead, the Treasurer seems to be saying: `I have a plastic card, therefore I exist.' Of course, he may not need to think if bureaucracy does that for him. I consider that the introduction of ID cards into Australia is the first stage in the destruction of the liberty of the individual and I reject it. I know that I will not be alone. I am sure that the thinking people of our country will reject the card with the same vehemence they showed when they rejected conscription. I have faith in our youth. I know that thinking Australians will reject the introduction of ID cards, and so will this House. However, if ever they are introduced I will publicly burn mine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —This third Keating Budget has failed the Australian people essentially on two grounds. Firstly, it is little more than a scissors and paste job based upon dubious economic assumptions. It tells us something of the Government's plans for expenditure. It tells us nothing of the Government's plans for revenue or taxation. In regard to the latter matter, in particular, we have yet to wait to see the outcome of the July National Taxation Summit, the results of which I hope the Treasurer (Mr Keating) will bring to this chamber later this month. Secondly, the Budget clearly lacks an underlying strategy for the growth of our industries, improvement in productivity and the willingness to encourage the entrepreneurial spirit to take the risks and give it a go.

SPEECH.PARA: I find this Budget to be a pathetic response to the obvious social and economic problems facing Australia today. The Hawke socialist Government has made no attempt to introduce major structural reforms, nor does it hold out any real hope for the long term economic growth of this country, placed as it is within the fastest growing region of the world. Not one near neighbour to our north-all of which are members of the Association of South East Asian Nations-has a rate of economic growth of less than 5 or 6 per cent over recent years. By comparison, even under this so-called illustrious Government, Australia's record remains pathetic.

The Australian economy needed, above all, major structural reform. Those who believe, as presumably do members of the socialist Left at least, that socialist governments are the great reformers should note the unwillingness of this Government to confront the hard decisions which must be taken if the Australian people are to continue to enjoy high living standards. These can be achieved only by developing an internationally competitive economy. The alternative, which is plain for all to see, is that Australia will continue to be plagued by booms and busts and regular recessions, as we have seen in the past, together with high unemployment, serious and rising public sector debt and a balance of trade which clearly points to the continuing economic decline of this nation. That is the structure. That is the economic environment in which this Budget was put together for the financial year 1985-86.

Various comments have been made by my colleagues as to the fact that the Budget represents nothing more than a half-baked Budget and so forth. As I said, we know little about the tax implications of these programs because they were not contained in the Budget. We have yet to see the outcome of the White Paper and what elements of option A will become part of the taxation base of this economy. While the Government may look upon the results of recent opinion polls as evidence of public support for the Budget, I strongly suggest that that may well not be the situation come the end of this month when people are made to realise that all is not silver nor are all linings of Budgets meant to be golden.

In addition, we have the problem of the attitude of this Government to wages policy. The Treasurer proclaimed in this house and elsewhere his ability to stand up to the Australian Council of Trade Unions. He was going to deliver wage discounting. There was even a comment to that effect in his Budget Speech to this House. However, under closer examination by the Opposition it became more than abundantly clear that the Treasurer was less than totally committed to the comments that were contained in his Budget Speech. He failed to spell out in the Budget an unambiguous commitment that the Government would do all in its power to achieve full discounting for the devaluation. He failed to make any reference in the Budget to the ACTU's 4 per cent productivity case or the push for superannuation payments. In the last few hours we have learnt that the ACTU has now endorsed the Government's strategy, which, in effect, means that at the current national wage case hearing no attempt will be made to reduce the impact of the devaluation in terms of wages and that the full consumer price index flow on will take place during this period.

While some statements have been made that things will change at the next such Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission hearing, the simple realities are that every time this Government goes down the road of full compensation for the CPI it is steadily but surely whittling away whatever economic advantages it claimed would come to this nation as a result of the greatest devaluation that has taken place in Australia's contemporary history. In the last 48 hours we have seen yet again the world's view and verdict of the value of the Australian dollar. We see that inexorable decline. The future of this nation is in the Government's hands, not in ours. Its economic strength is in the Government's hands. The value of the Australian dollar and the capacity of the Australian people to maintain their standards of living are very closely interwoven. As I said initially, it is on those grounds above all else that this Budget will be seen for what it is-a charade, a weak document based on dubious economic statistics and little more than hope.

Let us look at some of the disturbing realities which it contains. In 1985-86 inflation will be at least 8 per cent, almost double that of our major trading partners and one of the highest inflation rates in the entire range of member countries of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. As a result of the decision taken in the last few days by the ACTU, it is not unreasonable to suggest that it will not be 8 per cent inflation this financial year, but much closer to 10 per cent by 1986.

What about the average real increase in Government spending under the Hawke Government, something about which we have heard so much as a result of the glorious May economic statement, when we were told that overall cuts had been made to the value of $1.6 billion? Anybody who has been in government or even in opposition in recent years knows that one does not have to be a profound expert to cut back one's initial estimates of expenditure. That was the essence of what this Government did last May. It is interesting to point out that the rate of spending under the Hawke Government, even on this year's Budget, has increased by 4.9 per cent. That represents more than double the rate of average expenditure over the seven Budgets of the Fraser years.

SPEECH.PARA: We have noted in the last two days how at Question Time, when members of the Opposition have asked numerous questions of the Treasurer and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) about interest rates, they have ducked and weaved and done whatever they possibly can to avoid answering the questions. I think it is worth noting the recently released annual report of the Reserve Bank of Australia. It commented on the situation by the end of 1984-85:

Most interest rates had risen substantially, with many rates at historically high levels both absolutely and relative to the rate of inflation. The Bank's judgment is that policy at the end of the year is appropriately firm and that this policy will need to continue.

The Reserve Bank is saying that, in both real and nominal interest terms, rates are high and will remain so for some time. One of the realities of this situation is that, when we are carrying the high rates of international debt we are in Australia, it is essential that we be able to attract sufficient investment just to cover the interest bills which have already accrued on previous loans and, I might add, especially those loans incurred by the Whitlam Government back in the early to mid-1970s. That is the heritage that we are passing on to our children. It has to be borne by the next generation when we have left this place and, in due course, go on to retirement. We will see then whether this nation will be able to afford to pay the pensions which the present generation seems to take for granted.

Contrary to the Treasurer's assertion that the tax take for pay as you earn taxpayers is bud- geted to increase by 13.3 per cent, in reality, indirect taxes on cigarettes, beer, spirits, petrol and so forth will rise twice this year-in February and again in August-in accordance with the movements in the consumer price index as a result of decisions made in the first Hawke Budget. It has always amazed me how commentators on the Budget tend to imagine that, because there is not some specific mention of this each year, somehow or other the Government has suddenly found itself in a most Christian mood. The simple realities are that it is locked into CPI increases-a very profound and intelligent act as it was-as a means of increasing taxation.

Let me get back to the question of the deficit. We are told that there is a significant reduction of the deficit to $4.9 billion but the deficit outcome will be higher; it will be $5.3 billion. If wages are not discounted for the effects of devaluation, the cumulative deficit in the first three Keating Budgets will total some $20 billion. As I said earlier, that represents more than the seven Fraser Budgets of the past. In terms of Budget outlays, the Government has made much of its small increase in spending but the Budget Papers have shown us that outlays for 1985-86 are expected to increase to 29.8 per cent of gross domestic product. That represents the third highest level of Budget outlays in Australia's history, beaten only by the first two Hawke Budgets and equalled only by the last big spending Whitlam Budget. The average real increase in the first three Hawke Budgets was 4.9 per cent, which again was more than twice the average real increase in the seven Fraser Budgets.

Similarly, we were told about the $1.25 billion cut in outlays from the Forward Estimates but that has been shown for what it is. In fact, since the Forward Estimates $716m worth of extra spending has been incurred and the cuts which may have been made last May have resulted in a net cut of only $764m. However, 1986-87, the first full year of the changes, will result in an increase in spending of $169m. Surely that contrasts more than markedly with the alleged cuts offered by the Prime Minister and his vaunted Treasurer back in the so-called May mini-Budget. Nevertheless, the Commonwealth's public debt interest, which does not include States or statutory authorities, will be a massive $6,724 billion in 1985-86-an increase of over $1 billion over last year, or almost 19 per cent. If we relate that to the actual population it means that it is costing every taxpayer $20 per week to pay interest on the Government's national debt. I think the Australian people ought to consider those figures very carefully indeed because they mean that, since devaluation, the cost in interest alone has gone up some $5 billion per year. We could bear that if this nation was able to trade more and if our balance of trade was more to our favour. But the sad fact is that, despite devaluation, the balance of trade has not altered significantly in our favour.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will.

—We certainly hope it will. The honourable member for Charlton and I are at one on that point but that is precisely why the Government is wrong in going down the road of refusing to devalue wage increases for the impact of devaluation on the economy overall. If we are to open up new markets it is as clear as the eyes on the honourable member's face that we must be in a position to compete. If our cost structures are not in a competitive mode those markets will remain closed to us. Irrespective of what programs of subsidies the Government has, and irrespective of what levels of support and maintenance it may give industry, the bottom line is that the market-place will buy the product of the best quality and the greatest choice at the lowest price. It is time that the Australian people and this Labor Government in particular were prepared to live with that simple realisation. If they fail to do so they will be inexorably leading the people of this nation into a situation where we cannot possibly persist with our current standards of living and we will indeed become the poor nation of Asia.

SPEECH.PARA: For that reason the Opposition believes that the Australian economy needs major structural reform. For that reason we believe a number of major elements must be incorporated in a national strategy. They must have clear objectives. We should be directing our efforts towards greater economic flexibility and deregulation of the economy to give the private sector more expansion and more opportunities to get out and create market opportunities and jobs. We must reduce government involvement. For example, over one-third of the staff of the Department of Primary Industry are involved in meat inspection. In addition, we have the State meat inspection services and in some States local government is involved in the same activity as well.

Clearly, there is a massive need for restruc- turing and a devolution of the responsibilities between the Commonwealth and the States. We cannot control a cost factor in governmental terms while we have more than one level of government actively involved in the same area of policy. In addition, we have to reduce government involvement overall. We have to reward effort and excellence in all facets of Australian endeavour. We have to give full employment the status it deserves. As politicians we should not be ashamed to imagine that the Australian people deserve less than that. Nobody suggests that the task is easy or that the journey will be short. Let us have the courage to say to the Australian people: `You do have the right to a job provided you are also prepared to make the sacrifices which are in the national interest'. It is on that point above all that this Government has failed.

Once again in this Budget the Government has not been prepared to grasp the nettle. It has not been prepared to use it as a basis for its economic strategy. It has not been prepared to say to the Australian people: `That is our light on the hill. These are difficult decisions but they have been made and we ask you to support us'. The Government has had its chance. This is its third Budget. For the third time the opportunity to tackle the important elements of long term development for this nation, of giving Australians and future generations a role, a sense of belonging and a sense of national achievement was in its hands. As an Australian I say, with the greatest concern, that yet again this Government has failed the Australian people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maher Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Several months ago a very great educator, who lived in my electorate, died. He was actually the oldest Christian Brother in the world, Brother Creighton. The point of the story is that many of his old students from St Patrick's College, Strathfield, where he spent his teaching career, went to his funeral, as did I and many others. But, being old boys, of the school they went back to the college for a cup of tea. One of them, who is a constituent of mine, said afterwards that he was amazed at the improvements in his old school. What had been a quite run-down institution in those days, 15, 20 or more years ago, is now a splendid educational institution. That made me think that this is true. The school, without any Commonwealth funding, has been able to build a number of additions to its facilities. There is no municipal swimming pool in the area in which the school is located and it has been able to construct a swimming pool by raising money through the parents and friends, and by fund raising generally at the school. It is a very big school of over 1,000 boys.

SPEECH.PARA: The point made to me by my constituent made me think that, over the years of Federal funding of the government and non-government sector since the Whitlam initiatives, there have been amazing improvements in capital works at schools. Of course, this brings me to the appropriation for the funding of schools in our nation. I do not intend to speak entirely on capital works for schools but, in the state system, many of the schools have improved. Unfortunately at Homebush Boys High School and Burwood Primary School this was assisted by arsonists as the schools had major fires. But other state schools have improved greatly. I claimed in this House that Homebush West Primary School was, from a fabric point of view, the worst school in Australia. The quality of the teaching was first class but the school was a run-down old domestic science school. On a recent visit to that school I was amazed to find that the demountables had all been carpeted, all the old buildings had been refurbished and there was an absolute new spirit in the school. The staff felt that at last someone was thinking about them. They thanked me for what I did, although I am sure that that would have happened anyway in the fullness of time.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it was your representation.

—I thank the honourable member for Charlton for his enthusiasm and his point. Substantial capital works are also going on at Five Dock Public School and Strathfield South High School. In the non-government sector, in my area of Five Dock, I have been able to acquire the first major capital grant to redevelop a primary non-government school at All Hallows Primary School, Five Dock, which also received much publicity on Nationwide and other television programs because of its run-down nature. In fact it reached the stage where the two-storey building, in an old church with a hall above it, had to be closed and was deemed unsafe by engineers. All the children were put into demountable classrooms. There were about 450 students at the school. The state seems still to have forgotten Enfield Primary School and the systemic Catholic system in the archdiocese of Sydney seems to have forgotten St Dominic's at Flemington. I am sure that in the fullness of time something will happen there.

SPEECH.PARA: Tonight I wish to touch on the quality of education in schools. It is one thing for someone to go back to a school after a funeral and say: `My old school looks wonderful. It has a gymnasium now, a swimming pool and facilities that were not dreamed of'. But what is the quality of education? Has it improved since the days of Kim Beazley, who went around and found the Catholic systemic schools using old desks thrown out by the state system, and found three children sitting at desks made for two children in some of the parish schools in Melbourne and Sydney? We know that the class sizes have fallen and that teachers are better trained in that in-service programs and courses for teachers have improved. But what about the real quality of education?

There has been, quite fortuitously, a report, recently released-in April-entitled `Quality of education in Australia'. I praise the Minister for Education, Senator Ryan, for releasing this report. It disappoints me only slightly in that it was hard for that Review Committee to tackle the subject of schools which are substantially comprised of children from families in which English is a second language. In my electorate in Sydney, which is a metropolitan seat, in many of the systemic schools, even in the private schools and in all the state schools, perhaps an overwhelming majority of children come from families in which English is not spoken at home or in which there are no English magazines or books. This is a difficult problem, but neither the State system nor the Catholic system allows for classes for children who at home have nothing in English to which to refer, that is, no English language encyclopaedias or newspapers.

I was disappointed to hear a pupil tell me the other day that in her class in Year 7 in a systemic high school no one watches the Australian Broadcasting Corporation television programs. That disappointed me greatly because we pour a significant amount of money into the ABC. The children watch Bandstand on a Saturday afternoon. I do not blame them for not watching the National because it is on at the wrong time, but it is a pity that no one watches the ABC. Surely part of the purpose of all the funding for the ABC is for its programs of an educational nature. It has wonderful current affairs programs and first class general entertainment programs. It disappointed me greatly that this adjunct of education is just not used in the cities. Perhaps they watch Channel 0-28; I hope they do. But that does not help boys and girls in junior secondary schools who are trying to master the English language. Unless they can do so, they cannot go on to tertiary education; they cannot qualify for entrance to a university or teachers college. This worries me greatly.

The report on the quality of education refers to other reports and other research. But I feel that there are areas into which there should be more research. It is common in all of our capital cities that a vast majority of the children are from families in which English is really out of place. Even in the primary schools I find that, with the influx of Indo-Chinese, the children from families in which English books or English language newspapers would be found represent a tiny minority. That does not mean that the Indo-Chinese children or the children from other ethnic groups are not doing well. They are doing splendidly. At Homebush Boys High School they are forcing the pace, but essentially in mathematics, chemistry, physics and science-not in English. That is what worries me greatly. The report did lack some in-depth research and development into the ethnic schools throughout our capital cities. But it is difficult for any report, sweeping over the whole of the nation and the quality of education, to touch on what is happening in all the cities and all the suburbs.

The committee tried to deal with Aboriginal schools. Those schools are quite distinct. I have seen them in the Kimberleys and areas of the Northern Territory. In my electorate I have only three systemic schools run by the Catholic system in New South Wales, although one of them has gone private. The schools are essentially ethnic schools and each of them finishes at Year 10. The teachers have told me that the children who leave school at Year 10, aged 15, particularly the girls, do not all end up on the dole. Ethnic families put the girls into some job somewhere, even if they are getting only a pittance. The boys school did not have as good a record as the girls school. Of 95 boys who left the Christian Brothers School at Burwood last year about 15 are on the dole. That would be less than the national average of school leavers on the dole, but the number of girls on the dole is fewer than that, so I was quite pleased.

What upsets the school principals is that many bright pupils who could do better things are working in dead-end jobs that are far below their capacity or potential. The jobs are not at all stimulating. For example, a father might work for a tile company and the daughter might be given a position there. If anything, there is a social stigma in the daughter being at home and receiving the dole. I give great praise to the ethnic families who do not want their children to get the dole but to be occupied gainfully and learning at least some skill. It disappoints me greatly that some young people, who leave school with great enthusiasm and all the training and ideas they have, end up not on the dole but in jobs which are far less than they could aspire to and hope for. This is particularly so with children from Italian, Greek and Lebanese families.

I raise this tonight because we are dealing with the appropriations for the Department of Education and the Commonwealth Schools Commission and this report has been released, which I think is of great significance. I cast my mind back to the 1972 election campaign when Kim Beazley Sr, came to the area I represent. He gave a great thrust to education and brought education to the fore in our community and made it a big election issue, which it continued to be until last year or the year before when many of the difficulties and funding problems finally were resolved. At that time the situation almost brought Kim Beasley, the great educationist, to tears. I was with him when he visited the little Catholic Holy Innocents' School at Croydon. He was appalled. We went into a couple of the cottages which the school had brought in 1972 and found groups of children being taught in rooms that had been small bedrooms. Some of the groups were withdrawal groups for English as a second language. Kim Beazley was almost overwhelmed at the time he visited this school.

I went back to this school 10 to 12 years later and found the facilities much improved. There was substantial funding of that school under the Whitlam Administration and a whole new wing was built. Of the two cottages where classes were conducted, one was pulled down and another was turned into a library. Library funding is another issue. There is so little funding for libraries of schools which have a big enrolment of ethnic children who have no access to any English language books, magazines or newspapers.

In 1972 Kim Beazley also visited Haberfield, which is now in the electorate of Sydney. He tried to visit the All Hallows Primary School at Five Dock, which was very run down. Although the sister in charge of the school agreed to allow him in, the parish priest administrator at the time refused to allow him to enter the school. Despite all of that, times have changed and that administrator has gone and the present parish priest greatly welcomed and roundly acknowledged the $400,000 grant from the Federal Government to rebuild the parish school at Five Dock. The questions of education, funding for education and the appropriation for education are very basic to our future and the future of our country.
