DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Public Service-Retired Mine Workers-Goulburn Post Office Investment Trusts-Fuel Costs-Immigration Agents Australia: Culture and Sport-Enterprise Migrant Centre-Australian Flag

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 7.15 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper Mr P.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having received the call last night to speak in the adjournment debate just before the House adjourned at 11 p.m., I was only able to make what must have been one of the shortest speeches ever; it was about 15 seconds in duration. In the circumstances, Mr Speaker, I appreciate your giving me the opportunity to continue my address tonight on the question of Labor's bureaucracy at work. It is apparent, through practical experience, that the public is not getting the service for which it pays and to which it is entitled. The approach of many departments dealing directly with the public in areas often considered sensitive leaves a great deal to be desired. I wish to place before the House two examples that portray the real need for a streamlined, smaller, more efficient Public Service. My main argument is that, in the area of government, small government is good government.

SPEECH.PARA: My first example concerns a constituent who had become a victim of the current Labor induced escalating unemployment situation. Quite naturally, he applied for the unemployment benefit to alleviate short term hardship. My constituent visited his nearest office of the Department of Social Security to carry out this task and, after consulting with a staff member, he believed he would receive his first payment in due course. However, on the day the first cheque was due, the Department informed him that a mistake had been made and there was no record of his application. The call to my office, understandably, was one of anger and frustation.

At this stage it may be appropriate to detail some of my constituent's family background. He is a young married man with a small child who was then some 12 to 18 weeks old. The cheque was needed desperately, not for rent, as he realised he could not possibly meet this, but for food. The Department was particularly unsympathetic. Not only did it appear to be in no great hurry to establish the cause of its error but also it continually shuffled the responsibility for dealing with the case. Staff refused to give their names and this did not help at all. Subsequent telephone calls were delayed while it was established who exactly in the Department was dealing with the situation. Eventually the file miraculously appeared but, alas, more information was needed. Allegedly my constituent had failed to supply the correct details. Why then was this requirement not advised to my constituent previously? In such a critical situation, why did the Department delay telling my constituent what the problem was and how did the file `temporarily' disappear? This example is symptomatic of the attitude of many bureaucratic government departments-departments that appear not to give the public even momentary consideration.

My second example of such bungling bureaucracy concerns the total destruction of a young man's chosen career. My constituent, in an effort to pursue a more worthwhile career, decided to undergo tests to enter the Australian Army. He underwent and passed all the stipulated tests set down for entry. His call-up date was announced and he resigned from his job in preparation. My constituent at this point had met the full requirements that the Department wanted-every requirement for entry into the Service. Medical and other assorted procedures had been carried out with satisfactory results. His proud mother travelled to the Army depot to be present at her son's reception into the Army. However, just three-quarters of an hour before being sworn in the young man was taken before a civilian doctor who found that he had a health problem that prevented his entry into the Army. This was not an obscure or rare problem, but a curvature of the spine which probably would not affect him at all during his working life. The Army, although originally noting that he had one leg slightly longer than the other, had failed to diagnose correctly his full medical condition which, incidentally, I am informed was completely irrelavent to the discharge of his Army duties. Perhaps a quote from my constituent can best convey the explanation offered by the Army:
They made a mistake at the first medical.

What a disgrace! What a scandal! What utter disregard for my constituent's position! A situation such as this should not have been allowed to take place. Not only did my constituent become unemployed but also he was considerably out of pocket due to moneys spent in preparation for his enlistment. In view of such occurrences, who can blame the unemployed youth of today for their bitterness? Not only was this young man unemployed but also he was embittered and disillusioned with the Government and the Public Service sector.

The Public Service is there for a reason. It exists, as the name suggests, to provide a service for members of the public. Its monumental growth unfortunately has not resulted in greater efficiency. It has been a complete disaster. The public's natural suspicion of `red tape' will continue to grow if Labor cannot create a basic humane approach to the outrageous situations I have outlined. The bureaucracy needs to be trimmed and cut down to size. It needs to shed its excess kilos to give it some hope of rehabilitation in the public eye.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to refer to a meeting held recently in Kurri Kurri in my electorate. It was held on Wednesday 4 September and was attended by about 500 retired mine workers. The meeting was precipitated by an instruction given to retired mine workers requiring them to complete the income tax instalment declaration form. Many of those people in the Retired Miners Association are widows of former mine workers and the requirement that these elderly people fill out this form caused them considerable anguish and concern. Recently in Parliament the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon) raised this matter in a very effective way. He made out a strong case for minimising the pressure of bureaucratic requirements on retired or elderly people. It was that situation involving these forms which precipitated this meeting. Of course the meeting responded to those circumstances. I want to refer to the three decisions made unanimously at the meeting. The first one reads:

SPEECH.PARA: This meeting calls upon the responsible government authorities to recognise that the repeated requirements for aged and infirm people causes a great deal of anxiety.

We request our parliamentary representatives to raise this issue inside Parliament and in representations to the appropriate Ministers with the aim of minimising bureaucratic regulation of the lives of retired citizens.
Also we regard as invidious the situation of the elderly and infirm with the privileged position of those with wealthy means who do not pay as much tax as citizens of minimum incomes.
The second resolution, also carried unanimously, says:

We point to several anomalies affecting the living standards of retired persons which make them the most heavily taxed citizens in the Commonwealth. Those circumstances arise from the effects of social security income and assets tests and taxation requirements.
It should be self-evident that non-indexation of income test and the taxation spouse's rebate and pensioners' tax rebate operate to maximise the Government's clawback from pensioners' incomes.

The assets test which supposedly was brought down to eliminate wealthy claimants from social security and war veterans' entitlement is indexed. Commencing at $70,000 for single persons and $100,000 for marrieds it has now been advanced by indexation. Thus a couple with $105,000 assets would have lost $10 a week pension, with indexation that $10 has been restored.
However a pensioner under the income test who also loses $10 a week from pension has not had any of that amount restored. This is invidious to persons on minimal incomes.
We also call upon our parliamentary representatives to publicly press for the rectification of this anomaly and for indexation of taxation spouses and pensioners' rebates.

I interpose to say that I hope that that is one of the matters given consideration by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in the taxation statement which he will soon deliver in this Parliament. The third resolution says:

We support the attempt by the Australian Pensioners Federation to have the tax free threshold of $4,595 substantially increased and indexed. We require this to be included in the deputation to take place with the Treasurer Mr Keating the Miners Federation, the State Council of Retired Mineworkers and also the Northern District Retired Mineworkers and local MPs.

I want also to express my appreciation to Mr E. Withers, the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation at the Newcastle Taxation Office, for the sensitive, responsive and helpful way in which he has responded to these issues. He provided two officers to attend that meeting and for many of those retired mine workers their advice and counselling was of great value. It certainly helped to ease the pressure and concern they were experiencing as a result of the bureaucratic requirement that they make out that return. I also want to thank the leaders and the executive of those retired mine workers associations in my area for the dedication and commitment they bring to their responsibilities and for the leadership they provide for all of those retired mine workers with whom they worked in the past and for whom they feel a continuing responsibility and commitment.

Tonight in this chamber I call upon the Minister for Communications to act on this matter. I will be in contact with him again. I hope he will take heed of my advice. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gear Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct the attention of honourable members to an advertisement which appeared on page 7 of the West Australian of 9 September. The advertisement was designed to entice people to invest money in an organisation known as the Australian Scholarship Trust. These were the emotive words used in the advertisement:

SPEECH.PARA: How will your young children be employed in the year two thousand? or will they be employed at all?

It went on to extol the virtues of the Trust, asking parents of children under 10 years of age to protect their future by investing funds now which will be returned at a later stage and which will provide money to enable them to receive a specialist education. It indicated that in this way parents would avoid their children joining the ranks of the unemployed when they have finished their secondary education. Many honourable members will no doubt be asking themselves why I am raising the issue of this particular advertisement. The reason will become plain.

In 1983 concerned constituents contacted me after they had been approached by representatives of the Australian Scholarship Trust. I do not question the veracity or otherwise of that Trust or the associated Independant Provident Society of Victoria. However, I do question their marketing techniques which I regard as aggressive, questionable, misleading and emotive. The trust's representatives contact people whose names have been given to them by other clients. I believe that they offer the inducement of a free T-shirt or some other equally worthwhile prize if a person provides the names of 10 contacts who can be followed up. If a person is contacted after being nominated by a friend or neighbour, it has been the practice for the Trust's representative not to leave a contact number where he or she can be reached. Instead, such representatives say that it would be easier for the Trust to contact the potential clients and they suggest that a counsellor will make contact with them. In fact, the advertisement I mentioned was the first time that I had seen a contact address displayed publicly and when I return to Perth I will investigate 245 Churchill Avenue, Subiaco, to find out what sort of address it is and whether people can actually speak to anyone from the Trust if they visit it.

Having made contact with a prospective client, the representatives proceed with a well-orchestrated sales pitch which make parents feel that they are in some way lacking in their role if they do not commit themselves to paying part of their family allowance into the Trust over a number of years so that they can receive a scholarship to assist with tertiary education for their children. There is no guarantee as to the amount of the scholarship.

That the Trust's methods are aggressive is borne out by investigation undertaken by the Consumer Affairs Bureau in Perth in 1983. At that time the Trust used promotional material bearing photographs of the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) and the Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones) and extracts from some of their speeches, the implication being that the Ministers endorsed the product. They did not. In fact, the first that Susan Ryan knew of it was when she visited my electorate and it was brought to our attention by a constituent. This person was one who had been approached and who had signed up for the Trust, but had had second thoughts. Using the cooling off period provisions, my constituent had withdrawn from the agreement and had asked the Trust for a refund of his initial payment. He was, however, having difficulties obtaining a refund of this money. I was able to bring pressure to bear on the company concerned and my constituent's money was refunded. At that time I put out a Press release which was printed in one of the local papers in my electorate-the Comment News, a very good member of an excellent group of community newspapers. Subsequently I recieved a very aggressive phone call from a representative of the Trust objecting to my publicising what I felt were unfair selling practices. I made no apologies then, and I make none now. It concerns me that this organisation is again touting for business in such an emotive and, I believe, dubious manner. I can only repeat my warnings of two years ago: People should approach any such Trust with extreme caution. This view is supported by the Director of the Consumer Affairs Bureau in Western Australia, Mr Dick Fletcher, who was quoted in a recent article in Comment News as follows:
If anyone is approached to join an educational trust scheme I would strongly advise them to look at all schemes, not just the one making the approach.
I fully endorse Mr Fletcher's sentiments and ask other honourable members to be alert to the aggressive marketing tactics of the Trust about which I have been speaking.

The scheme being offered is nothing more than an investment marketing strategy and potential clients would be better advised to consult a bank manager or investment advisor who could no doubt offer a better way of investing money. A particularly odious selling technique is to induce potential clients to invest their family allowance in the scheme when this was never the intention of the allowance in the first place. Tertiary education is free in Australia and this removes the need for a scheme of this kind. In conclusion, I would again strongly advise potential clients to investigate this dubious scheme thoroughly and examine alternative ways of investing their money.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr I.M.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to refute some of the ridiculous economic statements made by the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) in the House today about the cost of fuel to farmers. Kerin, the swivel-chair farmer, has been stating all day that, because of devaluation, the price of fuel has not risen. I inform the Labor Government that devaluation has nowhere near offset the enormous increase in fuel costs to farmers and other people in the community. This year the price of wheat has gone up by only $1.30 a tonne and, of course, the price of sugar is disastrously low. No one could argue that sugar growers in this country have had any relief from devaluation.

SPEECH.PARA: Ten years ago, the wholesale price of fuel was 11.94 cents a litre. It is now 51.84 cents a litre, and has increased 434 per cent in that period-the past year it has risen 43 per cent. Ten years ago distillate cost 12.79 cents a litre. Tomorrow it will be 51.33 cents a litre. Tomorrow there will actually be a slight decrease in the price of petrol of 1.63 cents a litre, due to various adjustments that take place. Crude oil excise has also risen dramatically under the Hawke socialist Government. In 1983-84 it was $3.6 billion. In the current Budget estimate it is $4.4 billion. The farmers comprise the hardest hit sector.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, cut it out; not again.

—That is right, Gerry, and you know it. The farmers are the hardest hit sector in the community when it comes to fuel prices and taxes. Last year farmers paid $372 million net fuel tax to Treasury. This year it is estimated that the so-called world Treasurer (Mr Keating) has put up to $438 million taxes on farmers. That is what the farmers are paying. There are 170,000 hard-working primary producers in Australia, and on average they pay $2,600 in fuel taxes per farm. That is to be compared to each Australian household, which pays only $870 in fuel tax. One can see that farmers are being discriminated against. They are being asked to pay by this Labor socialist Government three times more in fuel taxes. How can the Minister for Primary Industry argue that as the result of devaluation farmers have not been affected by rapidly increasing fuel prices?

SPEECH.PARA: Farmers use 10 per cent of all diesel and petrol consumed in Australia. Since the mini-Budget, when the fuel price subsidy scheme was abolished by the Australian Labor Party, primary producers in many areas have had to cop an increase of 4 cents a litre on fuel. Farmers are now using 10,000 litres of fuel per farm each year, which is five times more than is used in the ordinary Australian household. I ask the present Government to see whether it can do something to reduce the cost of fuel taxes to the farmers of Australia.

The National Party of Australia has an excellent policy on fuel and we will continue to look at freeing up the oil market. I believe in the current trend towards privatisation-I direct my remarks to our side of the House in particular-and the first industry that should be de-socialised is the crude oil industry. The $4.4 billion excise should be taken out of the fuel industry and given back to the rightful owners, the crude oil producers. The Government should pick up the taxes from the people as they consume fuel, in sales taxes and so on. We must free up and privatise some of these industries. I shall be arguing and fighting hard with the Treasurer, the shadow Treasurer and with the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) for a freeing up of fuel prices and a withdrawal of excise taxes. If that can be done, we can bring about some reduction in costs. The National Party when it is returned to office at the next election will reintroduce the fuel freight subsidy scheme. The fishing industry-and legislation on that subject was dealt with in the House today-will be exempt from the excise levy it now pays. It is ridiculous that fishermen have to pay this excise. I thank you for your patience, Mr Speaker.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hand Mr G.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today's Australia has been built by settlers from all over the world. Our way of life, our rich culture and, indeed, our sound economic base are due in no small part to the contributions of people born in other countries who have made this country their home. It is no wonder that people want to settle in this country with all its opportunities. But there are also people who wish to exploit that desire for their own greed, and who cause potential immigrants and their families a lot of pain and anguish-not to mention the money they rip off their clients and the people who are harassed and intimidated on the way through. This brings me to the purpose of my speech tonight, which is to call for tighter controls on the practices and code of conduct of immigration agents. I am glad to hear that a government party committee is looking into this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: I specifically draw the attention of the House to one particular individual who has deliberately flouted even the most basic code of decent behaviour pertaining to agents assisting migrants into this country. That person is James Ghassan Rouda, born sometime between 1937 and 1940-depending on which official form that he has completed one wishes to choose. Mr Rouda has earned himself an unenviable reputation as a bully, a man prone to abusive, aggressive behaviour, and a man who has a history of misrepresenting facts when referring matters to members of parliament. That is one of my main concerns and why I raise this matter tonight.

An undischarged bankrupt since 1969, Mr Rouda has, since then, registered as a director of at least one company, which places him in breach of the Companies Act. I preface my remarks on this aspect of Mr Rouda's activities by saying that for his dubious services Mr Rouda charges far in excess of the prescribed fee, which puts him in breach of section 50 (4) of the Migration Act-yet another notch to his criminal belt. Since 1968, the first year that he commenced acting as an immigration agent, I am told that complaints have been lodged to both the Department of Immigration and the police about Rouda. Has he also breached the Bankruptcy Act by failing to surrender his passport? I wonder whether he has handed that in. That is not to mention his straight criminal diversions, which include convictions for unlawful assault, indecent language and making false statements.

It is his actions in relation to the acquisition of residency for his hapless clients which I find particularly bad. These complaints centre on the passing of worthless cheques, possible exploitation of Lebanese applicants for migrant entry, and an unsound financial record involving a series of County Court judgments being made against him. His declared bankruptcy the following year hardly comes as a surprise. This did not, however, stop Rouda in his tracks. He emerged the following year in Beirut running the Kangaroo Real Estate and Investment Co., which boasted in Arabic newspapers that, for a fee, Rouda could arrange migration to Australia. The Australian Embassy in Beirut received complaints that fees had been paid to Rouda without the promises being fulfilled.

I personally know of eight cases in which Rouda has extracted money from people-sometimes up to $2,000-in return for the promise of permanent resident status in Australia. This puts parliamentarians in an impossible situation. This person comes into our office, hands us a file, and says: `I want you to act for a friend of mine'. He then leaves the office and charges individuals $2,000 and implies that he pays or bribes parliamentarians or officers of departments for carrying out that service. Rouda's modus operandi includes intimidation and harassment of immigration officials. I am sure that that statement can be checked. In one instance in which he fell out with his clients, there were threatening and abusive phone calls which included the disgusting threat to bomb a person's car or to set up a person by planting drugs in his car.

This poor excuse for a human being should not be able by law to act as an immigration agent. The loopholes which allow these deplorable types of people to play on the vulnerability of intending settlers should be well and truly shut tight. At present the provisions of the Migration Act which cover immigration agents are wide open to abuse by people such as this, and those people who act on behalf of visitors who seek to change status to that of permanent residents are not covered under the Migration Act at all.

People such as Mr Rouda cause frictions in our society that we can all do without. I repeat: Rouda places people such as ourselves, who act on behalf of other people in good faith, under a tremendous threat. We are open to all sorts of charges when in fact we are acting in a very innocent way. Our society can well do without Mr Rouda and people like him. Effective control of the activities of migration agents will ensure our freedom from such individuals. I urge the Government to take action against people such as Rouda, because there are many like him. If honourable members want me to name other such people in other cities, I can do that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish tonight to endeavour to reawaken the Australian conscious. There was a time in this country when we were very proud indeed to buy an article labelled `Australian made'. I suspect that in recent times we have got away from that rather rugged outlook of being Australians and being proud of that. I want to comment on several matters to emphasise the point I am making and to indicate that it is about time that we as Australians started to sing the praise of our country. I want to talk about certain things that have happened recently. Last Tuesday night in Brisbane, at the Lyric Theatre, which is part of the delightfully built and exquisitely turned-out performing Arts complex-a great tribute to the Government and people of Queensland-
—And the workers.

—The workers played a part in building it. I acknowledge that because they were Australian tradesmen. My wife and I had the privilege of being present at the opening night of a performance by the Bolshoi Ballet. Of course, that was a rich and rewarding experience. But I state publicly that the Bolshoi Ballet is not as good as the Australian Ballet. It is true that the members of the Bolshoi Ballet were precise in their movements and executed every step with automatic precision, but to me it seemed as though their hearts were not in their dancing. That is not a criticism of a ballet company which is recognised world wide. But when I have the privilege of being part and parcel of an audience at a performance of the Australian Ballet, I have a feeling of exhilaration, delight and refreshment at watching true artists at work. I think it is about time that we in Australia started to let people know that we have ballet dancers, choreographers, directors and others involved in the various artistic fields who are world class.

SPEECH.PARA: Recently, in that game which is recognised as being a maker of men, an Australian side played rugby union against the Home Countries. It is wonderful to realise that the Australian team was victorious in every encounter. Those of us who love beauty and the flow of a great sport will remember forever the pushover try scored by the Australian eight against the Welsh eight-widely recognised as the greatest exponents of rugby rucking and mauling in the world. Implicit in those victories overseas and in the great victories achieved in Australia has been the performance of the Australian front row. In particular, I pay tribute tonight to Andy McIntyre. I am pleased that the scribes from Sydney have finally woken up to the fact that the Australian Wallabies have been so successful in recent years because the front row forwards, comprising Andy McIntyre, Rodriguez, McBain and Lawton, have been able to hold their own when the going gets tough. When the torches are put to their bellies they do not take a backward step. The scribes are now saying that the best rugby union player in Australia is Andy McIntyre. He was unknown and unsung, but he is in there when the going is tough. I am proud to inform the Parliament that his father is a member of my electorate committee. Andy McIntyre is a tribute to his parents and to the Darling Downs.

The third point that I raise concerns another issue which emphasises that if something is labelled Australian made we should be proud of it and acknowledge that we are the best in the world. Let others follow us, secure in the knowledge that if they can at least come near us, their attainment is almost approaching perfection because we are perfection. I refer to the racehorse Strawberry Road, which is now recognised in the world as being a top-class racehorse.

TALK.START.PARA: —The best.

—As the honourable member says, he is the best. It has been proved internationally. This horse is not like some other horses in Australia which have won $1m by racing on Australian tracks. This horse raced on tracks overseas and beat the others on their own tracks. I am delighted that the honourable member shares my enthusiasm. It is interesting to note that the real reason why that horse has been successful is that when he was being mouded and trained-again, unknown and unsung-he was in the tender care of a Mr Bougoure from Brisbane. It is only incidental that he is a product of a Darling Downs family. He is homegrown, and learnt his art in the local area. Those were the points that I wanted to raise tonight. I implore everyone not to worry too much about how much the bicentennial celebrations will cost us in 1988, but to recognise the fact that we are top-class people and the label `Australian made' is a good one.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent Mr L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to bring to the attention of the House the closure of the Enterprise Migrant Centre in Springvale, which was announced by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford) recently. It is not a pleasure for me to criticise my Government's decision. However, I am of the opinion that the closure will harm the long term settlement prospects of migrants arriving in this country. When announcing the closure the Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: The era of big, institutionalised migrant centres is over.

He went on to say that the centre will be closed and after a couple of years it will be refurbished and reopened if an experiment elsewhere proves satisfactory. There are so many ifs in the statement that I believe that if the centre is closed now it will never been reopened. The closure is set for 30 October and the occupants will be shifted into the Maribyrnong Midway Migrant Centre. The Midway hostel is situated in the depressed western area of Melbourne and will be the only remaining hostel in Victoria. Not only will the current occupants of Enterprise be herded into the western suburbs but all future arrivals will be directed to that area.

It is a well-known fact-I know it from my own experience-that most migrants will settle in the area in which they first arrived. This is mainly because of the insecurity of new arrivals. If the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs directs them into the only hostel in the State they will settle in the area a few square miles around it. When I arrived as a migrant to this country I did not go into a hostel but into a family situation; yet even today, 31 years later, I live only a couple of miles from the place where we first settled. So I ask the Minister to take this fact into account and to envisage what will happen to the western suburbs of Melbourne, already heavily populated by migrants and generally over populated altogether.

In those areas there are 20 houses to an acre instead of four to an acre such as in Springvale and the surrounding suburbs. We do not want to create Birmingham here. The Minister and his Department should take heed of what happens in other countries and places where migrants are herded together. The western suburbs of Melbourne are already depressed and, if we direct all future migrants there, it will be bad for those suburbs, it will be bad for the new arrivals and it will have future disastrous social consequences for our whole community.

Instead of closing hostels we should be opening more so that migrants are given the opportunity to settle into an average suburban environment, to spread amongst the rest of the populaton instead of being herded into giant migrant ghettos, without adequate services and adequate opportunity to settle into an Australian way of life. I hope that the Government and the Minister will take note of my remarks and reverse the decision. The decision to close the hostel has been made by the bureaucracy without consultation with the local population or ethnic groups. It is a typical decision of an unthinking bureaucracy wanting to save money at present and not thinking how much this decision will cost us in future. I say again: Look at Birmingham.

It is not only I who am alarmed because of the inane decision of the Department; so are all the councillors for the city of Springvale. They resolved to write to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and also to call a public protest meeting against the closure. I have already received sheets of petitions signed by the people in the area who are concerned about it. Finally, 62 employees of the hostel sent me a letter which they had signed-practically every employee who is facing the sack. In their petition they stated:

We the staff feel the closure has been forthcoming without any consideration whatsoever to us. We also feel the decision to keep Midway centre running is a disastrous mistake. The western suburbs are already extensively populated . . . The Enterprise Centre is the best kept centre in Victoria if not Australia. It is also the newest with its gardens, play areas and recreation youth centre, with many modern facilities.
The staff of Enterprise have always taken pride in maintaining this Centre and to close it would be criminal.
In view of the widespread dissatisfaction in the area I ask the Minister to reconsider the decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —I say to the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Kent) that blaming the bureaucracy is perhaps the easy way out if one is a member of the Government at the time. The system in this country is that ministerial responsibility pertains. If that hostel is being closed it is most appropriate to say that the Labor Government is closing it. There is no blaming some distant bureaucrat and hoping that people will be hoodwinked. It is the honourable member's Government which has made that decision. It may be a right decision-I do not know-but one cannot hide from the reality that it is a decision of the honourable member's Party and his Government.
—He's severely embarrassed the Minister.

—The Minister is not even here; he has fled. The matter I raise this evening is that of integrity. The honourable member for Hotham mentioned that the councillors of Springvale will write to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). They should save the 33c postage because it is a waste of time. I will give an example to the House so that history will record it. On 22 April-only a handful of months ago-the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan) asked:

SPEECH.PARA: I address a question to the Prime Minister. In view of the recently conducted Morgan gallop poll, which shows that by far the greater percentage of Australians do not favour a change in the design of the Australian flag, will he give an assurance that there will not be any change at all to our national flag?
On that day the Prime Minister answered:

We intend to be in government for a very long time but I am not presumptuous enough to answer for eternity. The Government does not have this item on the agenda and I do not see it emerging on the agenda.

That was on 22 April. Yet in July the Department of Education and Youth Affairs a department which is directly responsible to the Prime Minister, gave the Ausflag group $3,000 to fund its postage to write to all schools in Australia inviting them to participate-

TALK.START.PARA: —So what's wrong with that?
—It is the Government's integrity. The honourable member does not even understand integrity.
—Order! The honourable member for Hindmarsh will cease interjecting. The honourable member for Moreton will address the Chair.

—Thank you, Mr Speaker. The point I am endeavouring to make is that the Prime Minister told the Parliament on 22 April that a change in the design of the Australian flag was not on the agenda and that he was not presumptuous enough to answer for eternity. The definition of `eternity' for the Prime Minister is obviously no more than three months or he would not have used that word. The people of Australia have every reason to doubt anything that Robert James Lee Hawke says. He stood in the Parliament in April and said: `We are not even looking at it'. Yet in July he funded a campaign to change the flag. The decision must have been made before the announcement. It was probably in the pipeline when he said that in the Parliament. He is a man without integrity. I notice that the former Minister for Defence, the Minister for Territories (Mr Scholes), is at the table. I ask him why his Party is so determined to change all the symbols of this nation. The Minister had to step in against public outcry when the Government tried to remove, I think, the Queen's Shoot, which was a display-
—The Queen's Medal.

—For the Queen's Medal. His action was a display of absolute pettiness. The Victoria Cross-a medal of honour for valour-was something else which the Labor Government was going to stamp out because in its mind it represented the United Kingdom. When it comes to the Australian flag, 70 per cent of Australia's population says: `Leave it alone'. The honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mr Scott) asked: `What is wrong with changing it?'. What is wrong with changing it? For heaven's sake, let democracy have a say. The vast majority of Australians are happy with the flag without the Prime Minister resorting to underhand methods to fund changes.
